question_text: An 84-year-old woman with Alzheimer disease is brought to the physician by her son for a follow-up examination. The patient lives with her son, who is her primary caregiver. He reports that it is becoming gradually more difficult to care for her. She occasionally has tantrums and there are times when she does not recognize him. She sleeps 6–8 hours throughout the day and is increasingly agitated and confused at night. When the phone, television, or oven beeps she thinks she is at the dentist's office and becomes very anxious. She eats 2–3 meals a day and has a good appetite. She has not fallen. She has not left the home in weeks except for short walks. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and hypothyroidism. She takes levothyroxine, aspirin, warfarin, donepezil, verapamil, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and a multivitamin daily.  Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. It is important to the family that the patient continues her care at home. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: An 84-year-old woman with Alzheimer disease is brought to the physician by her son for a follow-up examination. The patient lives with her son, who is her primary caregiver. He reports that it is becoming gradually more difficult to care for her. She occasionally has tantrums and there are times when she does not recognize him. She sleeps 6–8 hours throughout the day and is increasingly agitated and confused at night. When the phone, television, or oven beeps she thinks she is at the dentist's office and becomes very anxious. She eats 2–3 meals a day and has a good appetite. She has not fallen. She has not left the home in weeks except for short walks. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and hypothyroidism. She takes levothyroxine, aspirin, warfarin, donepezil, verapamil, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and a multivitamin daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. It is important to the family that the patient continues her care at home. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
hint: Sleep disturbances are common in the later stages of Alzheimer disease and can result in anxiety and further disruption of patients' cognitive status.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate recommendation for managing sleep disturbances in Alzheimer disease.

answers.explanation_why: Quetiapine can be used to manage agitation, hallucinations, and insomnia in patients with Alzheimer disease. Although this patient is agitated and has been having difficulty sleeping, pharmacological treatment would only be indicated if nonpharmacological interventions had failed. Behavioral therapies have the same or increased efficacy compared to antipsychotic medications in this patient population.

Lorazepam is useful for managing symptoms of panic, anxiety, or stress disorders. Although this patient has symptoms of anxiety, nonpharmacological interventions should be attempted prior to resorting to medications. In addition, benzodiazepines are less effective than atypical antipsychotics in treating anxiety in patients with Alzheimer disease.

answers.content: Adhere to a regular sleep schedule
answers.explanation_why: Behavioral and environmental regulation, such as adhering to a regular sleep schedule, maintaining a familiar environment, and removing ambient noise, should always be attempted for patients who are agitated or anxious before resorting to pharmacological treatment. This patient's anxiety is likely a consequence of her dysregulated sleep (i.e., nighttime insomnia and daytime hypersomnia) and resulting disorientation. Efforts to regulate a patient's environment and schedule can help them to remain oriented and can improve symptoms.

Verapamil use is rarely complicated by insomnia or agitation (≤ 1% of cases). Other more likely causes of this patient's symptoms should be addressed before verapamil is discontinued, especially given that this is not a newly prescribed medication. Additionally, if verapamil were discontinued, this patient's atrial fibrillation and/or hypertension may no longer be well-controlled.

This patient is already struggling with ambient sounds (e.g., phone, television, oven beeping). Although classical music can have a calming effect, it would contribute to the ambient noise, which may further confuse and disorient this patient.

Haloperidol is often used to treat agitation or delirium. Although this patient is agitated, nonpharmacological interventions should be attempted prior to resorting to medications. In addition, atypical antipsychotics are usually preferred over typical antipsychotics when treating anxiety and agitation in patients with Alzheimer disease because of the decreased risk of extrapyramidal symptoms.

Cognitive behavioral therapy can be helpful for patients with Alzheimer disease, particularly those with anxiety. This step may eventually be an appropriate treatment for this patient, since she has been anxious at times during the day. However, she is having anxiety in the context of an aberrant sleep schedule, leading to disorientation. Environmental changes should first be attempted to manage her symptoms.

question_text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of concerns about his memory. His wife reports that over the past 7 months he has gradually become more forgetful. He commonly misplaces his car keys and forgets his children's names. He seems to have forgotten how to make dinner and sometimes serves uncooked noodles or raw meat. One night he parked his car in a neighbor's bushes and was found wandering the street. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and COPD. Current medications include atorvastatin, metoprolol, ipratropium, and fluticasone. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is alert and oriented to person and place only. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 19/30. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, creatinine, thyroid-stimulating hormone, liver function tests, vitamin B_12 (cobalamin), and folate are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

One night he parked his car in a neighbor's bushes and was found wandering the street. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and COPD. Current medications include atorvastatin, metoprolol, ipratropium, and fluticasone. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is alert and oriented to person and place only. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 19/30. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, creatinine, thyroid-stimulating hormone, liver function tests, vitamin B12 (cobalamin), and folate are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: This patient has several signs of dementia including forgetfulness, impaired judgment, and disorientation. The diagnosis is supported by his Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score (13–20 points: moderate dementia). His clinical and laboratory workup for reversible causes of dementia (e.g., vitamin B_12 deficiency, hypothyroidism, etc.) have been unremarkable.
learning_objective: Recognize signs of dementia, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Lumbar puncture and subsequent CSF analysis may be helpful in diagnosing specific etiologies of dementia, particularly those of rapid- or early-onset, including meningitis or encephalitis. While this patient exhibits several hallmarks of dementia, his course of development has been relatively slow and subtle. Moreover, his unremarkable vital signs (without evidence of fever or tachycardia), physical examination without neck stiffness or focal neurological deficits, and laboratory findings (without an elevated white blood cell count) decrease suspicion for encephalitis and meningitis as acute causes of dementia for which lumbar puncture would be diagnostically useful.

Neuropsychologic testing is useful for identifying patients with dementia and in documenting cognitive function over time but has limited utility in differentiating causes of dementia, as there is substantial overlap of the types of deficits involved. Because this patient's clinical history and examination results strongly suggest a diagnosis of dementia, neuropsychologic testing is unlikely to provide additional diagnostic information.

The ε4 allele of the Apolipoprotein E gene is associated with late-onset Alzheimer disease (AD). A positive genotype test may increase clinical suspicion for AD and help to stratify risk for progression. However, false positives and negatives do occur, and ApoE genotyping is not routinely used in clinical settings. Moreover, while this 72-year-old patient's relatively slow neurocognitive decline and his MMSE score may be consistent with a diagnosis of AD, there are other potential causes of dementia that are also consistent with his clinical course, and a broader diagnostic approach is more appropriate to address this differential.

Electroencephalography allows characterization of the electrical activity of the cortex and may aid in localizing seizures, which may increase suspicion for structural abnormalities. However, in this older patient with slowly and steadily progressive dementia and without evidence of seizures, EEG is unlikely to aid in identifying the etiology of his condition.

Functional neuroimaging with a PET scan may reveal distinct patterns that are associated with specific etiologies of dementia (e.g., amyloid CNS lesions, and the presence of localized hypoperfusion in Alzheimer disease or FTD). However, there are numerous other possible etiologies of his neurocognitive decline (e.g., CNS tumor, cerebrovascular disease) that could be detected with other diagnostic studies. PET scans are relatively expensive, provide very specific data, and are not without risk and, as such, would not be appropriate as a first-line imaging modality in this patient with a relatively broad remaining differential.

In patients presenting with new-onset neurocognitive defects, neuroimaging with noncontrast head CT or MRI helps exclude pathologies such as CNS tumors, subdural hematoma, or normal pressure hydrocephalus. Specific atrophy or lesion patterns may be associated with particular etiologies, e.g., multiple lacunar infarcts in vascular dementia (VD) or reduced hippocampal volume in Alzheimer disease (AD). In older adults with a slow, insidious onset of dementia and only cognitive deficits, such as this patient, AD and VD are among the most common causes of dementia, and MRI findings may help guide the next steps in management.

question_text: Six days after undergoing surgical repair of a hip fracture, a 71-year-old man is agitated and confused. Last night, he was restrained after multiple attempts to leave his room. His overnight nurse reported that she observed several periods of rest followed by sudden episodes of agitation without a clear trigger. He has hypertension and COPD. He previously smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks one glass of whiskey per day. His current medications include oxycodone, hydrochlorothiazide, and salmeterol. He appears agitated. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 141/84 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows a prolonged expiratory phase but no other abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows inattentiveness and no focal findings. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. During the examination, the patient becomes violent, pulls out his intravenous line, and attempts to leave the room. He does not respond to verbal deescalation techniques, and soft restraints are used. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Six days after undergoing surgical repair of a hip fracture, a 71-year-old man is agitated and confused. Last night, he was restrained after multiple attempts to leave his room. His overnight nurse reported that she observed several periods of rest followed by sudden episodes of agitation without a clear trigger. He has hypertension and COPD. He previously smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks one glass of whiskey per day. His current medications include oxycodone, hydrochlorothiazide, and salmeterol. He appears agitated. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 141/84 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows a prolonged expiratory phase but no other abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows inattentiveness and no focal findings. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. During the examination, the patient becomes violent, pulls out his intravenous line, and attempts to leave the room. He does not respond to verbal deescalation techniques, and soft restraints are used. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The patient's age, recent surgery, immobilization, and opioid use place him at high risk for delirium.
learning_objective: Recognize delirium with refractory agitation, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: A urine culture may be indicated if a urinary tract infection is the suspected underlying cause of a patient's delirium. However, because this patient is agitated and violent, another step in management is indicated before conducting diagnostic studies.

A chest x-ray may be indicated if pneumonia is the suspected underlying cause of a patient's delirium. However, this patient is afebrile, and his lungs are clear to auscultation, making pneumonia unlikely. Also, obtaining a chest x-ray in an agitated and violent patient is difficult. Another step in management is indicated before conducting diagnostic studies.

answers.content: Obtain CT scan of the head
answers.explanation_why: Neuroimaging (e.g., CT scan of the head) may be indicated if an intracranial condition (e.g., stroke) is the suspected cause of a patient's delirium. However, this patient has no focal findings that suggest intracranial pathology. Also, obtaining a CT scan in an agitated and violent patient is difficult. Another step in management is indicated before conducting diagnostic studies.

Benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam) are deliriogenic and are typically reserved for patients with delirium due to alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal. Although this patient's drinking pattern increases his risk of developing alcohol withdrawal delirium, this condition usually occurs 72–96 hours after the last drink and typically manifests with hallucinations and tremors.

The initial management of delirium includes nonpharmacologic supportive measures (e.g., reorienting the patient to time, place, and person). In patients with agitation, additional measures, such as deescalation techniques, are used. Coercive measures (e.g., physical restraints) may be necessary if the patient is actively violent. A calming medication should be used before or immediately after applying restraints to reduce the risk of injury and negative psychological consequences. An antipsychotic (e.g., haloperidol) is the calming medication of choice for refractory agitation in patients with delirium. After adequate sedation has been achieved, restraints should be removed immediately.

question_text: A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of increasing muscle pain and stiffness, weakness of her shoulders and legs, and generalized fatigue. She has been having great difficulty getting out of bed in the morning. On two occasions, her son had to come over and help her stand up. She has had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss and has not been sleeping well during this period. She has had multiple episodes of left-sided headaches and pain in the jaw while chewing over the past 2 months. She had a fall and hit her head on the staircase banister 3 months ago. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 128/88 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. Range of motion of the shoulder and hip is mildly limited by pain. Muscle strength in bilateral upper and lower extremities is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. On mental status examination, she admits her mood “is not that great.” Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 79 mm/h, and her serum creatine kinase concentration is 38 U/L. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's headaches?
content_preview: A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of increasing muscle pain and stiffness, weakness of her shoulders and legs, and generalized fatigue. She has been having great difficulty getting out of bed in the morning. On two occasions, her son had to come over and help her stand up. She has had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss and has not been sleeping well during this period. She has had multiple episodes of left-sided headaches and pain in the jaw while chewing over the past 2 months. She had a fall and hit her head on the staircase banister 3 months ago. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 128/88 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. Range of motion of the shoulder and hip is mildly limited by pain. Muscle strength in bilateral upper and lower extremities is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. On mental status examination, she admits her mood “is not that great.” Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 79 mm/h, and her serum creatine kinase concentration is 38 U/L. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's headaches?
hint: This 76-year-old woman has muscle pain and stiffness (worse in the mornings) of the shoulder and lower extremity in combination with weight loss, fever, a normal neurologic examination, and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), indicating polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR).
learning_objective: Recognize giant cell arteritis.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) can cause slowly progressive chronic headaches and fatigue and should be considered in patients with a history of head trauma. However, chronic SDH often causes cognitive impairment and/or focal neurologic deficits, neither of which is seen in this patient. In addition, chronic SDH does not cause fever, jaw pain, or an increased ESR.

Tension headaches are usually bilateral, not unilateral, and manifest with dull, pressure-like or band-like pain, often triggered by stress. They do not typically cause unilateral pain, fever, weight loss, jaw pain, or an increased ESR.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is a large- and medium-vessel vasculitis that most commonly develops in older individuals. This patient's constitutional symptoms (fever, weakness, weight loss) with additional symptoms of PMR, unilateral headache and jaw pain (from inflammation of the temporal artery), and an increased ESR are all suggestive of this disease. PMR is highly associated with giant cell arteritis; ∼ 50% of patients with GCA have PMR, and ∼ 20% of patients with PMR have GCA. Prompt diagnosis (via temporal artery biopsy) and treatment are warranted to prevent serious complications, such as visual loss (from anterior ischemic optic neuropathy) and cerebral ischemia.

Though migraine headaches can manifest with unilateral headaches, these are frequently accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. In addition, a typical aura (visual scotomas, paresis) may be present. The absence of these symptoms, as well as the presence of constitutional symptoms (weight loss, weakness, fatigue) and an increased ESR, make migraine headaches an unlikely diagnosis for this patient.

Temporomandibular joint dysfunction can cause unilateral facial pain and unilateral headache radiating to the jaw that is triggered by chewing. However, this condition does not cause constitutional symptoms (weight loss, weakness), symptoms of PMR, or an increased ESR.

question_text: A 77-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion and unusual behavior for 2 days. She has been mumbling to herself and wandering around the neighborhood. These symptoms are worse in the evenings and she has hardly slept at night. She has not been eating or drinking much for the past 6 days.  She has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. She was diagnosed with breast cancer 12 years ago and was treated with left-sided mastectomy. The patient is oriented to person but not to place or time. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a supple neck. Neurologic examination shows psychomotor agitation. Attention and concentration are impaired; she makes multiple errors while performing the serial sevens test. Her speech is disorganized. Her fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 122 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 77-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion and unusual behavior for 2 days. She has been mumbling to herself and wandering around the neighborhood. These symptoms are worse in the evenings and she has hardly slept at night. She has not been eating or drinking much for the past 6 days. She has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. She was diagnosed with breast cancer 12 years ago and was treated with left-sided mastectomy. The patient is oriented to person but not to place or time. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a supple neck. Neurologic examination shows psychomotor agitation. Attention and concentration are impaired; she makes multiple errors while performing the serial sevens test. Her speech is disorganized. Her fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 122 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The acute onset of fluctuating confusion, inattention, and agitation with a classical “sundowning” pattern (worsening of symptoms in the evening) indicates delirium. What would be the most likely cause of delirium in this older woman, given her medical history?
learning_objective: Recognize delirium in an older patient, and choose the most appropriate initial diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: A lumbar puncture would be performed if meningitis were suspected as the underlying cause of this patient's delirium. Delirium may be due to any kind of infection, including a urinary tract infection or meningitis. However, this patient does not display any signs of infection (e.g., tachycardia, fever) and her neck is supple, making meningitis unlikely.

Serum TSH levels would be checked if hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism were the suspected cause of this patient's delirium. However, this patient does not display any other symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation) or hyperthyroidism (e.g., fatigue, heat intolerance, excessive sweating, palpitations, weight loss despite increased appetite, diarrhea) in the past and also does not show signs of them on physical exam (e.g., cold, dry skin, delayed tendon reflex relaxation, or bradycardia in hypothyroidism; warm skin, tremor, or tachycardia in hyperthyroidism). It would also be unlikely for a thyroid disorder to initially manifest with delirium.

Serum electrolytes should be checked in patients who present with signs of delirium without an obvious etiology (e.g., infection, intoxication, or history of head trauma). In this 77-year-old woman, an electrolyte disturbance is the most likely cause of her delirium, given she has not been eating and drinking adequately for the past few days. In addition, she takes hydrochlorothiazide, which can cause hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypercalcemia, hyperglycemia, and dehydration. Approx. 30% of cases of delirium in older individuals are the result of medications.

answers.content: Perform CT scan of the head
answers.explanation_why: A CT scan of the head would be done if a brain pathology (e.g., intracranial bleeding, stroke, brain metastases) were the suspected cause of this patient's delirium. Although she had breast cancer in the past, it is unlikely that it metastasized to her brain more than 10 years after it was treated curatively. She also has no other risk factors (e.g., falling on her head, taking blood thinners) or findings on physical exam (e.g., focal neurologic deficits) that point towards a brain pathology.

A chest x-ray would be indicated if pneumonia were the suspected cause of this patient's delirium. However, this patient does not display any signs of infection (e.g., fever, tachycardia, tachypnea) or typical symptoms of pneumonia (e.g., cough, dyspnea), making pneumonia an unlikely cause of her delirium.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician with his son for a follow-up examination. The son reports that his father's mental status has declined since the previous visit when he was diagnosed with Alzheimer dementia. The patient often begins tasks and forgets what he was doing. He has increased trouble remembering events that occurred the day before and sometimes forgets names of common household objects. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His current medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, and donepezil. He is confused and oriented only to person. He is unable to count serial sevens backward from 100. He is able to register 3 items but unable to recall them 5 minutes later. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician with his son for a follow-up examination. The son reports that his father's mental status has declined since the previous visit when he was diagnosed with Alzheimer dementia. The patient often begins tasks and forgets what he was doing. He has increased trouble remembering events that occurred the day before and sometimes forgets names of common household objects. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His current medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, and donepezil. He is confused and oriented only to person. He is unable to count serial sevens backward from 100. He is able to register 3 items but unable to recall them 5 minutes later. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: This patient's disorientation to time (- 5 points) and place (- 5 points), inattention on serial sevens (- 5 points), and word recollection (- 3 points) give him a Mini-Mental State Exam (MMSE) score of ≤ 12, which is consistent with severe dementia.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for severe Alzheimer dementia.

answers.explanation_why: Risperidone is indicated for psychotic symptoms (e.g., hallucinations) that may sometimes complicate Alzheimer disease. Because this patient is not experiencing hallucinations, risperidone would not be indicated at this time.

Benztropine is used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms associated with antipsychotic drugs and as an adjunct therapy in Parkinson disease. Benztropine is not used in Alzheimer disease and may actually exacerbate this patient's symptoms due to its anticholinergic effects. The loss of cholinergic neurotransmission is believed to be part of the pathophysiologic mechanism of Alzheimer disease, which might explain symptom exacerbation by anticholinergics such as benztropine.

Although some small studies have suggested a possible benefit of gingko biloba supplementation in patients with Alzheimer disease, randomized controlled trials showed no benefit compared to placebo. Therefore, gingko biloba is not recommended for patients with Alzheimer disease.

SSRIs (e.g., citalopram) are indicated to treat depression, which may affect patients with Alzheimer disease and sometimes worsen dementia symptoms. While this patient has progressive dementia, he does not exhibit depressive symptoms (e.g., sadness, sleep/appetite change, etc.).

In patients with moderate-to-severe (≤ 18/30 MMSE) Alzheimer disease (AD), memantine may be given in addition to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil). The exact mechanism by which memantine improves Alzheimer symptoms is unclear, but it is believed to have neuroprotective effects by preventing glutamate-induced excitotoxicity. As with all currently available Alzheimer medications, memantine does not treat the underlying cause of AD (i.e., amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles), but only helps to relieve symptoms of the disease.

Although high-dose vitamin E may be mildly beneficial (likely due to its antioxidant effects) for patients with Alzheimer disease (AD) and is usually well-tolerated, there is some evidence that it may increase the risk of cardiovascular side effects. Vitamin E supplementation can be considered as an adjunct therapeutic agent in patients with mild-to-moderate AD. However, vitamin E therapy is not used routinely and would not be the treatment of choice for this patient with advanced AD.

question_text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 2 years. Initially, she used to misplace keys and forget her dog's name or her phone number. Now, she often forgets about what she has seen on television or read about the day before. She used to go for a walk every morning but stopped one month ago after she got lost on her way back home. Her son has prevented her from cooking because she has had episodes of leaving the gas oven on after cooking a meal. She becomes agitated when asked questions directly but is unconcerned when her son reports her history and says he is overprotective of her. She has hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include aspirin, enalapril, carvedilol, and atorvastatin. She is alert and oriented to place and person but not to time. Vital signs are within normal limits. Short- and long-term memory deficits are present. Her speech rhythm is normal but is frequently interrupted as she thinks of words to frame her sentences. She makes multiple errors while performing serial sevens. Her clock drawing is impaired and she draws 14 numbers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Initially, she used to misplace keys and forget her dog's name or her phone number. Now, she often forgets about what she has seen on television or read about the day before. She used to go for a walk every morning but stopped one month ago after she got lost on her way back home. Her son has prevented her from cooking because she has had episodes of leaving the gas oven on after cooking a meal. She becomes agitated when asked questions directly but is unconcerned when her son reports her history and says he is overprotective of her. She has hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include aspirin, enalapril, carvedilol, and atorvastatin. She is alert and oriented to place and person but not to time. Vital signs are within normal limits. Short- and long-term memory deficits are present. Her speech rhythm is normal but is frequently interrupted as she thinks of words to frame her sentences. She makes multiple errors while performing serial sevens. Her clock drawing is impaired and she draws 14 numbers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: An MRI scan of the brain would show generalized cerebral atrophy.
learning_objective: Recognize Alzheimer disease.

answers.explanation_why: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is characterized by the triad of urinary incontinence, gait instability, and memory loss (“wet, wobbly, and wacky”). Although this patient has significant memory loss, she lacks the other features of the triad, making this diagnosis less likely. Neuroimaging would show enlarged ventricles.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: Lewy body dementia is characterized by dementia with visual hallucinations and parkinsonism (e.g., tremor, rigidity). Although this patient has cognitive decline, she does not have the visual hallucinations or motor symptoms that are commonly seen in Lewy body dementia.

Frontotemporal dementia is characterized by early, selective degeneration of the frontal and temporal lobes. Frontal lobe degeneration results in behavioral and personality changes (e.g., apathy, compulsive eating, disinhibition), and temporal lobe degeneration causes memory loss. Although this patient has memory issues, she does not have any of the classic findings of frontal lobe degeneration. Neuroimaging in early stages would show selective atrophy of the frontal and temporal lobes, not global atrophy.

Pseudodementia is characterized by reversible cognitive impairment due to severe depression. This patient does not have any mood symptoms (sadness, anhedonia, irritability) that suggest depression. Also, those with pseudodementia usually express concern about their memory impairments, unlike this patient who says she is unconcerned with the memory lapses.

This patient's hypertension and hypercholesterolemia increase her risk for vascular dementia. However, the cognitive decline of vascular dementia occurs in a step-wise fashion, in which the patient's cognition remains stable for a certain period, and then declines again after another vascular event. In contrast, this patient exhibited a slowly progressive deterioration.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia (decline that develops over weeks to months), ataxia, and startle myoclonus. Although this patient is suffering from dementia, her decline has progressed over years and she lacks the classic feature of startle myoclonus.

Certain cognitive declines are expected with normal aging, such as slowing of cognitive processing speed and issues with memory retrieval. In dementia, however, cognitive deficits exceed those of normal aging and impair the actions of daily living. Since the patient's cognitive declines impair her daily life (i.e., inability to cook safely at home, navigate her neighborhood), they are pathologic and more severe than what would be expected with normal aging.

Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of slowly progressive memory loss. This condition typically affects the temporal and parietal lobes first: Temporal lobe degeneration results in memory loss (misplaced keys, leaving the stove on) and language deficits (word-finding difficulties), whereas parietal lobe degeneration results in spatial navigation problems (getting lost during walks outside).

question_text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 3 years. Initially, he used to forget his grandchildren's names or forget to lock the house door. During the past year, he has gotten lost twice while returning from the grocery store and was unable to tell passersby his address. On one occasion, he went to the park with his granddaughter and returned home alone without realizing he had forgotten her. His daughter says that over the past year, he has withdrawn himself from social gatherings and avoids making conversation. He does not sleep well at night. His daughter has hired a helper to cook and clean his home. On mental status examination, he is oriented only to person. He describes his mood as fair. Short- and long-term memory deficits are present. He appears indifferent about his memory lapses and says this is normal for someone of his age. The most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient is a drug that acts on which of the following neurotransmitters?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 3 years. Initially, he used to forget his grandchildren's names or forget to lock the house door. During the past year, he has gotten lost twice while returning from the grocery store and was unable to tell passersby his address. On one occasion, he went to the park with his granddaughter and returned home alone without realizing he had forgotten her. His daughter says that over the past year, he has withdrawn himself from social gatherings and avoids making conversation. He does not sleep well at night. His daughter has hired a helper to cook and clean his home. On mental status examination, he is oriented only to person. He describes his mood as fair. Short- and long-term memory deficits are present. He appears indifferent about his memory lapses and says this is normal for someone of his age. The most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient is a drug that acts on which of the following neurotransmitters?
hint: This patient's insidious onset of memory impairment and disorientation that has been progressively affecting his activities of daily living is consistent with Alzheimer disease (AD).
learning_objective: Recognize Alzheimer disease, and recall the neurotransmitter targeted by initial pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why:
Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that is targeted by sedatives (e.g., benzodiazepines, barbiturates). Sedatives should be avoided in older adults, especially those with dementia, due to increased risk of adverse reactions (delirium, falls, and dependence).

Recent research suggests that patients with AD may also have loss of GABA activity in the brain, which could contribute to symptoms. Currently, GABA-ergic treatments are not standard therapy for AD.

Serotonin is commonly targeted by first-line antidepressants (e.g., SSRIs). While depression may cause dementia symptoms (i.e., pseudodementia) and this patient presents with some symptoms that might suggest depression (disturbed sleep, social withdrawal), he does not meet diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder. Patients with AD may develop depression, in which case an antidepressant would be indicated.

AD is caused by the degeneration of cholinergic neurons mainly in the nucleus basalis of Meynert, leading to decreased acetylcholine synthesis and impaired cholinergic transmission to the cortex. First-line pharmacotherapy for mild to moderate AD is acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil).

In patients with moderate to severe disease (according to the Mini-Mental State Examination score) and suboptimal response to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, memantine can be added.

Some antidepressants (e.g., TCAs) increase norepinephrine levels. While depression may cause dementia symptoms (i.e., pseudodementia) and this patient presents with some symptoms that might suggest depression (disturbed sleep, social withdrawal), he does not meet diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder. Moreover, if this patient were depressed, first-line antidepressants should be attempted before a TCA would be indicated due to more favorable side effect profiles. Norepinephrine levels can be low in patients with AD, but first-line medications for this condition do not act on norepinephrine.

Loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra causes Parkinson disease, for which first-line medical therapy (e.g., levodopa) aims to restore dopamine levels. Parkinson disease typically presents with prominent motor symptoms (e.g., resting tremor, mask-like facies, bradykinesia, rigidity, shuffling gait), and advanced disease may cause dementia. While this patient has dementia, he has no evidence to suggest Parkinson disease.

Memantine acts as an N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist and is thought to block the action of glutamate on those receptors. Memantine is used in patients with moderate-to-severe AD and suboptimal response to the preferred pharmacologic agent. However, a drug that acts on a different neurotransmitter would be tried first.

question_text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty walking for the past year. He reports that his gait has become slower and that initiating steps has become more challenging. During the past 6 months, his family has noticed that he is starting to forget important family meetings and holidays. On a number of occasions, he has not been able to get to the bathroom in time in order to urinate. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His father died of Parkinson disease at the age of 63 years. The patient had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years, but quit 10 years ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is confused and has short-term memory deficits. He has a wide-based, shuffling gait. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. An MRI of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty walking for the past year. He reports that his gait has become slower and that initiating steps has become more challenging. During the past 6 months, his family has noticed that he is starting to forget important family meetings and holidays. On a number of occasions, he has not been able to get to the bathroom in time in order to urinate. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His father died of Parkinson disease at the age of 63 years. The patient had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years, but quit 10 years ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is confused and has short-term memory deficits. He has a wide-based, shuffling gait. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. An MRI of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: The combination of gait abnormalities, dementia, urinary incontinence, and ventriculomegaly without sulcal enlargement in MRI highly suggests normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).
learning_objective: Recognize normal pressure hydrocephalus, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.explanation_why: Gradual-onset, mild forgetfulness, hesitant gait, and urinary incontinence may be normal consequences of aging, with risk increasing with advancing age. However, the severity and relative rapidity of this patient's symptoms are unlikely to be part of normal aging. Additionally, this patient's cranial MRI is abnormal.

Increased CSF production (due to choroid plexus neoplasia or inflammation) is a rare cause of communicating hydrocephalus. While communicating hydrocephalus also causes enlarged ventricles, it typically manifests with signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g, headache, nausea, vomiting) rather than the symptoms seen in this patient.

Degeneration of the substantia nigra is a hallmark of Parkinson disease (PD), which causes a characteristic shuffling, short-stepping gait. While this patient is at increased risk of PD given his family history, urinary incontinence and dementia are typically late findings of advanced PD. If this patient had advanced PD, he would have had other earlier signs of the disease (e.g., muscle rigidity, resting tremor, mask-like facies, etc.) for years preceding his current symptoms. Additionally, PD does not explain this patient's abnormal cranial MRI.

Frontotemporal brain atrophy is characteristic of frontotemporal dementia (FTD), which typically presents early on with aphasia and personality changes. This patient's prominent motor/urinary symptoms without substantial personality changes make FTD less likely. Moreover, his cranial MRI does not show frontotemporal atrophy and instead suggests another diagnosis.

images.title: Frontotemporal dementia
images.description: MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

answers.explanation_why:
Impaired CSF absorption (either idiopathic or due to dysfunction of the arachnoid villi) is the suspected underlying pathophysiologic mechanism of NPH. Impaired CSF absorption leads to transiently elevated intracranial pressure, which causes ventricular enlargement and compression of cerebral structures (e.g., corona radiata). Once the ventricles enlarge, homeostasis between CSF production and resorption is established and intracranial pressure normalizes.

CSF shunting is the main treatment for NPH. The next step in the management of this patient should be to perform a lumbar tap test. Improvement of symptoms after CSF removal strongly supports the diagnosis of NPH and suggests a favorable response to CSF shunting.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: Obstruction of CSF flow causes non-communicating hydrocephalus. While non-communicating hydrocephalus also causes enlarged ventricles, it typically manifests with signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g, headache, nausea, vomiting) rather than the symptoms seen in this patient. In addition, evidence of an obstructive mass would likely be seen on this patient's cranial MRI.

images.title: Noncommunicating hydrocephalus
images.description:
Cranial CT (axial view) of a 13-year-old boyA large, liquor-like, hypodense lesion (red area) is located in the posterior cranial fossa in images 1–3. This lesion is most likely an arachnoid cyst compressing the cerebral aqueduct (A), which prevents the free circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the ventricles to the subarachnoid space. As a result, the third ventricle (III) and the lateral ventricles (hatched area) are dilated, and there is transependymal egress of CSF (green shaded area, images 4 and 5).

C = cistern of great cerebral vein
T = inferior horn of the lateral ventricle

answers.content: Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the temporal lobe
answers.explanation_why: Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the temporal lobe is found in Alzheimer disease (AD), which commonly causes memory difficulties and enlarged ventricles on cranial MRI. Gait changes and urinary incontinence are typically found in advanced AD years after diagnosis. However, this patient's rapid onset and progression of memory and gait changes associated with urinary incontinence is unlikely to be caused by AD. Moreover, AD usually causes cerebral atrophy (particularly of the hippocampus and temporal lobe), which is not seen on this patient's MRI.

images.title: Cerebral atrophy in Alzheimer disease 2/3
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbanceBilateral cerebral atrophy with prominent Sylvian fissures (green overlay) is seen.1: caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3: thalamus

answers.explanation_why: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rare cause of rapidly progressive dementia. While CJD can also cause ataxia and a resulting wide-based gait, more than 90% of patients present with myoclonus and the condition is commonly associated with other neuropsychiatric symptoms such as hallucinations and depression. Also, this patient's MRI shows ventriculomegaly, which is more consistent with another diagnosis.

images.title: MRI in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
images.description: MRI head (left: T2-weighted image, axial plane; right: diffusion-weighted image (DWI), axial plane) of a patient with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)The DWI shows hyperintensities (examples indicated by arrows) in the putamen (red overlay), thalamus (yellow overlay), and caudate nucleus (green overlay), common locations for deep gray matter involvement with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Sporadic CJD may also demonstrate ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri (cortical ribboning; not shown). A probable diagnosis of CJD can be made when expected MR imaging patterns are seen and CJD-mimicking disorders are confidently ruled out clinically.

answers.explanation_why: Multiple brain infarctions are characteristic of vascular dementia, which is the second most common form of dementia. This patient is at increased risk of developing vascular dementia given his history of smoking and hypertension, and symptom onset in vascular dementia may be relatively rapid. However, this patient's MRI does not show the expected signs of ischemia (e.g., multiple infarcts), and a stepwise decline in function would be more typical of vascular dementia.

images.title: Subcortical atherosclerotic encephalopathy 2/2
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Abnormal low attenuation areas (green overlay) are seen in the periventricular white matter. Two frontal lacunar infarcts (arrowheads) are also present.These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial plane)There is marked dilatation of the lateral ventricles (green overlay) with mild sulcal enlargement (red overlay). The findings are suggestive of normal pressure hydrocephalus as opposed to age-related or neurodegenerative cerebral atrophy.Periventricular hypointensities (examples indicated by white arrowheads) are also seen and may reflect transependymal edema due to elevated cerebrospinal fluid pressure.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 12 hours after the onset of blurry vision. During this time, she also reports nausea, one episode of vomiting, and a worsening, diffuse, dull, throbbing headache. She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks one to two glasses of wine per day. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 185/110 mm Hg. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral blurring of the optic disc margins. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein but no WBCs or RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 12 hours after the onset of blurry vision. During this time, she also reports nausea, one episode of vomiting, and a worsening, diffuse, dull, throbbing headache. She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks one to two glasses of wine per day. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 185/110 mm Hg. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral blurring of the optic disc margins. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein but no WBCs or RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's medical history and vital signs point to a complication of an underlying condition that is usually asymptomatic.
learning_objective: Recognize a hypertensive emergency.

answers.explanation_why: Acute angle closure glaucoma presents with headache, nausea, and visual changes (halos around lights). However, it is typically accompanied by severe eye pain, conjunctival injection, a hazy cornea, and a fixed, mid-dilated pupil. Bilateral papilledema is not a primary finding in acute glaucoma.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) typically presents with a hyperacute severe thunderclap headache (maximum intensity within 1–5 minutes of onset) rather than the worsening headache seen in this patient. While it can cause increased intracranial pressure, signs of meningismus (e.g., nuchal rigidity) are usually present. In SAH, hypertension is often a reactive response to increased intracranial pressure (Cushing reflex).

While idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) can manifest with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., papilledema, nausea, vomiting), its onset is not acute, and it typically affects overweight or obese women of childbearing age.

Migraine headaches usually manifest as recurrent, acute, unilateral, throbbing/pulsatile headaches and are sometimes associated with a visual aura, nausea, and/or vomiting. This patient has no history of migraine or recurrent headaches, and the new onset of migraine in an older adult is unlikely. Moreover, migraine would not explain this patient's papilledema.

The combination of severe hypertension (systolic ≥ 180 mm Hg and/or diastolic ≥ 120 mm Hg) and signs of acute end-organ damage are highly concerning for a hypertensive emergency. This patient presents with significantly elevated blood pressure and signs of both severe hypertensive retinopathy (formerly referred to as “malignant hypertension”) and hypertensive encephalopathy (headache, nausea, vomiting). A hypertensive emergency requires immediate treatment to prevent further end-organ damage. Generally, blood pressure must be lowered slowly, as vessels will have adjusted to hypertension and rapid drops in blood pressure (even if it remains within normal limits) can induce ischemia. A common approach is mean arterial pressure reduction by 10–20% in the first hour and another 5–15% over the following 23 hours.

Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) are characterized by focal neurologic deficits (e.g., weakness, aphasia) that resolve within 24 hours (most last < 1 hour). While visual symptoms, such as amaurosis fugax, can occur, they are typically unilateral. TIAs do not cause bilateral papilledema.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is a vasculitis affecting the elderly, and it presents with headache and visual disturbances. However, the visual loss in GCA is usually due to anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, which presents with a pale, swollen disc, often unilaterally, rather than bilateral papilledema. GCA is also typically associated with jaw claudication and scalp tenderness.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son for evaluation of cognitive decline. Her son reports that she has had increased difficulty finding her way back home for the last several months, despite having lived in the same city for 40 years. He also reports that his mother has been unable to recall the names of her relatives and been increasingly forgetting important family gatherings such as her grandchildren's birthdays over the last few years. The patient has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her current medications include enalapril and metformin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. She is confused and oriented only to person and place. She recalls 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after 5 minutes. Her gait and muscle strength are normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

Her son reports that she has had increased difficulty finding her way back home for the last several months, despite having lived in the same city for 40 years. He also reports that his mother has been unable to recall the names of her relatives and been increasingly forgetting important family gatherings such as her grandchildren's birthdays over the last few years. The patient has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her current medications include enalapril and metformin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. She is confused and oriented only to person and place. She recalls 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after 5 minutes. Her gait and muscle strength are normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient's insidious onset of memory impairment, language abnormalities (impaired naming), and disorientation are consistent with Alzheimer disease (AD).
learning_objective: Recognize Alzheimer disease, and recall its neuroimaging findings.

answers.explanation_why: Hallucinations and sudden memory loss may be caused by delirium, which has many causes (infection, electrolyte imbalances, drugs) and occurs commonly in older and hospitalized patients. It is also characterized by a sudden waxing and waning mental status, in addition to deficits in attention. Although this patient suffers from cognitive impairments, her issues have been subacute as opposed to acute, and her attention is intact.

A resting, “pill-rolling” tremor is characteristic of Parkinson disease. Although this patient is exhibiting cognitive decline, Parkinson's is characterized by motor symptoms such as a narrow, shuffling gait, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability, none of which this patient has.

Vitamin B_12 deficiency can lead to serious neurological disturbances, including peripheral neuropathies (which may cause a positive Babinski sign) and neuropsychiatric disease. However, this patient has no signs of sensory disturbances, weakness, or gait abnormality to indicate peripheral neuropathy or spinal cord degeneration.

Neuroimaging findings of focal cerebral atrophy (e.g., atrophy of the hippocampus) and generalized cerebral atrophy (decreased brain parenchymal volume, prominent sulci, enlarged ventricles) are common in patients with AD. Although not pathognomonic of AD, these findings help support the diagnosis. Disproportionate atrophy of the hippocampus and/or medial temporal lobe are the most characteristic neuroimaging findings of AD.

images.title: Cerebral atrophy in Alzheimer disease 1/3
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbanceThere is bilateral cerebral atrophy, with prominent sulci (green overlay).Multiple small hyperintense foci in the white matter (examples outlined) are enlarged perivascular spaces (Virchow-Robin spaces).

answers.explanation_why: The triad of urinary incontinence, gait instability, and memory loss (“wet, wobbly, and wacky”) is characteristic of normal pressure hydrocephalus. Although this patient has significant memory loss, she does not have the other features of the triad.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is characterized by myoclonic jerks (particularly triggered by startling) and rapidly progressive dementia. This patient's dementia has been insidiously progressive and she has no reports of myoclonus.

question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of lower back pain and tingling and numbness in his legs for the past 6 months. The pain radiates bilaterally to his buttocks and legs and gets worse while standing or walking downhill. Two weeks ago, he had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His son has ankylosing spondylitis. Current medications include enalapril and atorvastatin. The patient does not smoke. He drinks two to three beers on the weekends. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. There is no tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. The patient's gait is unsteady and wide-based. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of lower back pain and tingling and numbness in his legs for the past 6 months. The pain radiates bilaterally to his buttocks and legs and gets worse while standing or walking downhill. Two weeks ago, he had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His son has ankylosing spondylitis. Current medications include enalapril and atorvastatin. The patient does not smoke. He drinks two to three beers on the weekends. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. There is no tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. The patient's gait is unsteady and wide-based. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
hint: Lower extremity radiculopathy that worsens with standing or walking downhill is consistent with lumbar spinal stenosis.
learning_objective: Recognize lumbar spinal stenosis, and recall the postural change that relieves symptoms.

answers.explanation_why: Seronegative spondyloarthropathies have a strong genetic association with HLA-B27 and frequently manifest with lower back pain. This patient is at increased risk for seronegative spondyloarthropathies given his family history, but those diseases are usually present before age 40. Additionally, they typically manifest with reduced range of motion and enthesitis and they do not cause neurologic symptoms.

An increased HbA1c occurs in diabetes mellitus (DM) and is not commonly associated with spinal stenosis. This patient has several risk factors for type 2 diabetes mellitus (weight, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia), and long-standing DM may lead to diabetic neuropathy that manifests with sensory deficits and reduced reflexes as seen in this patient. However, diabetic neuropathy does not account for this patient's radiating back pain.

A positive straight leg raise test suggests back pain secondary to degenerative disk disease and is not a common finding in spinal stenosis. This patient's lower radiating back pain, sensory deficits, and reduced reflexes may be consistent with degenerative disk disease. However, degenerative disk disease primarily causes dermatomal sensory deficits, decreased leg strength, and reduced deep tendon reflexes only of the muscles innervated by the compressed nerve root.

An anterior disk herniation into the cauda equina could cause bilateral and multi-dermatomal/myotomal symptoms, but the association of symptoms with exertion and chronic duration makes herniation unlikely (most herniations self-resolve/improve within 6–8 weeks) and this patient has no history of trauma (e.g., heavy lifting) to explain a herniation.

Albuminocytologic dissociation on CSF analysis is seen in Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), which sometimes follows an upper respiratory infection like the one this patient had. GBS may account for this patient's back and limb pain and his reduced muscle reflexes. However, GBS typically also causes a rapidly progressive ascending flaccid paralysis that self-resolves within weeks to months, whereas this patient has had chronic symptoms with intact muscle strength.

Postural changes can widen or narrow the spinal canal and thereby alleviate or worsen symptoms of spinal stenosis. By leaning forward, the spinal canal is widened and spinal cord compression is reduced. Therefore, leaning forward will most likely relieve this patient's back pain. Activities that flex the lumbar spine, such as sitting, cycling, or walking uphill, also help widen the spinal canal and alleviate pain in patients with spinal stenosis.

The exacerbation of lumbar spinal stenosis symptoms by certain postures that narrow the spinal cord (walking downhill, standing, walking) is called pseudoclaudication. In contrast to vascular claudication, which is a result of arterial vessel narrowing and impaired metabolic demands of muscle tissue, pseudoclaudication is thought to result from increased metabolic demands of a compressed and ischemic spinal cord.

images.title: Posture-dependent pain in lumbar spinal stenosis (neuropathic claudication)
images.description: Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

answers.explanation_why: A decreased ankle-brachial index is seen in peripheral arterial disease (PAD), which also manifests with lower extremity pain with exertion (i.e., claudication). This patient has several risk factors for developing PAD (hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, advanced age), but his pain has a radiculopathic character and is also exacerbated by standing upright, neither of which are seen in PAD.

question_text: An 81-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter after being found wandering on the street. His daughter says that over the past several months he has been more aggressive towards friends and family. She also reports several episodes in which he claimed to see two strangers in her apartment. He sometimes stares blankly for several minutes and does not react when addressed. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and was diagnosed with Parkinson disease 2 months ago. His current medications include carbidopa-levodopa, hydrochlorothiazide, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. He is oriented to person but not to place and time. There is a resting tremor in his right upper extremity. There is muscle rigidity in the upper and lower extremities. He is able to walk without assistance but has a slow gait with short steps. Mental status examination shows short-term memory deficits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: An 81-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter after being found wandering on the street. His daughter says that over the past several months he has been more aggressive towards friends and family. She also reports several episodes in which he claimed to see two strangers in her apartment. He sometimes stares blankly for several minutes and does not react when addressed. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and was diagnosed with Parkinson disease 2 months ago. His current medications include carbidopa-levodopa, hydrochlorothiazide, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. He is oriented to person but not to place and time. There is a resting tremor in his right upper extremity. There is muscle rigidity in the upper and lower extremities. He is able to walk without assistance but has a slow gait with short steps. Mental status examination shows short-term memory deficits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient seems to have had a poor response to levodopa.
learning_objective: Recognize dementia with Lewy bodies.

answers.explanation_why: Lewy bodies are a typical pathological finding in dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) and Parkinson disease. Parkinsonism and dementia are typical features of both conditions and the onset of neuropsychiatric features in relation to motor symptoms can help differentiate between the two. In DLB, dementia, visual hallucinations, and paranoid episodes typically occur before or concurrent to the onset of parkinsonism, whereas in Parkinson disease, dementia occurs in advanced disease (usually several years after the onset of motor symptoms). DLB causes abnormal sleep and episodic cognitive fluctuations and responds poorly to levodopa.

images.title: Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites
images.description: Microscopy of the substantia nigra of a patient with Parkinson disease (upper row: 60x magnification, lower row: 20x magnification; staining with antibodies against alpha-synuclein, counterstaining with Mayer hematoxylin)Both Lewy bodies (spherical intracytoplasmic aggregates of alpha-synuclein; green overlay) and the strand-like Lewy neurites (neurites containing alpha-synuclein aggregates; white arrows) are visible.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with vascular dementia can present with dementia, behavioral changes, and loss of cognitive function (e.g., disorientation), but the onset is typically abrupt with stepwise deterioration. Other findings, such as focal neurologic deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, dysarthria), would also be expected. In addition, parkinsonism and visual hallucinations are uncommon with vascular dementia.

Temporal and frontal lobe atrophy is seen in patients with frontotemporal dementia (FTD). Early changes in behavior and personality (e.g., irritability, failure to observe social etiquette) are characteristic of FTD but dementia and parkinsonism typically occur in the late stages of the disease. In addition, FTD typically manifests earlier, usually between the ages of 40 and 60 years.

Prions are the underlying cause of prion diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Dementia and visual hallucinations may occur as a result, but prion disease progresses extremely rapidly and other findings, e.g., myoclonus and seizures, would be expected as well.

Impaired absorption of CSF and resulting ventriculomegaly is the proposed mechanism underlying normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). This condition is characterized by dementia and gait abnormalities. However, urinary incontinence, which this patient lacks, would also be expected. Moreover, visual hallucinations are not typically seen in NPH.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

question_text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of progressively worsening blurry vision. She has also had intermittent headaches for the past 2 months. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, osteoarthritis, second-degree heart block, and presbyopia. Her current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and ibuprofen. Examination shows bilateral equal and reactive pupils. The best-corrected visual acuity in each eye is 20/40. There is narrowing of her visual fields bilaterally. Funduscopic examination shows bilateral narrowing of the outer rim of the optic nerve head and cupping of the optic disc. Intraocular pressure by applanation tonometry is 27 mm Hg in the right eye and 26 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). Gonioscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of progressively worsening blurry vision. She has also had intermittent headaches for the past 2 months. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, osteoarthritis, second-degree heart block, and presbyopia. Her current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and ibuprofen. Examination shows bilateral equal and reactive pupils. The best-corrected visual acuity in each eye is 20/40. There is narrowing of her visual fields bilaterally. Funduscopic examination shows bilateral narrowing of the outer rim of the optic nerve head and cupping of the optic disc. Intraocular pressure by applanation tonometry is 27 mm Hg in the right eye and 26 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). Gonioscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Blurry vision and headaches in an individual with cupping of the optic nerve on funduscopy and raised intraocular pressure suggests glaucoma. A normal gonioscopic examination excludes angle closure; therefore, this patient has primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG).
learning_objective: Recognize primary open-angle glaucoma, and choose the most appropriate initial therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical trabeculectomy is indicated for patients with POAG who are refractory to medical treatment or laser therapy. Although effective at lowering intraocular pressure, surgical trabeculectomy is associated with complications, such as the early development of cataracts. This patient should attempt conservative therapy before considering surgery.

Topical pilocarpine is an alternative medical therapy for open-angle glaucoma. It is no longer a first-line treatment due to significant side effects, such as worsening of vision from increased myopia and miosis and shallowing of the anterior chamber. First-line treatment options should be attempted first before considering pilocarpine.

Topical prostaglandins such as latanoprost are the first-line treatment for POAG. They lower intraocular pressure by improving the drainage of aqueous humor. Side effects include increased pigmentation of the iris, elongated eyelashes, and burning/stinging during instillation. If topical prostaglandins are too expensive for patients, topical beta blockers (e.g., timolol) may offer a cheaper initial option, though they would be contraindicated in this patient with second-degree heart block.

images.title: Glaucomatous excavation of the optic disc
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeAn enlarged cup (yellow overlay) of the optic disc with thinning of the neuroretinal rim (green overlay) can be seen, especially evident in the temporal superior area of the optic disc (focal notching, indicated by arrow). Cupping leads to kinking of the blood vessels at the base of the cup (examples indicated by arrowheads).This is a pathognomonic finding in glaucoma, predominantly caused by elevated intraocular pressure.

answers.explanation_why: Although topical beta blockers like timolol can treat POAG by reducing the production of aqueous humor, they are no longer considered as first-line treatment and are contraindicated in this patient with a second-degree heart block. Additional contraindications to timolol include severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma, acute heart failure, and sinus bradycardia.
Laser iridotomy is used in the management of acute angle-closure glaucoma. It has no use in POAG as the elevation of intraocular pressure in POAG is not due to drainage angle obstruction.
