question_text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because she is seeing things that she knows are not there. Sometimes she sees a dog in her kitchen and at other times she sees a stranger in her garden, both of which no one else can see. She also reports a lack of motivation to do daily tasks for the past week. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with Parkinson disease and was started on levodopa and carbidopa. Her younger brother has schizophrenia. The patient also takes levothyroxine for hypothyroidism. She used to drink a bottle of wine every day, but she stopped drinking alcohol 2 months ago. Neurologic examination shows a mild resting tremor of the hands and bradykinesia. Her thought process is organized and logical. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because she is seeing things that she knows are not there. Sometimes she sees a dog in her kitchen and at other times she sees a stranger in her garden, both of which no one else can see. She also reports a lack of motivation to do daily tasks for the past week. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with Parkinson disease and was started on levodopa and carbidopa. Her younger brother has schizophrenia. The patient also takes levothyroxine for hypothyroidism. She used to drink a bottle of wine every day, but she stopped drinking alcohol 2 months ago. Neurologic examination shows a mild resting tremor of the hands and bradykinesia. Her thought process is organized and logical. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: While hallucinations may be caused by dysregulation of a variety of neurotransmitters, this patient's symptoms are most likely due to an activation of dopamine D2-receptors.
learning_objective: Recognize adverse effects of levodopa therapy.

answers.explanation_why:
Levodopa (L-DOPA), a dopamine precursor, is the most effective medication for controlling the motor symptoms of Parkinson disease. Primary effects of L-DOPA are achieved by stimulating D2-receptors in the substantia nigra and striatum. However, overstimulation of D2-receptors by levodopa may also induce psychosis and hallucinations (usually visual). The risk for developing psychiatric symptoms increases with age, other psychiatric conditions, long duration of levodopa treatment, and high doses. Since this patient has been taking levodopa for 3 years and is elderly, her symptoms are most likely the result of levodopa therapy.

Other adverse effects of L-DOPA therapy include dizziness, somnolence or insomnia, anxiety, and aggressive behavior.

images.title: Mechanism of action: drugs used in Parkinson disease
images.description: Dopamine agonists (e.g., ropinirole, bromocriptine) bind to the dopamine receptor, mimicking the action of dopamine.DOPA-Decarboxylase (DDC) inhibitors (e.g., carbidopa) decrease the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, which results in reduced peripheral side-effects of L-DOPA. These drugs cannot cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore do not reduce dopamine production in the brain nor do they have central side-effects.Dopamine precursors (e.g., L-DOPA) are converted by DOPA decarboxylase at the presynaptic neuron resulting in direct dopaminergic effects (especially in D2 receptors).COMT inhibitors (e.g., entacapone, tolcapone) inhibits central (tolcapone) or peripheral (entacapone) catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) resulting in the reduced metabolization of dopamine, increase in dopamine effects, a decreased demand for L-DOPA, and a longer therapeutic effect with each dose.MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) reduce the metabolism of central dopamine by inhibiting the monoamine oxidase B enzyme, which normally breaks down dopamine (and catecholamines) in the brain. This results in a prolonged dopamine effect and reduced demand for L-DOPA.Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, resulting in a proportionately lower concentration of acetylcholine compared to dopamine.NMDA antagonists (e.g., amantadine) act as antagonists at the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which results in a dopaminergic effect.

answers.explanation_why: Alcohol withdrawal occurs in individuals with alcohol use disorder shortly after a complete cessation of alcohol consumption (i.e., within 24 hours). Common clinical manifestations are mild (e.g., gastrointestinal symptoms, headache, insomnia) but more severe findings (e.g., seizure, hallucinations, impaired consciousness) may also develop. Although this patient's visual hallucinations are similar to those seen in alcoholic hallucinosis and alcohol withdrawal delirium, she has not consumed alcohol for 2 months; alcohol withdrawal cannot be the cause of her symptoms.

The clinical features of schizophrenia can be categorized according to positive symptoms of psychosis and negative symptoms of psychosis. Although this patient has an increased risk (∼ 12%) of developing schizophrenia because her brother is affected, she lacks other expected symptoms (e.g., disorganized thought process, alogia). Moreover, symptom onset at the patient's age would also be very unusual since schizophrenia is typically diagnosed in the late 20s in women.

Major depressive disorder (MDD) can sometimes be associated with psychotic symptoms. In addition to the clinical features of MDD, patients may present with delusions and hallucinations, which are often auditory but can also be visual or tactile. Although this patient has hallucinations and recently noted a lack of motivation, she does not meet the criteria for a diagnosis of MDD.

Poorly controlled hypothyroidism, especially in older patients, may manifest with features similar to dementia, including impaired memory and concentration. Although hallucinations may occur, they are rare and usually accompanied by psychotic symptoms, such as paranoia and thought disorders. This patient does not have any expected signs or symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain) and has isolated hallucinations, making thyroid dysfunction unlikely.

question_text: A 69-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of multiple falls and increasing forgetfulness over the past year. During this time, she also has had blurred and double vision. For the past 3 months, her husband notes that he has had difficulty understanding her speech. She has also become withdrawn and refuses to go to social gatherings. She occasionally becomes confused in the evenings. Her blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg when supine and 124/80 mm Hg while standing. Examination shows a broad-based gait and difficulty maintaining balance while standing upright and walking. Neurologic examination shows bradykinesia, dysarthria, and palmar grasp reflex bilaterally. Muscle tone is increased in the upper extremities. Visual acuity test shows no abnormalities. There is conjugate limitation of both eyes when looking down. Mental status examination shows apathy. The patient responds to questions with 1–2 words after a delay of several seconds. MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 69-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of multiple falls and increasing forgetfulness over the past year. During this time, she also has had blurred and double vision. For the past 3 months, her husband notes that he has had difficulty understanding her speech. She has also become withdrawn and refuses to go to social gatherings. She occasionally becomes confused in the evenings. Her blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg when supine and 124/80 mm Hg while standing. Examination shows a broad-based gait and difficulty maintaining balance while standing upright and walking. Neurologic examination shows bradykinesia, dysarthria, and palmar grasp reflex bilaterally. Muscle tone is increased in the upper extremities. Visual acuity test shows no abnormalities. There is conjugate limitation of both eyes when looking down. Mental status examination shows apathy. The patient responds to questions with 1–2 words after a delay of several seconds. MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's MRI shows midbrain atrophy with an intact pons, which is also referred to as the hummingbird sign (or penguin sign).
learning_objective: Recognize progressive supranuclear palsy.

answers.explanation_why: Multiple system atrophy (MSA) can manifest with signs of cerebellar dysfunction (e.g., frequent falls, gait disturbances, and dysarthria) and parkinsonism (e.g., postural instability). Apathy, frontal lobe release signs (e.g., positive grasp reflex), and signs of dementia (sundowning, social withdrawal, forgetfulness) are typically not seen in MSA because the frontal lobe and other regions of the cortex are usually spared. In addition, MSA typically manifests with features of autonomic dysfunction such as urinary incontinence and orthostatic hypotension. MRI of the brain can show atrophy of the cerebellum and brainstem, and the hot cross bun sign, which is a common but unspecific finding in patients with MSA.

Alzheimer disease (AD) is characterized by progressive memory loss. Language impairment, temporal and spatial disorientation, and apathy may also be present as AD progresses. AD does not typically cause motor dysfunction (e.g., bradykinesia, broad-based gait), oculomotor dysfunction, or upper extremity hypertonia.

Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a neurodegenerative disease that belongs to the Parkinson-plus syndromes. PSP is characterized by oculomotor deficits such as vertical gaze palsy (due to atrophy of structures in the tectum of the midbrain), which can progress to complete supranuclear ophthalmoplegia. Patients with PSP often have postural instability, which leads to gait impairment and frequent falls. Frontal lobe dysfunction can manifest with behavioral changes (e.g., apathy, disinhibition, impaired reasoning) and dementia (forgetfulness, social withdrawal, sundowning). Patients usually also present with parkinsonism (e.g., bradykinesia, rigor) and may develop features of pseudobulbar palsy such as dysarthria and dysphagia. The prognosis of PSP is generally poor and most patients die within 5–10 years of symptom onset.

See “Overview of Parkinson-plus syndromes” table.

Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) can manifest with features of parkinsonism (e.g., bradykinesia, rigidity), frequent falls, and signs of dementia (forgetfulness, sundowning, and especially visuospatial deficits and executive dysfunction). DLB is also characterized by visual hallucinations, delusions, or episodes of paranoia. Dysarthria is not commonly seen.

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) manifests with symptoms of cognitive disturbance (e.g., apathy, confusion) and gait impairment with a broad-based gait. Hypertonia (due to paratonia or spasticity), bradykinesia, and frontal release signs (e.g., grasp reflex) may also be present. NPH typically does not result in dysarthria or oculomotor dysfunction. In addition, patients with NPH usually present with urinary incontinence. MRI of the brain typically shows ventriculomegaly.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: Parkinson disease (PD) can manifest with motor dysfunction (e.g., frequent falls, bradykinesia, broad-based gait), signs of dementia (e.g., forgetfulness), and apathy. This patient does not, however, have other typical signs of PD, such as resting tremor, rigidity, and hyposmia.

images.title: Hummingbird sign
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; sagittal plane)The hummingbird sign (illustration; also known as “penguin sign”) refers to the appearance of the brainstem on MRI in the sagittal plane in patients with progressive supranuclear palsy. The atrophic mesencephalon (red overlay) represents the bird's head, with the beak extending towards the optic chiasm. The preserved pons (green overlay) represents the body of the bird.Yellow overlay: medulla oblongata

question_text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of involuntary, rhythmic movements of her hands for the past 5 months. The symptoms initially affected her left hand only, but now both hands are affected. She also reports that her symptoms are worse at rest and that performing tasks such as tying her shoelaces and writing have become more difficult. Her husband reports that she has been more withdrawn lately. She drank half a bottle of sherry every day for 18 years but has not consumed alcohol in the past year. She has chronic liver disease, hypertension, and peripheral artery disease. Current medications include aspirin and propranolol. She appears anxious. She is oriented to time, place, and person. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 144/82 mm Hg. Examination shows a rhythmic, low-frequency tremor that is more prominent in the left hand. Range of motion in the arms and legs is normal. There is increased resistance to passive flexion and extension in the left upper limb. Muscle strength is 4/5 in all extremities. Sensations to pinprick and light touch are preserved. Finger-nose testing shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical findings?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of involuntary, rhythmic movements of her hands for the past 5 months. The symptoms initially affected her left hand only, but now both hands are affected. She also reports that her symptoms are worse at rest and that performing tasks such as tying her shoelaces and writing have become more difficult. Her husband reports that she has been more withdrawn lately. She drank half a bottle of sherry every day for 18 years but has not consumed alcohol in the past year. She has chronic liver disease, hypertension, and peripheral artery disease. Current medications include aspirin and propranolol. She appears anxious. She is oriented to time, place, and person. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 144/82 mm Hg. Examination shows a rhythmic, low-frequency tremor that is more prominent in the left hand. Range of motion in the arms and legs is normal. There is increased resistance to passive flexion and extension in the left upper limb. Muscle strength is 4/5 in all extremities. Sensations to pinprick and light touch are preserved. Finger-nose testing shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical findings?
hint: This patient's muscle rigidity, low-frequency (4–6 Hz) resting tremor, and a change in affect are consistent with parkinsonism. Given the unilateral onset of the tremor and the patient's age, the most likely diagnosis is Parkinson disease.
learning_objective: Recognize parkinsonism, and recall its underlying pathology.

answers.content: Copper accumulation in the basal ganglia
answers.explanation_why: Copper accumulation in the basal ganglia is characteristic of Wilson disease, which can result in chronic liver disease as well as features of parkinsonism (e.g., resting tremors, bradykinesia, and rigidity). However, the neurological manifestations of Wilson disease typically occur in patients in their twenties or thirties and are associated with Kayser-Fleischer rings and dysarthria.

Levels of free T4 are increased in patients with hyperthyroidism, which may manifest with hypertension, anxiety, and tremor. However, the tremor seen in hyperthyroidism is typically bilateral, of high frequency (10–12 Hz), and does not improve with movement.

Patients with a functional neurological symptom disorder may develop a psychogenic tremor that may manifest as a unilateral tremor. Although this patient appears anxious, there is no history of a recent stressful event or a change in environment to suggest a functional neurological symptom disorder. Moreover, unlike the tremor in this patient, which has gradually worsened over the past 5 months and is present at rest, psychogenic tremors are episodic with an abrupt onset most often (∼ 80%) in the right hand. Psychogenic tremors are furthermore characterized by sudden variations in amplitude and/or frequency of the tremor and a decrease in tremor when the patient is distracted.

Infarction of the red nucleus, which is seen in patients with Benedikt syndrome, can result in Holmes tremor as well as in hypertonicity on the contralateral side. However, hypertonicity associated with infarction of the red nucleus affects extensor muscles more than flexor muscles, which results in a decerebrate posture (unlike this patient who has a normal range of motion and increased resistance to both flexion and extension). Moreover, patients with Benedikt syndrome would have ataxia contralaterally (unlike this patient who has a normal finger-nose test) and features of oculomotor nerve palsy (e.g., ptosis, exotropia) ipsilaterally.

Hypertension is a risk factor for cerebellar infarction, which may result in a tremor. However, the onset of symptoms is usually acute, and the tremor seen with cerebellar dysfunction is typically an intention tremor, i.e., it worsens with goal-directed movements leading to dysmetria while performing the finger-nose test. Other signs of cerebellar dysfunction (e.g., nystagmus, abnormal gait, dysdiadochokinesia) would also be present.

In patients with chronic liver disease, decompensated cirrhosis can lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which would cause mood changes, handwriting changes, and a low frequency flapping tremor (asterixis). However, asterixis is not a true tremor but rather myoclonic jerks that typically occur bilaterally in a nonrhythmic manner when the arms and hands are extended. The onset of symptoms over a period of 5 months as well as the absence of other features of decompensated liver failure (e.g., jaundice, ascites) suggest a different cause.

Parkinson disease (PD) involves progressive degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the basal ganglia, particularly the substantia nigra pars compacta, resulting in dopamine deficiency at the striatum. Dopamine deficiency at the striatum results in an inability of the basal ganglia to modulate the activity of the motor cortex, which in turn causes the motor symptoms (e.g., bradykinesia, resting tremor, muscle rigidity, and postural instability) that are typically seen in PD.

See “Common types of tremors” table.

question_text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 5 weeks. The patient had been living independently but came to live with his daughter temporarily after he told her that he was unable to perform some of his daily activities. He has left the front door wide open and tap water running on multiple occasions. The patient is concerned about his memory lapses. He wakes up 6–7 times during the night. He often feels too tired to leave his room and rarely makes conversation with his daughter. He says that he used to enjoy playing the piano but has not played for several months. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows orientation to person, place, and time as well as psychomotor retardation. He has a blunted affect. Attention, concentration, and short- and long-term memory are impaired. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B_12 are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
content_preview: A 78-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 5 weeks. The patient had been living independently but came to live with his daughter temporarily after he told her that he was unable to perform some of his daily activities. He has left the front door wide open and tap water running on multiple occasions. The patient is concerned about his memory lapses. He wakes up 6–7 times during the night. He often feels too tired to leave his room and rarely makes conversation with his daughter. He says that he used to enjoy playing the piano but has not played for several months. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows orientation to person, place, and time as well as psychomotor retardation. He has a blunted affect. Attention, concentration, and short- and long-term memory are impaired. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B12 are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
hint: This patient's cognitive deficits are likely caused by pseudodementia.
learning_objective: Recognize pseudodementia in the context of major depressive disorder, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Donepezil is indicated in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer dementia (AD). Patients with AD can present with impairment of daily life and, especially in early stages, show symptoms of depression. However, the onset of AD is usually insidious, with progression over ∼ 8–10 years. The memory of recent events is typically the cognitive domain affected first in patients with AD. For this reason, patients are typically not oriented to person, place, or time. Also, unlike this patient who is concerned about his memory loss, patients with AD are often not aware of their cognitive deficits.

This patient meets 5 (anhedonia, sleep disturbance, diminished cognition, psychomotor changes, and low energy) out of the 9 diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD). In patients with late-life depression, cognitive deficits may resemble dementia (i.e., pseudodementia). Compared to patients with other types of dementia, patients with pseudodementia are more likely to be aware of and concerned about memory impairment. Cognitive deficits in MDD typically have a sudden onset and manifest after the mood symptoms (e.g., this patient lost interest in playing the piano several months ago). Treatment of the underlying depression, e.g., with SSRIs such as citalopram, may lead to remission of the depression and reversal of the cognitive deficits. In older patients in particular, different causes of dementia must be considered if memory impairment persists after appropriate treatment and an improvement in depressive symptoms.

See “Differential diagnosis of subtypes of dementia” table.

Antiplatelet drugs such as aspirin may be considered in patients with vascular dementia. This type of dementia may present with abrupt cognitive decline and stepwise deterioration. This patient has risk factors for vascular dementia such as hypertension and advanced age. However, his loss of interest, sleep disturbance, and psychomotor retardation cannot be explained by this diagnosis and warrant a different treatment.

A cerebral shunt is the treatment of choice for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). While NPH typically manifests with impaired memory, other typical findings such as incontinence and ataxic gait are absent in this patient.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: Memantine can be used in addition to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors in patients with moderate to severe Alzheimer dementia or vascular dementia. This patient's memory deficits could be explained by either of these dementia types, and depressive symptoms may occur in early dementia. However, his cognitive deficits are more likely to be caused by pseudodementia.

question_text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a worsening tremor that began 1 year ago. The tremor affects his left hand and improves when he uses his hand to complete a task. He also reports feeling stiffer throughout the day, and he has fallen twice in the past year. He has not noticed any changes in his cognition or mood. He has not had difficulty sleeping, but his wife says that he would kick and punch while dreaming for almost a decade. His mother has Alzheimer disease. He drinks two cans of beer daily. He takes no medications. He appears well-nourished. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient maintains a blank stare throughout the visit. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a worsening tremor that began 1 year ago. The tremor affects his left hand and improves when he uses his hand to complete a task. He also reports feeling stiffer throughout the day, and he has fallen twice in the past year. He has not noticed any changes in his cognition or mood. He has not had difficulty sleeping, but his wife says that he would kick and punch while dreaming for almost a decade. His mother has Alzheimer disease. He drinks two cans of beer daily. He takes no medications. He appears well-nourished. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient maintains a blank stare throughout the visit. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: This patient's asymmetrical resting tremor, rigidity, and reduced facial expression (hypomimia) should raise concern for idiopathic Parkinson disease (PD), which is commonly associated with sleep disturbances (e.g., REM sleep behavior disorder) during early stages of the disease.
learning_objective: Recognize idiopathic Parkinson disease, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why:
Slowed and reduced amplitude of repetitive movements (e.g., foot tapping, opening and closing the hand, or tapping thumb and index fingers) is a sign of bradykinesia, which is a hallmark feature of PD. In PD, degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra leads to a deficiency of dopamine in the striatum. Dopamine deficiency in the striatum in turn causes decreased excitatory signaling to the motor cortex, which results in bradykinesia and akinesia. Other common features of PD include shuffling gait, postural instability, and micrographia.

The diagnosis of PD is clinical; additional tests, including imaging, are not routinely required but should be considered in patients with atypical presentation or to rule out other disorders. To establish the diagnosis of PD, patients must present with bradykinesia in addition to tremor or rigidity.

Startle myoclonus is a classic sign of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a rare condition that manifests with neuropsychiatric changes and akinetic mutism. Although patients with CJD may initially present with parkinsonian features (e.g., rigidity), they typically develop rapidly progressing dementia within weeks to months and die within approx. 12 months of symptom onset.

Impaired vertical eye movement in a patient with parkinsonism is concerning for progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP). While PSP may also cause frequent falls (due to postural instability) and sleep disturbances, this condition is not the most likely cause of this patient's parkinsonism. PSP often manifests with a prolonged prodromal period characterized by headache, arthralgia, dizziness, depression, and fatigue, which are all absent in this patient. Also, PSP typically causes behavioral disturbances (e.g., apathy, disinhibition, or euphoria), as well as dysarthria and/or dysphagia.

Horizontal gaze nystagmus is a classic finding in Wernicke encephalopathy, which manifests with ataxia and gait instability, particularly in individuals with alcohol use disorder. However, this patient appears well nourished and does not have further symptoms of encephalopathy (e.g., disorientation, inattention), making thiamine deficiency unlikely.

Extensor plantar response occurs in a number of neurological diseases including multiple system atrophy (MSA), which is a Parkinson-plus syndrome. MSA typically affects patients > 50 years of age and manifests with parkinsonism (especially rigidity/stiffness), gait instability, tremor, and REM sleep dysfunction (e.g., thrashing during sleep). However, the majority of patients also have early dysautonomia, most commonly urinary dysfunction and orthostatic hypotension. This patient's absence of autonomic dysfunction makes MSA unlikely.

Choreiform movements in an adult should raise concern for Huntington disease (HD), which can lead to parkinsonian features (e.g., akinesis, rigidity). However, these features usually only occur during later stages of the disease when cognitive decline (e.g., executive dysfunction) and depression are also commonly present. Most patients with HD initially present with typical features such as chorea and abnormal eye movements, with a symptom onset usually between 20 and 50 years of age. Moreover, HD does not explain this patient's tremor.

All of this patient's symptoms, in isolation, may represent normal findings. Two falls in a person > 65 years of age may be attributed to tripping, a resting tremor may represent exaggerated physiologic tremor or essential tremor, and thrashing in sleep may be caused by isolated REM dysfunction. However, the combination of all of these symptoms in one patient is concerning for PD. In addition, essential tremor usually worsens with intentional movements, unlike this patient's tremor that improves when he uses his hand to complete a task.

question_text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of gradually worsening rhythmic movements of his right hand for the past 5 months. His symptoms worsen when he is in a meeting and he is concerned that people are noticing it. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient recalls that his father developed bobbing of the head at an older age. He takes no medications. Neurologic examination shows tremor of the right hand with a frequency of approximately 5 Hz when the limbs are relaxed. When the patient is asked to move his arm the tremor decreases. There is reduced arm swing while walking. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of gradually worsening rhythmic movements of his right hand for the past 5 months. His symptoms worsen when he is in a meeting and he is concerned that people are noticing it. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient recalls that his father developed bobbing of the head at an older age. He takes no medications. Neurologic examination shows tremor of the right hand with a frequency of approximately 5 Hz when the limbs are relaxed. When the patient is asked to move his arm the tremor decreases. There is reduced arm swing while walking. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: A unilateral resting tremor with a frequency of 4–6 Hz that worsens with stress and improves with voluntary movements, as well as signs of mild bradykinesia (decreased arm swing), are features consistent with Parkinson disease (PD).
learning_objective: Recognize Parkinson disease, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for a young patient with resting tremor.

answers.explanation_why: Donepezil is a cholinesterase inhibitor used for the treatment of dementia, such as Alzheimer disease, vascular dementia, and frontotemporal dementia. In patients with PD, donepezil is used as an adjunctive treatment for symptoms of dementia. This patient shows no signs of cognitive impairment and has only recently begun noticing neurologic deficits. Dementia is typically a symptom of late-stage PD.

Trihexyphenidyl is a muscarinic antagonist that reduces cholinergic activity in the CNS. Initial monotherapy with an anticholinergic (e.g., trihexyphenidyl, benztropine, biperiden) can be considered in patients with PD who are ≤ 65 years of age if the main symptom is resting tremor and there is no evidence of cognitive impairment, significant bradykinesia, or gait disturbance. Alternative pharmacotherapy for patients with PD who are ≤ 65 years of age includes nonergot dopamine agonists, MAO-B inhibitors, COMT inhibitors, and/or levodopa/carbidopa. Anticholinergics should be avoided in patients > 65 years of age (particularly those with dementia) because they may worsen psychiatric symptoms and cause urinary retention.

See “Common types of tremors” table.

Clonazepam can be used to treat patients with orthostatic tremor, a condition with an average onset of ∼ 60 years of age. Typical clinical features of orthostatic tremor are triggered by longer periods of standing and include leg tremors as well as a sensation of instability. However, the condition only affects the legs and would not be the cause of this patient's hand tremor or reduced arm swing.

Topiramate is second-line treatment of benign essential tremor. This patient likely has a family history of essential tremor (his father developed head bobbing at an older age). However, unlike the asymmetric resting tremor seen in this patient, essential tremor is symmetrical, worsens with voluntary movements, and resolves completely at rest.

Methimazole is used to treat hyperthyroidism. Although patients with hyperthyroidism can also present with a tremor that increases with stress, as in this patient, the tremor is usually symmetric and occurs while holding a position against gravity (e.g., extending arms in front of the body). It would also not explain this patient's bradykinesia.

Propranolol is a first-line treatment of benign essential tremor. This patient likely has a family history of essential tremor (his father developed head bobbing at an older age). However, unlike the asymmetric resting tremor seen in this patient, essential tremor is symmetrical, worsens with voluntary movements, and resolves completely at rest.

question_text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of changes in her sleeping habits. She says that she has been gradually sleeping less over the past couple of months. It takes her 20–25 minutes to fall asleep each night, and she wakes up earlier in the morning than she used to. On average, she sleeps 5–6 hours each night. She says that she has also been waking up several times per night and needs about 20 minutes to fall asleep again. She feels mildly tired in the afternoon but does not take any naps. Her husband reports that she does not snore. She takes a 45-minute walk with her husband and their dog every other day. The patient drinks two cups of coffee each morning. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she appears cooperative with a full range of affect. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of changes in her sleeping habits. She says that she has been gradually sleeping less over the past couple of months. It takes her 20–25 minutes to fall asleep each night, and she wakes up earlier in the morning than she used to. On average, she sleeps 5–6 hours each night. She says that she has also been waking up several times per night and needs about 20 minutes to fall asleep again. She feels mildly tired in the afternoon but does not take any naps. Her husband reports that she does not snore. She takes a 45-minute walk with her husband and their dog every other day. The patient drinks two cups of coffee each morning. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she appears cooperative with a full range of affect. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Changes in sleep architecture occur naturally with aging. Sleep disorders (e.g., depression, obstructive sleep apnea, restless leg syndrome, and GERD) should be also considered if patients are having trouble sleeping.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in management for an elderly patient with changes in sleep architecture.

answers.explanation_why: Sleep restriction can be used in patients with chronic insomnia in order to reduce sleep latency. This patient's sleep latency is within the standard deviation of normal, and therefore this technique is not likely to be significantly beneficial.

Flurazepam can be prescribed for insomnia in patients under 65 years of age. However, flurazepam and other long-acting benzodiazepines are on the Beers list of medication that is potentially inappropriate for patients > 65 years of age due to an increased risk of delirium, falls, and motor vehicle crashes. Since this patient is 74 years old, and her sleep changes are likely part of the normal aging process, flurazepam is not indicated.

Melatonin is an important hormone for sleep onset, and melatonin levels decrease with aging. In theory, melatonin should decrease sleep latency, but studies have shown its effect size to be small and potentially clinically insignificant. Furthermore, this patient's sleep latency is within the standard deviation of normal (i.e. < 30 minutes), and it is unclear how much benefit she would receive. A trial of melatonin could be indicated if sleep latency onset increased in this patient.

Changes in sleep architecture that occur naturally with aging are best managed with reassurance and sleep hygiene counseling. Changes include increased sleep latency, longer light stages of sleep with increasing frequency of nighttime awakenings, decreased time in the deep sleep phase (stage 3), shorter REM phases, as well as earlier bedtimes and morning awakenings, all of which can make individuals feel more tired. While such changes may indicate disorders (e.g., advanced sleep phase disorder) and merit treatment, this patient is most likely experiencing normal changes in sleep that occur with aging.

The sedating side effects of diphenhydramine can help patients with increased sleep latency to fall asleep. However, most patients become tolerant to this side effect over the course of a few days. Furthermore, diphenhydramine is on the Beers list of medication that is potentially inappropriate for patients > 65 years of age due to its anticholinergic effects that can precipitate delirium, constipation, dry mouth, and urinary retention. Therefore, diphenhydramine should be avoided in this 74-year-old patient.

Cognitive and behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is the treatment of choice in patients with insomnia disorder. CBT-I combines cognitive therapy, stimulus control, and sleep restriction therapy, sometimes with the addition of relaxation training. Although difficulty initiating and maintaining sleep as well as early morning awakening with the inability to return to sleep are features of insomnia, this patient does not have impaired daytime functioning, which rules out this diagnosis.

Antidepressants, such as trazodone can be used to treat insomnia, especially in patients suffering from depression. This patient's sleep changes are likely related to normal aging, and she lacks the evidence of depression (e.g., restricted affect) for trazodone to be indicated.

question_text: A 69-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because of increasing forgetfulness and generalized fatigue over the past 4 months. She is unable to remember recent events and can no longer recognize familiar people. She lives independently, but her daughter has hired a helper in the past month since the patient has found it difficult to shop or drive by herself. She has stopped attending family functions and refuses to visit the neighborhood clubhouse, where she used to conduct game nights for the residents. She has had a 7-kg (15-lb) weight gain over this period. She is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. Her temperature is 36°C (97.6°F), pulse is 54/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg. Mental status examination shows impaired attention and concentration; she has difficulty repeating seven digits forward and five in reverse sequence. She cannot recall any of the 3 objects shown to her after 10 minutes. She has no delusions or hallucinations. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 69-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because of increasing forgetfulness and generalized fatigue over the past 4 months. She is unable to remember recent events and can no longer recognize familiar people. She lives independently, but her daughter has hired a helper in the past month since the patient has found it difficult to shop or drive by herself. She has stopped attending family functions and refuses to visit the neighborhood clubhouse, where she used to conduct game nights for the residents. She has had a 7-kg (15-lb) weight gain over this period. She is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. Her temperature is 36°C (97.6°F), pulse is 54/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg. Mental status examination shows impaired attention and concentration; she has difficulty repeating seven digits forward and five in reverse sequence. She cannot recall any of the 3 objects shown to her after 10 minutes. She has no delusions or hallucinations. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: This patient's weight gain, bradycardia, and cognitive symptoms are likely related to a treatable underlying medical condition.
learning_objective: Recognize hypothyroidism-related cognitive dysfunction, and recall the expected laboratory finding.

answers.explanation_why: Vitamin B_12 deficiency is a reversible cause of cognitive impairment that is associated with anemia and neurologic dysfunction (e.g., subacute combined degeneration, peripheral neuropathy, autonomic dysfunction). However, it does not typically cause weight gain and bradycardia. Although all patients with dementia should be evaluated for vitamin B_12 deficiency, this patient's cognitive impairment is most likely due to a different condition.

answers.content: Diffuse cortical atrophy on brain MRI
answers.explanation_why: Diffuse cortical atrophy on neuroimaging is a characteristic finding in Alzheimer dementia, the most common irreversible cause of dementia in older patients. Though this patient shows signs of impaired cognition (the hallmark of Alzheimer), she also has weight gain and bradycardia, which suggest a different condition.

images.title: Cerebral atrophy in Alzheimer disease 1/3
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbanceThere is bilateral cerebral atrophy, with prominent sulci (green overlay).Multiple small hyperintense foci in the white matter (examples outlined) are enlarged perivascular spaces (Virchow-Robin spaces).

answers.content: Ventriculomegaly on CT scan of the head
answers.explanation_why: Enlarged cerebral ventricles on CT scan of the head is a characteristic finding of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), a condition that manifests with dementia, gait ataxia, and urinary incontinence (remember: “wacky, wobbly, wet”). This patient does not report any gait abnormalities or incontinence, however, and NPH would not explain her weight gain and bradycardia.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: An elevated WBC count can be seen in infection. Acute delirium in older patients is often the result of a urinary tract infection. Accordingly, a urinalysis should be performed in patients with confusion. However, this woman's symptoms are more characteristic of dementia (4-month history; progressive) and not delirium, which would follow a waxing-waning course that is worse at night. Delirium also commonly presents with illusions and/or hallucinations, both of which are absent in this patient. Acute infections generally do not cause dementia; consequently, her WBC count is likely to be normal.

This patient's findings should raise concern for hypothyroidism. Cognitive dysfunction is prevalent in older patients with hypothyroidism and can often mimic Alzheimer disease and other dementias. Primary hypothyroidism (the most common type of hypothyroidism) manifests with elevated serum TSH and decreased FT4. All patients with cognitive impairment must be evaluated for hypothyroidism, as this is a treatable and reversible cause of dementia.

question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of gradual onset of bilateral ankle swelling over the past month. He also noticed reddish blotches of skin around his ankles. Five weeks ago, he came to the physician with difficulty walking and a resting tremor. He was diagnosed with Parkinson disease and started on medication. He has a history of hypertension and his antihypertensive medications were also adjusted. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 64/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 124/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral 2+ edema in the ankles. There is purple-red discoloration on the lower legs in a reticular pattern. Neurologic examination shows resting tremor in both hands and bilateral cogwheel rigidity in the elbows. Which of the following pharmacotherapies is the most likely cause of this patient's edema?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of gradual onset of bilateral ankle swelling over the past month. He also noticed reddish blotches of skin around his ankles. Five weeks ago, he came to the physician with difficulty walking and a resting tremor. He was diagnosed with Parkinson disease and started on medication. He has a history of hypertension and his antihypertensive medications were also adjusted. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 64/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 124/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral 2+ edema in the ankles. There is purple-red discoloration on the lower legs in a reticular pattern. Neurologic examination shows resting tremor in both hands and bilateral cogwheel rigidity in the elbows. Which of the following pharmacotherapies is the most likely cause of this patient's edema?
hint: This patient is taking an antiparkinson medication that commonly causes ankle edema and livedo reticularis. In rare cases, it may cause confusion, hallucinations, and nightmares.
learning_objective: Recognize the side effects of antiparkinson medications.

answers.explanation_why: Levodopa is a dopamine precursor that is administered with carbidopa, which prevents its degradation. This combination drug is a first-line treatment for Parkinson patients > 65 years of age. Levodopa can cause gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting), orthostatic hypotension, and induce psychotic symptoms. However, ankle edema and livedo reticularis are not commonly seen with the use of these drugs.

Selegiline is an MAO-B inhibitor that can be used as an alternative to levodopa or dopamine agonists to treat Parkinson patients with mild symptoms, or it can be taken in combination with levodopa to reduce motor fluctuations. Common side effects of selegiline include nausea, headache, and insomnia. In older patients, selegiline can also precipitate confusion. Ankle edema and livedo reticularis are not commonly seen with the use of this drug.

Entacapone is a COMT inhibitor used as an adjunct to levodopa therapy. It increases the effectiveness of levodopa by preventing its peripheral breakdown. The most common side effects of COMT inhibitors are nausea and dyskinesia. Peripheral edema and livedo reticularis are not commonly seen with COMT inhibitors.

Losartan can be used to treat hypertension, especially in patients with comorbid diabetes who cannot tolerate an ACE inhibitor. It can cause hyperkalemia and also rarely angioedema, albeit at lower rates than ACE inhibitors. However, peripheral edema and livedo reticularis are not associated with losartan.

Amantadine is a weak NMDA receptor antagonist that can improve motor symptoms (tremor, rigidity, akinesia) in patients with mild forms of Parkinson disease, or it can be combined with levodopa to reduce dyskinesia in patients with advanced disease. Livedo reticularis and peripheral edema, which are seen in this patient, occur as adverse effects in up to 5% of patients who take amantadine.

See “Overview of antiparkinson drugs” table.

images.title: Mechanism of action: drugs used in Parkinson disease
images.description: Dopamine agonists (e.g., ropinirole, bromocriptine) bind to the dopamine receptor, mimicking the action of dopamine.DOPA-Decarboxylase (DDC) inhibitors (e.g., carbidopa) decrease the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, which results in reduced peripheral side-effects of L-DOPA. These drugs cannot cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore do not reduce dopamine production in the brain nor do they have central side-effects.Dopamine precursors (e.g., L-DOPA) are converted by DOPA decarboxylase at the presynaptic neuron resulting in direct dopaminergic effects (especially in D2 receptors).COMT inhibitors (e.g., entacapone, tolcapone) inhibits central (tolcapone) or peripheral (entacapone) catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) resulting in the reduced metabolization of dopamine, increase in dopamine effects, a decreased demand for L-DOPA, and a longer therapeutic effect with each dose.MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) reduce the metabolism of central dopamine by inhibiting the monoamine oxidase B enzyme, which normally breaks down dopamine (and catecholamines) in the brain. This results in a prolonged dopamine effect and reduced demand for L-DOPA.Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, resulting in a proportionately lower concentration of acetylcholine compared to dopamine.NMDA antagonists (e.g., amantadine) act as antagonists at the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which results in a dopaminergic effect.

answers.explanation_why: Lisinopril is a first-line agent for hypertension in patients with comorbid diabetes. Cough and hyperkalemia are common side effects. Rarely, this drug can cause angioedema of the tongue, face, and/or neck that can be life-threatening (especially in patients with hereditary angioedema). However, peripheral edema and livedo reticularis are not associated with this drug.

Hydrochlorothiazide is a first-line agent for hypertension. Common side effects of this drug include electrolyte abnormalities and orthostatic hypotension. Although some patients may experience a hypersensitivity rash, livedo reticularis is not associated with this drug. Moreover, it does not cause peripheral edema. On the contrary, since it is a diuretic, it is sometimes used to treat edema.

Benztropine is an anticholinergic agent that can be used as a monotherapy in Parkinson patients who are  < 65 years old and have resting tremor as the predominant symptom. Since it is an anticholinergic agent, it tends to be avoided in patients > 65 years old, as it is more likely to cause side effects such as urinary retention, constipation, and delirium. However, ankle edema and livedo reticularis are not commonly seen with the use of this drug.

question_text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty speaking. The symptoms began abruptly one hour ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include pravastatin, lisinopril, metformin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences, and has difficulty repeating sequences of words. He can follow simple instructions. Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left, and there is a mild right-sided pronator drift downwards. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty speaking. The symptoms began abruptly one hour ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include pravastatin, lisinopril, metformin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences, and has difficulty repeating sequences of words. He can follow simple instructions. Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left, and there is a mild right-sided pronator drift downwards. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with sudden-onset focal neurologic deficits that are consistent with stroke. Telegraphic speech (as evidenced by the use of short, simple sentences), intact comprehension (as evidenced by the ability to follow commands), and impaired repetition of word sequences are consistent with Broca aphasia. The presence of this type of language deficit helps localize the damage to a specific region of the cortex.
learning_objective: Recognize occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery.

answers.content: Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which manifests with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Broca aphasia and right-sided weakness are not consistent with lateral medullary syndrome.

answers.content: Occlusion of the right penetrating arteries
answers.explanation_why: Ischemia to the right posterior limb of the internal capsule, due to occlusion of right penetrating arteries, would cause left-sided, not right-sided weakness. Furthermore, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by penetrating arteries.

answers.content: Occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery typically causes left-sided weakness and, if the right hemisphere is nondominant (most individuals), hemineglect. In some, typically left-handed individuals, the language center is located in the right hemisphere. In these patients, a right middle cerebral artery stroke could cause Broca aphasia. However, left-sided, not right-sided, weakness would be expected in this scenario.

answers.content: Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries that supply the left posterior limb of the internal capsule can result in right-sided weakness, as seen in this patient. However, Broca aphasia localizes to the inferior frontal gyrus of the left hemisphere, which is not supplied by penetrating arteries.

answers.content: Dissection of the right vertebral artery
answers.explanation_why: Dissection of the right vertebral artery can cause ischemia to brain regions supplied by the posterior circulation (e.g., cerebellum, brainstem, occipital cortex). However, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, while right-sided weakness indicates a lesion to the left precentral gyrus, both of which are supplied by the left anterior circulation.

answers.content: Occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why:
Broca aphasia is caused by damage of the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (typically left) hemisphere. This patient additionally has right facial droop, right-sided muscle weakness, and right-sided pronator drift downwards, suggesting an upper motor neuron lesion in the left motor cortex. The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the inferior frontal gyrus, as well as the motor cortex. This patient has several risk factors for arteriosclerosis and, therefore, ischemic stroke (hypertension, age > 65 years, diabetes mellitus), making occlusion of the left MCA the most likely cause of his focal neurologic deficits.

Ischemic strokes do not typically cause headaches, whereas hemorrhagic strokes usually manifest with severe headaches.

images.title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

answers.content: Rupture of right posterior cerebral artery malformation
answers.explanation_why: Hemorrhage into the right posterior limb of the internal capsule due to rupture of a right posterior cerebral artery malformation could cause left-sided, but not right-sided weakness. Rupture of this artery would also cause left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which is not present in this patient. Further, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.content: Occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which presents with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Broca aphasia and right-sided weakness are not consistent with lateral medullary syndrome.

answers.content: Rupture of left posterior cerebral artery malformation
answers.explanation_why: Hemorrhage into the left posterior limb of the internal capsule due to rupture of a left posterior cerebral artery malformation could cause right-sided hemiparesis, as seen in this patient. However, rupture of this artery would also cause right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which is not present here. Further, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.

answers.content: Dissection of the left vertebral artery
answers.explanation_why: Dissection of the left vertebral artery can cause ischemia to brain regions supplied by the posterior circulation (e.g., cerebellum, brainstem, occipital cortex). However, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, while right-sided weakness indicates a lesion to the left precentral gyrus, both of which are supplied by the left anterior circulation.

question_text: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he lost consciousness for 5 minutes while watching a game of summer league football from a seat in the stands during the afternoon. On arrival, he is lethargic and oriented only to person. Three weeks ago, he was treated for hepatitis A. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypothyroidism. Current medications include metformin and levothyroxine. His temperature is 41.5°C (106.7°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 128/70 mm Hg. Examination shows hot, dry skin. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Fundoscopy shows proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His abdomen is soft and nontender. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. His serum glucose concentration is 160 mg/dL. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he lost consciousness for 5 minutes while watching a game of summer league football from a seat in the stands during the afternoon. On arrival, he is lethargic and oriented only to person. Three weeks ago, he was treated for hepatitis A. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypothyroidism. Current medications include metformin and levothyroxine. His temperature is 41.5°C (106.7°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 128/70 mm Hg. Examination shows hot, dry skin. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Fundoscopy shows proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His abdomen is soft and nontender. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. His serum glucose concentration is 160 mg/dL. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This older patient has characteristic signs of nonexertional heatstroke, namely severe hyperthermia (usually > 40.0°C (> 104°F)), hot, dry skin, and altered mental status, likely after prolonged exposure to high summer temperatures.
learning_objective: Recognize nonexertional heatstroke, and recall its underlying pathophysiology.

answers.explanation_why: Nonexertional heatstroke is a life-threatening condition that occurs when the body's hypothalamic thermoregulatory response is inadequate to maintain a normal temperature. The normal physiologic response to increased body temperature is hypothalamus-mediated peripheral vasodilation (to expose blood to the cooler air) and sweating (to dissipate heat into the environment). In older individuals, these control mechanisms are impaired because of reduced vasodilation and surface area for conductive heat loss. Accordingly, the hypothalamus is less able to adequately regulate temperature in this population, thereby increasing the risk for heatstroke. Treatment for heatstroke consists of rapid reduction of the core body temperature to 39°C (102.2°F) via conductive cooling (immersion in ice water). If immersion is not possible or insufficient, other active cooling methods (e.g., spraying cold water, fanning, cold IV crystalloids) can be considered.

Although uncommon, a TIA could lead to a sudden loss of consciousness. This patient's older age and history of diabetes do put him at increased risk for a TIA or stroke. However, he has no focal neurological symptoms such as loss of vision, aphasia, hemiparesis, or paresthesias, which would be expected. The combination of severe hyperthermia, anhidrosis, and altered mental status make another diagnosis more likely.

answers.content: Accumulation of ammonia due to liver dysfunction
answers.explanation_why: Accumulation of ammonia due to liver dysfunction can cause hepatic encephalopathy, which would also present with altered mental status. Although this patient has a recent history of treated hepatitis A, a three-week delay between viral illness and liver failure would not occur. This patient additionally has no signs of liver disease (e.g., jaundice, abdominal pain, spider telangiectasias, etc.), making hepatic encephalopathy unlikely.

Metabolic acidosis with ketosis is the characteristic state of diabetic ketoacidosis, a serious complication of diabetes mellitus. Although more common in children, DKA can occur at any age. Typical findings include rapid onset of altered mental status and hyperventilation, both seen in this patient. However, DKA is also characterized by severe hyperglycemia (often > 600 mg/dL), polyuria, polydipsia, and abdominal pain, all of which are absent here. Additionally, DKA would not explain this patient's very high fever.

Gram-negative bacilli in the bloodstream is a potential cause of sepsis, a condition that may cause tachycardia, fever, and altered mental status. However, this patient has no underlying signs of infection (e.g., costovertebral angle tenderness, cough, open wound, abdominal pain, etc.) and has normal blood pressure (sepsis usually causes ↓ BP).

answers.content: Mutation in the ryanodine receptor type 1
answers.explanation_why: A mutation in the ryanodine receptor type 1 predisposes patients to malignant hyperthermia, a condition that usually occurs following administration of general inhaled anesthetics. This condition can also lead to very high fevers, delirium, tachycardia, and tachypnea. However, malignant hyperthermia also causes muscle spasticity and would rarely occur in the absence of general anesthetic inhalation.

Elevation of serum thyroxine levels can be seen in thyroid storm due to acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. Thyroid storm can cause many of the symptoms observed in this patient, including high fever, tachycardia, and delirium. Although an overdose of L-thyroxine could explain this patient's symptoms, the onset would be less acute and preceded by other signs of hyperthyroidism such as nervousness, tremor, loose stools, or insomnia. Additionally, the blood pressure would be higher and the temperature would most likely only be mildly elevated.

A central dopamine receptor blockade may be seen in patients with neuroleptic malignant syndrome, a condition that causes progressively worsening delirium, high fevers, and muscle rigidity over 1–3 days in the setting of antipsychotic medication use. Though this patient clearly has altered mental status and severe hyperthermia, he does not have muscle rigidity nor does he take antipsychotic medications.

question_text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the physician because of increasing forgetfulness, unsteadiness, and falls over the past year. He reports that these symptoms seem to worsen with each fall. Initially, he could not remember directions to his home but now cannot remember recent conversations or appointments he has made. He often repeats questions that he asked shortly before. He has long-standing hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include aspirin, carvedilol, enalapril, and atorvastatin. Examination shows a bruise over the left temple and an unsteady gait. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person and place only. Short-term memory is impaired; he can recall 0 out of 5 objects after 10 minutes. Long-term memory is intact. He has no delusions or hallucinations. Muscle strength is decreased in the left lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the left. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man is brought to the physician because of increasing forgetfulness, unsteadiness, and falls over the past year. He reports that these symptoms seem to worsen with each fall. Initially, he could not remember directions to his home but now cannot remember recent conversations or appointments he has made. He often repeats questions that he asked shortly before. He has long-standing hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include aspirin, carvedilol, enalapril, and atorvastatin. Examination shows a bruise over the left temple and an unsteady gait. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person and place only. Short-term memory is impaired; he can recall 0 out of 5 objects after 10 minutes. Long-term memory is intact. He has no delusions or hallucinations. Muscle strength is decreased in the left lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the left. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Progressive impairment in an individual with cardiovascular disease, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and focal neurologic deficits in conjunction with a head CT scan showing hypodense periventricular lesions is highly suggestive of vascular dementia.
learning_objective: Recognize vascular dementia, and choose the most appropriate management step.

answers.explanation_why: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that can be used to prevent thromboembolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Vascular dementia, however, is primarily a small vessel disease caused by lipohyalinosis or microatheroma formation, not thromboemboli, and is primarily treated with antiplatelet agents rather than anticoagulants. Anticoagulants may be indicated in some patients with vascular dementia who have previously had a cardioembolic stroke, but neither the imaging findings in this patient nor his history point towards a previous cardioembolic stroke. Therefore, anticoagulation is not indicated in this patient. In addition, because this patient has a very high fall risk (unsteady gait with decreased muscle strength in the lower extremities and a bruise over the left temple), anticoagulants should be avoided if possible.

Vitamin E is an antioxidant that has been studied as a possible treatment for Alzheimer disease (AD), which can manifest with short-term memory loss and spatial disorientation. However, CT findings typically seen in AD include ventriculomegaly, narrowing of gyri, and prominent cerebral sulci with disproportionate atrophy of the hippocampi. Although there are no adverse effects associated with vitamin E therapy, it has not been shown to improve cognition secondary to vascular dementia.

Cerebral shunt placement is an important step in the treatment of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), which commonly causes dementia and an unsteady gait. However, NPH also manifests with urinary incontinence and ventriculomegaly on neuroimaging. This patient's head CT scan shows ventricles of normal size, which rules out NPH.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: Tetrabenazine is a medication used in the treatment of chorea associated with Huntington disease (HD), which may cause cognitive-behavioral changes and symptoms of dementia (e.g., memory loss, spatial disorientation) in advanced stages. Although a head CT scan may show cerebral atrophy in HD, these changes are most pronounced in the caudate. In addition, this patient has an ataxic gait (an atypical finding in HD) and no history of chorea.

Cognitive training is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's confirmed vascular dementia. While cognitive training and rehabilitation are important components of treatment for all forms of dementia, treatment specific to vascular dementia also includes reduction of cardiovascular risk factors and, in some cases, anticoagulation. However, this patient's medical regimen for his cardiovascular conditions is already optimal and he cannot be started on anticoagulation because he is at high risk of falling.

images.title: Subcortical atherosclerotic encephalopathy 2/2
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Abnormal low attenuation areas (green overlay) are seen in the periventricular white matter. Two frontal lacunar infarcts (arrowheads) are also present.These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.

images.title: Subcortical atherosclerotic encephalopathy 1/2
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Abnormal low attenuation zones are seen in the periventricular white matter adjacent to the frontal and temporal horns of the lateral ventricles (green overlay). The cerebral sulci (examples indicated by red overlay) and ventricles are also prominent.These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.

question_text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of vulvar itching and dryness. During this period, she has also had pain during sexual intercourse but no postcoital bleeding. Her last menstrual period was at the age of 51 years. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and her only medication is metformin. Pelvic examination shows atrophic labial folds. There are excoriation marks and a well-demarcated, white plaque on the vulva. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The results of a punch biopsy show no evidence of malignancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment for this patient's lesions?
content_preview: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of vulvar itching and dryness. During this period, she has also had pain during sexual intercourse but no postcoital bleeding. Her last menstrual period was at the age of 51 years. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and her only medication is metformin. Pelvic examination shows atrophic labial folds. There are excoriation marks and a well-demarcated, white plaque on the vulva. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The results of a punch biopsy show no evidence of malignancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment for this patient's lesions?
hint: Dyspareunia and pruritus in a postmenopausal woman with a white vulvar plaque on pelvic examination are consistent with lichen sclerosus.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate treatment for lichen sclerosus.

answers.explanation_why: Topical fluconazole is indicated to treat mucocutaneous fungal infections like candidiasis (vaginal yeast infection). This patient's age puts her at increased risk of secondary infections of the genital area as a complication of atrophic vaginitis. A yeast infection would also explain the vulval pruritus and dyspareunia in this case. However, the absence of key features like vaginal discharge, foul odor, and vulvovaginal inflammation make this diagnosis unlikely.

Individuals with lichen sclerosus have an increased risk of developing vulvar squamous cell carcinoma. Because the results of this patient's biopsy are negative for malignancy, the next step in management is to administer superpotent topical glucocorticoids, such as betamethasone or clobetasol, which help reduce inflammation and pruritus.

images.title: Vulvar lichen sclerosus
images.description: An irregular, sclerotic white plaque with a reddened, inflammatory edge localized to the vulva and perianal region is visible. The labia minora and majora are hard to distinguish from one another because of atrophy and sclerosis; the vaginal opening is markedly narrowed.

answers.explanation_why: Topical tacrolimus (FK506) is a calcineurin inhibitor that can be used to treat lichen sclerosus topically. However, this is a second-line therapy because it is less effective than another therapy.
Although topical progesterone was used in the past for lichen sclerosus, it is no longer used as it is less effective than other forms of therapy and is not approved by the FDA.

Topical estrogen is the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis, which often manifests in postmenopausal women with vulval dryness and dyspareunia in association with labial atrophy. However, this condition does not cause white, plaque-like lesions or pruritus.
Although UVA1 phototherapy has been shown to improve symptoms for lichen sclerosus, it is less effective than another form of therapy.
