question_text: An asymptomatic 65-year-old woman is found to have a T-score of -2.6 SD on routine bone mineral density screening. She has a 10-year history of hypertension and an esophageal stricture due to severe gastroesophageal reflux disease. She was diagnosed with endometrial hyperplasia 20 years ago and treated with medroxyprogesterone. Menarche occurred at 11 years of age and her last menstrual period was 8 years ago. Her last mammography and Pap smear 6 months ago showed no abnormalities. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 45 years. The patient does not have any children. Current medications include lansoprazole and hydrochlorothiazide. Her blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The physician recommends pharmacotherapy with raloxifene to prevent further bone resorption. Before initiating the new treatment, this patient should be counseled that it increases her risk for developing which of the following?
content_preview: An asymptomatic 65-year-old woman is found to have a T-score of -2.6 SD on routine bone mineral density screening. She has a 10-year history of hypertension and an esophageal stricture due to severe gastroesophageal reflux disease. She was diagnosed with endometrial hyperplasia 20 years ago and treated with medroxyprogesterone. Menarche occurred at 11 years of age and her last menstrual period was 8 years ago. Her last mammography and Pap smear 6 months ago showed no abnormalities. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 45 years. The patient does not have any children. Current medications include lansoprazole and hydrochlorothiazide. Her blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The physician recommends pharmacotherapy with raloxifene to prevent further bone resorption. Before initiating the new treatment, this patient should be counseled that it increases her risk for developing which of the following?
hint: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is used to treat osteoporosis in patients who also require breast cancer prophylaxis.
learning_objective: Recognize the use of raloxifene, and recall its risk of thromboembolic events.

answers.explanation_why: Mandibular osteonecrosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of bisphosphonates rather than raloxifene. Bisphosphonates are the first-line treatment in osteoporosis because they prevent bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclasts. This patient has an esophageal abnormality (stricture secondary to gastroesophageal reflux disease), which is a contraindication to therapy with oral bisphosphonates.

Tamoxifen and unopposed estrogen increase the risk of endometrial cancer by acting as agonists on endometrial estrogen receptors, thereby stimulating growth and possibly malignant transformation. Because this patient has a history of endometrial hyperplasia and has not yet undergone hysterectomy, drugs associated with an increased risk of endometrial cancer are contraindicated. Raloxifene acts as an estrogen antagonist in the endometrium, which decreases the risk of endometrial cancer.

Teriparatide is associated with an increased incidence of osteosarcoma. This drug is rarely prescribed as initial therapy for postmenopausal osteoporosis but can be used in women with severe osteoporosis (T-score ≤ -3.5, or T-score ≤ -2.5 in combination with a fragility fracture) or those with contraindications or unresponsiveness to first-line medication. Raloxifene is not associated with the development of osteosarcoma.

Raloxifene can increase serum triglycerides in women with a history of severe hypertriglyceridemia during oral estrogen therapy. This woman has no such history and a different side effect is both more likely and more concerning.

In postmenopausal women, osteoporosis is most commonly due to estrogen deficiency. Estrogen physiologically prevents bone breakdown by stimulating osteoblasts and inhibiting osteoclasts. Raloxifene prevents bone resorption by acting as an estrogen agonist in the bone. At the same time, it has estrogen antagonist qualities in the breast and endometrium. Since estrogen receptors are often expressed on endometrial and breast cancer cells, raloxifene is also indicated for cancer prophylaxis in postmenopausal women with an increased risk of breast cancer. The most severe adverse effects of raloxifene are thromboembolic events, such as deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and retinal vein thrombosis; raloxifene is contraindicated in women with a history of or current venous thromboembolic disorders.

question_text: A 93-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of a purple area on her right arm that has been growing for one month. She has not had any pain or itching of the area. She has hyperlipidemia, a history of basal cell carcinoma treated with Mohs surgery 2 years ago, and a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast treated with radical mastectomy 57 years ago. She has had chronic lymphedema of the right upper extremity since the mastectomy. Her only medication is simvastatin. She lives in an assisted living facility. She is content with her living arrangement but feels guilty that she is dependent on others. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows extensive edema of the right arm. Skin examination of the proximal upper right extremity shows three coalescing, 0.5–1.0 cm heterogeneous, purple plaques with associated ulceration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 93-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of a purple area on her right arm that has been growing for one month. She has not had any pain or itching of the area. She has hyperlipidemia, a history of basal cell carcinoma treated with Mohs surgery 2 years ago, and a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast treated with radical mastectomy 57 years ago. She has had chronic lymphedema of the right upper extremity since the mastectomy. Her only medication is simvastatin. She lives in an assisted living facility. She is content with her living arrangement but feels guilty that she is dependent on others. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows extensive edema of the right arm. Skin examination of the proximal upper right extremity shows three coalescing, 0.5–1.0 cm heterogeneous, purple plaques with associated ulceration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This condition occurs as a result of chronic lymphedema and is now considered rare since breast-sparing surgery techniques are favored and radical mastectomy has become less common.
learning_objective: Recognize lymphangiosarcoma associated with chronic lymphedema.

answers.explanation_why: Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare, secondary malignancy that develops from endothelial cells as a result of chronic lymphedema (classically in individuals who have undergone axillary lymphadenectomy after mastectomy). Lymphangiosarcoma typically manifests with multiple purple macules and/or papules with possible ulceration, and less commonly with tender, subcutaneous nodules.

images.title: Soft tissue sarcoma
images.description: Photographic image of a woman with erythematous confluent macules and some papules in her right axillar region.These lesions are typical for lymphangiosarcoma (e.g. after lymphadenectomy).

answers.explanation_why: Chronic lymphedema is an important risk factor for the development of cellulitis and other soft tissue infections (including abscesses), and this patient is certainly at ongoing risk of infection given her long-standing edema. However, she does not have typical features of cellulitis (e.g., pain, erythema, warmth, tenderness, systemic symptoms), which makes an infection very unlikely.

images.title: Cellulitis in superinfected scabies
images.description: Diffuse, poorly demarcated erythema and edema associated with small, crusted red patches are visible over the left leg.These findings are consistent with cellulitis due to scabies infection.

answers.explanation_why: Melanoma, a malignant skin cancer originating from melanocytes, should always be considered in the differential for a growing, asymmetric, hyperpigmented skin lesion. While this patient is at increased risk (age, previous skin cancer) for developing melanoma, the presence of chronic lymphedema is more consistent with a different diagnosis.

images.title: Superficial spreading melanoma
images.description: Composite image showing 6 patients with superficial spreading melanomaOf the ABCDE criteria of skin lesions concerning for melanoma, the lesion in image 1 fulfills only criteria A (asymmetry) and B (border irregularity). The lesions in images 2–6 fulfill criteria A, B, and C (color variegation). The lesion in image 2 also fulfills criterion D (diameter > 6 mm), which cannot be assessed in the other images in the absence of a measurement device. Criterion E (evolution: changes over time) cannot be assessed on single images.

answers.explanation_why: Thrombophlebitis of a superficial vein typically manifests with erythema and tenderness along the vein and can cause congestion of venous vasculature distal to the thrombus. While upper extremity thrombophlebitis can have a similar distribution of lesions to that seen in this patient, it typically manifests with associated pain and erythema, which are not seen here. In addition, this patient's history of chronic lymphedema suggests a different diagnosis.

Elder abuse should always be considered in an elderly patient presenting with possible bruises or hematomas. However, the chronicity, progressive growth in size, and history of lymphedema make an alternative diagnosis more likely.

Cutaneous lichen planus typically manifests with purple, polygonal, pruritic papules, or plaques (5 Ps) on the lower back, wrist, and/or ankles. It can also manifest with a lattice-like network of white stripes, called Wickham striae. This patient has no major features of lichen planus (pruritus, polygonal shape) and the distribution of her lesions in combination with chronic lymphedema suggests a different diagnosis.

images.title: Cutaneous lichen planus
images.description: Photograph of the left wristMultiple erythematous papules, which are partially confluent are visible on the flexor side of the wrist. The papules are polygonal in shape and appear to be slightly elevated. This finding is characteristic of cutaneous lichen planus. as polygonal, pink, slightly elevated, sharply demarcated, and partially confluent and partially grouped.

answers.explanation_why: Kaposi sarcoma may also manifest with purple skin plaques of the extremities that can progress to deeper, more nodular, and, occasionally, ulcerative, lesions. However, the lesions usually develop in severely immunocompromised patients (e.g., individuals with AIDS, transplant recipients). The absence of severe immunocompromise in this elderly woman makes this diagnosis highly unlikely. In addition, her history of chronic lymphedema suggests a different diagnosis.

images.title: Kaposi sarcoma on skin
images.description: A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

question_text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of loss of urine for the last several months. She loses small amounts of urine without warning after coughing or sneezing. She also sometimes forgets the names of her relatives. She is retired and lives at an assisted-living facility. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her older sister recently received a ventriculoperitoneal shunt. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Medications include metformin and enalapril. Vital signs are within normal limits. She walks without any problems. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of loss of urine for the last several months. She loses small amounts of urine without warning after coughing or sneezing. She also sometimes forgets the names of her relatives. She is retired and lives at an assisted-living facility. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her older sister recently received a ventriculoperitoneal shunt. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Medications include metformin and enalapril. Vital signs are within normal limits. She walks without any problems. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with loss of urine with physical stress such as coughing, sneezing, and laughing. These features suggest a diagnosis of stress incontinence.
learning_objective: Recognize urethral hypermobility as a cause of stress incontinence.

answers.explanation_why: Detrusor overactivity is an important cause of urge incontinence. This form of urinary incontinence is characterized by a strong, sudden urge to urinate, which results in involuntary leakage of urine. However, this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is not preceded by any urge to urinate.

Complete loss of sphincter function would cause total urinary incontinence, which is characterized by continuous urinary leakage with no associated preceding symptoms or specific trigger activity. Complete loss of sphincter function is unlikely in this patient, who exhibits urinary expulsion preceded by physical stress.

Impaired detrusor contractility is the underlying mechanism of overflow incontinence, which is characterized by frequent, involuntary dribbling of urine that occurs when the bladder is full. Since this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is preceded by physical stress rather than a feeling of bladder fullness, this is unlikely to be the underlying cause here.

Urethral hypermobility is one of the most common causes of stress incontinence and is caused by impaired support from the pelvic floor. At times of increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, coughing, sneezing), the proximal urethra and the bladder neck descend out of the pelvis and transmit more pressure to the bladder. During this process, intraurethral pressure falls below bladder pressure, resulting in urine leakage. Considering this patient's age and gender, urethral hypermobility can result from postmenopausal estrogen loss and as part of the normal aging process.

Treatment of stress incontinence includes lifestyle modifications, Kegel exercises, and insertion of a vaginal pessary. If conservative treatment is insufficient, pharmacological and surgical treatment can be considered.

Detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia is the underlying mechanism of reflex incontinence, which is characterized by unpredictable urinary leakage that occurs when the bladder is full or otherwise stimulated (e.g., by cold air). This occurs due to simultaneous dyssynergistic contractions of the sphincter and the detrusor muscle, brought about by an underlying neurologic condition like multiple sclerosis or spinal cord injury. This patient has no such condition and exhibits urinary expulsion that is preceded by physical stress.

answers.content: Bacterial infection of the urinary tract
answers.explanation_why: A urinary tract infection could possibly cause incontinence. Preexisting diabetes mellitus, in the setting of forgetfulness (and thus, possibly poor personal hygiene), could increase the chance of infection in this patient. However, the lack of typical features of infection, like fever and dysuria, make this a highly unlikely underlying cause of this patient's condition.

Decreased cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) absorption is the underlying pathology in normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). This condition often manifests in adults > 60 years of age and commonly manifests with signs of dementia and urinary incontinence, which are both seen in this elderly patient. However, the absence of gait disturbance, which is typically the initial and most prominent symptom of the disease, makes this diagnosis unlikely. Also, the incontinence in NPH is usually of the urge type, in which the patient experiences a strong, sudden urge to urinate, followed by urinary leakage. Since this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is not preceded by any urge to urinate, decreased CSF absorption is unlikely to be the underlying cause.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

question_text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of loss of urinary control for the last year. The patient states that she loses control over her bladder when walking or standing up. She reports frequent, small-volume urine losses with no urge to urinate prior to the leakage. She tried to strengthen her pelvic muscles with supervised Kegel exercises and using a continence pessary but her symptoms did not improve. The patient is sexually active with her husband. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her hemoglobin A_1c is 6.3% and fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 100 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of loss of urinary control for the last year. The patient states that she loses control over her bladder when walking or standing up. She reports frequent, small-volume urine losses with no urge to urinate prior to the leakage. She tried to strengthen her pelvic muscles with supervised Kegel exercises and using a continence pessary but her symptoms did not improve. The patient is sexually active with her husband. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her hemoglobin A1c is 6.3% and fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 100 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: This patient presents with loss of urine with light physical stress (walking and standing up), features which suggest moderate stress incontinence.
learning_objective: Recognize moderate stress incontinence, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Topical vaginal estrogen is indicated in patients with vaginal atrophy, a common condition in postmenopausal women that may also manifest with symptoms of urinary incontinence. However, she is lacking typical signs of atrophy such as vaginal dryness, irritation, and dyspareunia.

Duloxetine is only used off-label for urinary stress incontinence; it is not yet approved in the US for this indication. Duloxetine is thought to enhance sphincter contraction as a result of inhibiting serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake at the spinal level.

Urethropexy (colposuspension) used to be the gold standard surgical procedure following unsuccessful conservative management of stress incontinence. However, it requires laparotomy or laparoscopy and is associated with a long operative duration and increased risk of certain postoperative complications (e.g., urgency incontinence). Urethropexy may be preferred in a patient who also requires repair of pelvic organ prolapse.

Glucosuria in poorly controlled diabetes mellitus may cause polyuria as glucose causes osmotic movement of water into the tubules. Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus can lead to recurrent urinary tract infections that may cause unintentional voiding due to dysuria, frequency, and urgency. However, this patient's diabetes is well controlled and her loss of urine with light physical stress suggests stress incontinence.

Biofeedback is a supplemental modality for those learning pelvic floor muscle strengthening exercises with difficulty identifying the proper muscles. Sensors placed close to the anus are connected to a computer screen, displaying a graph with the patient's muscle contractions. While biofeedback may be helpful in regaining bladder control in urinary incontinence, this woman has already tried supervised muscle strengthening exercises, which did not relieve her symptoms.

A urethral sling is the first-line surgical procedure for stress incontinence if conservative therapy, consisting of pelvic floor muscle exercises (Kegel exercises), lifestyle changes (e.g., weight loss, alcohol cessation), and use of continence pessaries have failed. The sling is inserted via vaginal approach and supports and partially compresses the urethral lumen, thereby decreasing or stopping urinary leakage when intraabdominal pressure increases. Complications following the procedure include erosion of sling material with formation of fistulas, urinary obstruction (if the sling is too tense), damage to the bladder and bowel, pain, bleeding, and urinary tract infections.

question_text: A 70-year-old woman, gravida 5, para 5, comes to the physician for the evaluation of sensation of vaginal fullness for the last six months. During this period, she has had lower back and pelvic pain that is worse with prolonged standing or walking. The patient underwent a hysterectomy at the age of 35 years because of severe dysmenorrhea. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolemia. Medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination elicits a feeling of pressure on the perineum. Pelvic floor muscle and anal sphincter tone are decreased. Pelvic examination shows protrusion of the posterior vaginal wall with Valsalva maneuver and transparent, thick fluid at the vaginal introitus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 70-year-old woman, gravida 5, para 5, comes to the physician for the evaluation of sensation of vaginal fullness for the last six months. During this period, she has had lower back and pelvic pain that is worse with prolonged standing or walking. The patient underwent a hysterectomy at the age of 35 years because of severe dysmenorrhea. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolemia. Medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination elicits a feeling of pressure on the perineum. Pelvic floor muscle and anal sphincter tone are decreased. Pelvic examination shows protrusion of the posterior vaginal wall with Valsalva maneuver and transparent, thick fluid at the vaginal introitus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with a condition that typically affects elderly women. Risk factors include multiparity, postmenopausal status, and prior pelvic surgery.
learning_objective: Recognize enterocele as a cause of posterior vaginal wall protrusion.

answers.explanation_why: Although a large Bartholin gland cyst can cause pelvic pain which worsens on walking, a pelvic examination would show a unilateral, soft, fluctuant mass in the lower vestibular area. Moreover, a Bartholin gland cyst is uncommon in this patient's age group (more common in young women).

The decrease in estrogen levels in postmenopausal women (or those who have undergone hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy) can cause atrophic vaginitis. Although atrophic vaginitis can occasionally manifest with vaginal discharge, this patient's other clinical features (feeling of pressure on the perineum, decreased tone of pelvic floor muscle and anal sphincter, protrusion of the posterior vaginal wall) are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

Although patients with infectious vulvovaginitis may also present with pelvic pain and vaginal discharge, the pelvic examination findings of posterior vaginal wall protrusion and lax sphincter in this patient are characteristic of another condition. In addition, the vaginal discharge of infectious vulvovaginitis is often purulent (e.g., in gonorrhea, chlamydia) and/or foul-smelling (e.g., bacterial vaginosis, trichomoniasis).

Pelvic pressure and/or pain, which worsens on standing or walking, in the presence of posterior vaginal wall protrusion and lax sphincter tone on pelvic examination, is diagnostic of enterocele. This condition also causes increased vaginal discharge. Posterior vaginal wall prolapse can either be an enterocele (upper 1/3^rd of the posterior vaginal wall) or rectocele (middle 1/3^rd of the posterior vaginal wall). Both can occur concurrently.

Although vaginal cancer is more common in women > 60 years of age and can manifest with pelvic discomfort and vaginal discharge, it does not cause a prolapse of the posterior vaginal wall, as seen in this patient.

question_text: An 82-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty sleeping and increasing fatigue. Over the past 3 months she has been waking up early and having trouble falling asleep at night. During this period, she has had a decreased appetite and a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss. Since the death of her husband one year ago, she has been living with her son and his wife. She is worried and feels guilty because she does not want to impose on them. She has stopped going to meetings at the senior center because she no longer enjoys them and because she feels uncomfortable asking her son to give her a ride, especially since he has been under a great deal of stress lately. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (110 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is tired and has a flattened affect. Cognition is intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: An 82-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty sleeping and increasing fatigue. Over the past 3 months she has been waking up early and having trouble falling asleep at night. During this period, she has had a decreased appetite and a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss. Since the death of her husband one year ago, she has been living with her son and his wife. She is worried and feels guilty because she does not want to impose on them. She has stopped going to meetings at the senior center because she no longer enjoys them and because she feels uncomfortable asking her son to give her a ride, especially since he has been under a great deal of stress lately. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (110 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is tired and has a flattened affect. Cognition is intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: This patient presents with ≥ 5 symptoms of depression (anhedonia, insomnia, loss of appetite, fatigue, and feelings of guilt) for ≥ 2 weeks, which is suggestive of major depressive disorder (MDD).
learning_objective: Recognize major depressive disorder, and choose the most appropriate initial step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Psychiatric hospitalization is indicated in patients with severe functional impairment and those at imminent risk of harming themselves or others. This patient's MDD may be severe enough to require hospitalization, but to establish this, she should first be properly assessed.

Notification of adult protective services becomes necessary if abuse and/or neglect are suspected. This patient's BMI is normal and physical examination has not revealed signs of malnourishment, dehydration, or physical abuse.

answers.content: Recommend relocation to a nursing home
answers.explanation_why: Recommending relocation to a nursing home could be indicated if the patient's son was unable to properly care for his mother or if there were signs of abuse and/or neglect (e.g., severe dehydration, low BMI), but this is not the case in this patient.

Cognitive-behavioral therapy can be helpful as an adjunct therapy in patients with MDD, because it can teach stress management, relaxation, and coping techniques, and may improve everyday functioning. However, patient assessment has to be completed beforehand.

Family therapy may be helpful in this patient with MDD as an adjunct therapy, especially since there are familial conflicts stressing her. However, it is not the next best step and patient assessment has to be completed beforehand.

This patient may benefit from mirtazapine therapy, a second-line treatment for MDD that would also cause her to gain weight and help improve insomnia due to its sedative effect. However, this patient requires proper assessment prior to initiation of antidepressive therapy.

Suicide screening and assessment is indicated for all patients who display symptoms of MDD. The physician should inquire about suicidal ideation, intent, and plans. Appropriate management depends on the severity of these symptoms and ranges from close observation, psychotherapy, and pharmacotherapy to the involvement of the family and involuntary hospitalization.

question_text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the office because she is having trouble staying awake in the evening. Over the past year, she has noticed that she gets tired unusually early in the evenings and has trouble staying awake through dinner. She also experiences increased daytime sleepiness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. She typically goes to bed between 7 and 8 PM and gets out of bed between 3 and 4 AM. She does not have any trouble falling asleep. She takes 30-minute to 1-hour daytime naps approximately 3 times per week. She has no history of severe illness and does not take any medication. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 71-year-old woman comes to the office because she is having trouble staying awake in the evening. Over the past year, she has noticed that she gets tired unusually early in the evenings and has trouble staying awake through dinner. She also experiences increased daytime sleepiness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. She typically goes to bed between 7 and 8 PM and gets out of bed between 3 and 4 AM. She does not have any trouble falling asleep. She takes 30-minute to 1-hour daytime naps approximately 3 times per week. She has no history of severe illness and does not take any medication. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Timed bright light phototherapy can be used to treat this patient's condition.
learning_objective: Recognize advanced sleep phase disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Advanced sleep phase disorder is a circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorder in which the sleep-wake cycle begins and ends earlier than normal. This causes individuals to feel the need to go to bed early and to wake up early in the morning regardless of when they go to bed. A patient who delays going to bed will therefore not get an adequate quantity of sleep, resulting in daytime sleepiness. Advanced sleep phase disorder is frequently associated with older age.

Patients with hypersomnolence disorder may have excessive daytime sleepiness despite at least 7 hours of uninterrupted sleep. However, other features of hypersomnolence disorder such as sleep inertia and prolonged sleep are also not present in this patient. Moreover, the onset of hypersomnolence disorder usually occurs between the ages of 15 and 25 years.

Depression can manifest initially as a sleep disturbance (insomnia or hypersomnia) and is often associated with early awakening. However, since this patient does not have other features of depression such as anhedonia, a depressed mood, and/or a change in appetite, another disorder is more likely. In older patients with sleep disturbances, a thorough history should be obtained and mental status examination performed in order to rule out major depressive disorder. This is important because the diagnosis of depression is often missed in older adults despite a relatively high prevalence.

Individuals with an insomnia disorder often have daytime sleepiness. However, they usually have difficulty falling asleep or difficulty staying asleep, unlike this patient, who does not have a history of frequent nighttime awakening or difficulty falling asleep.

Early sleep onset and early awakening are some of the changes in sleep patterns that occur as a part of the normal aging process. However, these changes would not be accompanied by symptoms such as daytime sleepiness and unusual tiredness in the evenings. Instead, patients typically complain of increased sleep latency and frequent nighttime awakenings. Also, total sleep time is typically decreased in normal aging whereas this patient sleeps 7–9 hours daily.

Patients with delayed sleep phase disorder would have excessive daytime sleepiness if they forced themselves to wake up before the end of their sleep-wake cycle. This patient, however, wakes up spontaneously early in the morning. Moreover, delayed sleep phase disorder causes individuals to go to bed later than normal (usually 1–4 AM) and would not result in excessive sleepiness in the evening. Factors associated with this condition include puberty, irregular sleep schedules, and caffeine/nicotine consumption before bedtime, none of which are seen here.

Patients with non-REM sleep arousal disorder would have repeated episodes of brief but incomplete awakenings (i.e., the patient does not become fully awake) during the first third of sleep. These episodes are furthermore often accompanied by sleepwalking or sleep terrors. Excessive daytime sleepiness and trouble staying awake in the evening are not features of non-REM sleep arousal disorder.

question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing pain in his right leg for 2 months. The pain persists throughout the day and does not improve with rest. He tried taking acetaminophen, but it provided no relief from his symptoms. There is no family history of serious illness. He does not smoke. He occasionally drinks one beer. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the right tibia is bowing anteriorly; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right leg shows a deformed tibia with multiple lesions of increased and decreased density and a thickened cortical bone. Laboratory studies show markedly elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and normal calcium and phosphate levels. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing pain in his right leg for 2 months. The pain persists throughout the day and does not improve with rest. He tried taking acetaminophen, but it provided no relief from his symptoms. There is no family history of serious illness. He does not smoke. He occasionally drinks one beer. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the right tibia is bowing anteriorly; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right leg shows a deformed tibia with multiple lesions of increased and decreased density and a thickened cortical bone. Laboratory studies show markedly elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and normal calcium and phosphate levels. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following complications?
hint: In a patient with bone pain, a deformed tibia (saber shin) with thickened cortical bone and both sclerotic and osteolytic lesions seen on x-ray, in combination with an isolated elevation of serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP), are suggestive of Paget disease of bone (PDB). This condition most commonly affects individuals > 50 years of age.
learning_objective: Recognize Paget disease of bone, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: Bone sequestrum is a complication of chronic osteomyelitis, which can manifest with persistent, localized bone pain. However, chronic osteomyelitis generally develops slowly (over months or years), inflammatory markers would be elevated, and x-ray would show bone destruction, sequestrum formation, and periosteal reactions.

images.title: Bony sequestrum
images.description: X-ray leg (left; AP view) of a childA fragment of bone (green overlay) has separated from adjacent bone and is surrounded by a lucent rim (red outline).A bony sequestrum is devascularized bone that may be seen in the setting of chronic osteomyelitis. A sequestrum may act as a nidus for ongoing infection.

answers.explanation_why: Renal insufficiency is a complication of multiple myeloma (MM), which can also cause localized bone pain. However, monoclonal plasma cell proliferation in the bone marrow in MM results in hypercalcemia, anemia, and exclusively lytic bone lesions, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation.

High-output cardiac failure is a rare complication of PDB. It arises as a result of increased vascularity within pagetic bones and the formation of arteriovenous fistulas within the bone, which, in turn, result in an increase in cardiac output to meet increased peripheral demand. High-output cardiac failure is usually associated with high PDB disease activity, as evidenced by an ALP level that is ≥ 4 times greater than normal and extensive skeletal involvement. Another complication of PDB is more common.

PDB is associated with a high rate of bone remodeling, and there is a risk of malignant degeneration into osteosarcoma. However, this is very rare, occurring in < 1% of cases. Another complication is more common.

Approx. 40% of patients with PDB have skull involvement, which can result in hearing impairment. Ankylosis of the ossicles can lead to conductive hearing loss while narrowing of the internal auditory meatus can lead to compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve and subsequent sensorineural hearing loss. Medical therapy with bisphosphonates should be initiated in all patients with active disease (raised ALP levels or active disease foci on skeletal scintigraphy).

Bone pain of PDB is often resistant to NSAIDs and acetaminophen, which is consistent with this patient's presentation. However, NSAIDs can be used to treat flu-like symptoms that arise during treatment with bisphosphonates.

images.title: Paget disease of bone fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Pancytopenia can occur secondary to numerous conditions that involve the bone marrow space and hematopoiesis. For instance, it may be seen in osteopetrosis, a diffuse bone disease that results in progressive sclerosis of the bone. However, x-ray would show homogenous, marbled thickening of cortical and trabecular bone, and serum calcium levels would be decreased.

question_text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of progressively worsening pain in her knees and fingers. The knee pain is worse when she walks for longer than 30 minutes. When she wakes up in the morning, her fingers and knees are stiff for about 15 minutes. She cannot recall any trauma to the joints. She was treated with amoxicillin following a tick bite 2 years ago. She is otherwise healthy and only takes a multivitamin and occasionally acetaminophen for the pain. She drinks one to two glasses of wine daily. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 133/78 mm Hg. Examination of the lower extremities shows mild genu varum. Range of motion of both knees is limited; there is palpable crepitus. Complete flexion and extension elicit pain. Tender nodules are present on the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of progressively worsening pain in her knees and fingers. The knee pain is worse when she walks for longer than 30 minutes. When she wakes up in the morning, her fingers and knees are stiff for about 15 minutes. She cannot recall any trauma to the joints. She was treated with amoxicillin following a tick bite 2 years ago. She is otherwise healthy and only takes a multivitamin and occasionally acetaminophen for the pain. She drinks one to two glasses of wine daily. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 133/78 mm Hg. Examination of the lower extremities shows mild genu varum. Range of motion of both knees is limited; there is palpable crepitus. Complete flexion and extension elicit pain. Tender nodules are present on the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's symptoms are consistent with the most common joint disorder in the US, which most frequently affects the knee.
learning_objective: Recognize osteoarthritis.

answers.explanation_why: Arthropathy due to gout is often acute, asymmetric, and usually involves a single joint (e.g., the great toe or a knee). Although this patient has a few risk factors for gout (e.g., advanced age, obesity, alcohol consumption), examination in gout would show an acutely red, tender, inflamed joint, with decreased range of motion and pain.

Lyme arthritis is a late manifestation of untreated Lyme disease, developing months (rarely, as late as 2 years) after a tick bite. Lyme arthritis usually causes effusion and mild pain in a single joint, most often the knee, but can affect multiple joints as well and can persist for several years. Although this patient sustained a past tick bite, which could have infected her with Borrelia burgdorferi, she was already treated with amoxicillin, the first-line therapy for Lyme disease. Additionally, she shows no extraarticular signs of the condition. Lastly, Lyme arthritis does not cause crepitus, genu varum, and interphalangeal nodes.

Although this patient presents with symmetrical small and large joint pain and stiffness, which would be seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), she has several features that are not consistent with this diagnosis. In patients with RA, morning stiffness of joints characteristically lasts for > 30 minutes, the joint pain and stiffness are relieved with activity, the DIP joints are not affected, and constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, night sweats) are often present. Moreover, the characteristic hand deformities from long-standing RA are swan-neck deformity and Boutonniere deformity as opposed to the interphalangeal joint nodes seen in this patient.

This patient presents with symptoms characteristic of osteoarthritis (OA): joint pain that worsens with ambulation/weight-bearing, joint stiffness < 30 minutes after prolonged immobility, decreased range of motion (due to osteophytes), palpable crepitus of both knees, genu varum (due to medial cartilage loss), and nodules on the DIP (Heberden nodes) and PIP (Bouchard nodes). Furthermore, this patient has multiple risk factors for OA, including female sex, obesity, and age > 55 years.

X-ray of the involved joints would most likely show decreased joint space, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis (areas of increased bone density caused by unequal load-bearing).

Septic arthritis generally has an acute onset, involves a single joint, and is characterized by fever, joint pain, signs of inflammation (erythema, edema, warmth), and a restricted range of joint motion. It is also typically associated with a distant infection (e.g., abscess), IV drug abuse, or immunosuppression. This patient's findings are inconsistent with septic arthritis.

Pseudogout or calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition (CPPD) disease is a paroxysmal joint inflammation due to calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition. CPPD is often asymptomatic, but acute CPPD can manifest with episodic pain in a single joint characterized by severe pain, inflammation, and joint disability. Chronic CPPD can cause progressively worsening pain affecting large and small joints, without signs of acute inflammation on examination, like this patient. However, chronic CPPD is uncommon and the characteristic interphalangeal joint nodes seen in this patient would not be present in CPPD.

question_text: Two days after being admitted for pneumonia, a 70-year-old man has repeated episodes of palpitations and nausea. He does not feel lightheaded and does not have chest pain. The patient appears mildly distressed. His pulse is 59/min and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Sputum cultures taken at the time of admission were positive for Mycoplasma pneumoniae. His magnesium concentration is 2.0 mg/dL and his potassium concentration is 3.7 mEq/L. An ECG taken during an episode of palpitations is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Two days after being admitted for pneumonia, a 70-year-old man has repeated episodes of palpitations and nausea. He does not feel lightheaded and does not have chest pain. The patient appears mildly distressed. His pulse is 59/min and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Sputum cultures taken at the time of admission were positive for Mycoplasma pneumoniae. His magnesium concentration is 2.0 mg/dL and his potassium concentration is 3.7 mEq/L. An ECG taken during an episode of palpitations is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The ECG shows polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). The QRS complexes can be seen twisting around the isoelectric baseline (best seen in lead V1), giving rise to a spindle-shaped pattern, also referred to as torsades de pointes (TdP).
learning_objective: Recognize polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (torsades de pointes), and choose the most appropriate initial treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Metoprolol would be the initial treatment of choice in patients with nonsustained VT who have an underlying cardiac condition. Beta blockers are not used in the treatment of TdP.

IV magnesium sulfate is the first-line treatment for TdP in hemodynamically stable patients. It is highly effective in terminating TdP as well as preventing recurrences, which is vital because patients are at an increased risk for ventricular fibrillation. Patients with a normal serum magnesium concentration also benefit from this intervention. TdP in this patient is most likely due to macrolide antibiotics, which are the first-line antibiotics for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia. The macrolide antibiotic should be discontinued and treatment with doxycycline initiated.

Emergent electrical cardioversion is the first-line treatment for TdP in hemodynamically unstable patients. However, this patient is conscious and hemodynamically stable, making another line of treatment more appropriate.
Amiodarone is the first-line therapy for ventricular tachycardia in hemodynamically stable patients. Amiodarone is, however, contraindicated in this patient because it prolongs the QT interval.

Temporary transvenous overdrive pacing (TTVP) is an alternative treatment modality that is reserved for patients with long QT-related TdP who do not respond to the first-line drug. TTVP increases the heart rate to ∼ 100 bpm and shortens the QT-interval, thereby terminating the TdP.
Administration of potassium chloride (KCl) is indicated to treat hypokalemia, which can cause TdP. This patient's K^+ levels are normal; KCl is not the treatment of choice of this patient's TdP.

images.title: Torsades de pointes
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Bursts of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT; rate ∼ 220/min) alternating with sinus beats
– During the VT phases, the QRS complexes are wide (∼ 200 ms) and appear to be twisting around the isoelectric line, producing a spindle-shaped pattern (best seen in V_1 rhythm strip; indicated by green ellipse).These findings are characteristic of torsades de pointes (TdP), a subtype of polymorphic VT.Note how the sinus rhythm converts to VT/TdP as a result of the R-on-T phenomenon (best seen in rhythm strip V_6): a premature ventricular complex (PVC; red line) occurs in the downslope of the preceding T wave, initiating VT/TdP.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain and muscle weakness in her right lower leg for 3 hours. Medical history is remarkable for rheumatic mitral valve stenosis, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, hydrochlorothiazide, and lisinopril. Her pulse is 88/min and irregularly irregular, and her blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a cool and pale right leg with delayed capillary filling. Muscle strength and tone in the right calf and foot are decreased. Femoral pulses are present bilaterally. Pedal pulses are absent on the right. Inhibition of which of the following would have most likely prevented this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain and muscle weakness in her right lower leg for 3 hours. Medical history is remarkable for rheumatic mitral valve stenosis, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, hydrochlorothiazide, and lisinopril. Her pulse is 88/min and irregularly irregular, and her blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a cool and pale right leg with delayed capillary filling. Muscle strength and tone in the right calf and foot are decreased. Femoral pulses are present bilaterally. Pedal pulses are absent on the right. Inhibition of which of the following would have most likely prevented this patient's condition?
hint: This patient presents with signs of acute limb ischemia. Her irregularly irregular pulse and history of rheumatic mitral valve stenosis suggest that atrial fibrillation (Afib) is the most likely cause.
learning_objective: Recognize acute limb ischemia, and recall the prevention of thromboembolic events in atrial fibrillation.

answers.explanation_why: P2Y12 receptor antagonists (e.g., clopidogrel) inhibit platelet aggregation and are indicated in the management of acute myocardial infarction and secondary prevention of cardiac events after percutaneous coronary intervention and/or stenting. These agents are not used to prevent thromboembolism in patients with Afib.

Long-term anticoagulation is indicated in women with Afib who have a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥ 3. This therapy prevents atrial thrombus formation and subsequent thromboembolic events (e.g., acute limb ischemia, stroke). This patient has a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 4 (history of hypertension, history of diabetes, age 65–74 years, female sex) and a HAS-BLED score of 1, excluding contraindications for anticoagulation therapy. Given this patient's history of mitral valve stenosis, warfarin (a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor) is the preferred anticoagulant.

Nondihydropyridine channel blockers, such as verapamil, inhibit L-type calcium channels and can be used to control heart rate in patients with Afib. However, calcium channel blockers are not used to prevent atrial thrombus formation and subsequent thromboembolic events.

Aspirin inhibits the synthesis of prostaglandins through irreversible inhibition of the cyclooxygenase enzyme. Aspirin is sometimes used to reduce the risk of thromboembolic events in patients with Afib but is not as effective as another treatment. It may be considered if patients cannot tolerate first-line agents due to bleeding risks, which is not the case here.

Beta blockers, such as metoprolol, inhibit beta-adrenergic receptors of the sympathetic nervous system and can be used to control fast heart rate in patients with Afib. However, beta blockers do not prevent atrial thrombus formation and subsequent thromboembolic events.

question_text:
A previously healthy 75-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and decreasing exercise tolerance over the past 6 weeks. She also has intermittent episodes of dizziness. She has never smoked and does not drink alcohol. She takes a daily multivitamin. She appears pale. Physical examination shows a smooth liver that is palpable 1 cm below the costal margin. The spleen is not palpable. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
9.8 g/dL

MCV
104 fL

Reticulocyte count
0.2%

Folate

21 ng/mL (N = 2–20)

Vitamin B_12

789 pg/mL (N = 200–900)

A peripheral blood smear shows anisocytosis and bone marrow aspirate shows ringed sideroblasts. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following?
content_preview: A previously healthy 75-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and decreasing exercise tolerance over the past 6 weeks. She also has intermittent episodes of dizziness. She has never smoked and does not drink alcohol. She takes a daily multivitamin. She appears pale. Physical examination shows a smooth liver that is palpable 1 cm below the costal margin. The spleen is not palpable. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 9.8 g/dL MCV 104 fL Reticulocyte count 0.2% Folate 21 ng/mL (N = 2–20) Vitamin B12 789 pg/mL (N = 200–900) A peripheral blood smear shows anisocytosis and bone marrow aspirate shows ringed sideroblasts. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following?
hint: This patient's symptomatic macrocytic anemia (low hemoglobin, high MCV) with an insufficient reticulocyte response indicates dysplastic hematopoiesis. Her normal folate and vitamin B_12 levels indicate refractory anemia. Together with the presence of ringed sideroblasts, the laboratory results raise concern for myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).
learning_objective: Recognize myelodysplastic syndrome, and recall its progression to acute myelocytic leukemia.

answers.explanation_why: Sézary syndrome is a cutaneous non-Hodgkin lymphoma that can develop secondary to mycosis fungoides. Although anemia can occur, other features such as hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, and leukemic dissemination would also be expected. More importantly, because mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous lymphoma, these findings would be preceded by intensely pruritic erythroderma accompanied by palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis. Atypical T cells would be present on peripheral blood smear instead of ringed sideroblasts. Sézary syndrome is not associated with MDS.

images.title: Mycosis fungoides
images.description: Left upper arm, shoulder, and back with sharply demarcated, partially confluent, erythematous scaling lesions that are severely pruritic.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) primarily occurs in older patients (> 70 years) and could explain this patient's anemia. However, CLL more commonly manifests with a more insidious onset of B symptoms, hepatosplenomegaly, and painless lymphadenopathy and is not associated with MDS. Predisposing factors include positive family history, advanced age, and exposure to organic solvents. Bone marrow biopsy of patients with CLL would reveal lymphocytosis and characteristic smudge cells rather than ringed sideroblasts.

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), the most common non-Hodgkin lymphoma in adults, can occur spontaneously or secondary to numerous low-grade B-cell lymphomas (e.g., chronic lymphocytic leukemia). Patients with DLBCL are of advanced age (> 70 years) and present with a rapidly enlarging mass within the lymph system. However, B symptoms (weight loss, fever, night sweats) and painless lymphadenopathy would also be expected. In addition, DLBCL would not cause ringed sideroblasts and does not occur in association with myelodysplastic syndrome.

Acute myelocytic leukemia (AML) develops in up to 30% of patients with MDS. The two conditions are distinguished based on the blast percentage in the bone marrow (blast percentage > 20% in AML) and the presence of AML-related chromosomal abnormalities in pluripotent stem cells. Patients with MDS that progresses to AML have a worse prognosis because they are not as responsive to chemotherapy (compared to patients with de novo AML).

images.title: Anisocytosis and poikilocytosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Pappenheim stain)This specimen depicts anisocytosis, which are erythrocytes of different sizes (black circles), as well as poikilocytosis, which are erythrocytes of different shapes. Acanthocytes with thorny projections (light blue circles) and teardrop shaped dacrocytes (red circles) are present.These findings suggest impaired erythropoiesis, which may be a result of impaired bone marrow hematopoiesis.

answers.explanation_why: Multiple myeloma (MM) can develop secondary to monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS), which is diagnosed in asymptomatic patients with elevated serum monoclonal immunoglobulins (>3 g/dL). Approximately 1% of patients with MGUS progress to MM annually. Anemia could be an early sign of MM. However, other findings, such as bone pain, symptoms of hypercalcemia, and foamy urine, would also be expected.

Although hairy cell leukemia (HCL) could be responsible for this woman's anemia, patients with HCL usually also have massive splenomegaly, as well as thrombocytopenia and neutropenia (multiple cells lines are affected). HCL is associated with exposure to ionizing radiation and pesticides, but not with myelodysplastic syndrome.

question_text:
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of an unintentional 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. During this period, the patient has had recurrent episodes of high-grade fever, night sweats, and feelings of fatigue. Two months ago, he had herpes zoster that was treated with acyclovir. He appears pale. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows generalized painless lymphadenopathy. The liver and the spleen are palpated 2–3 cm below the right and the left costal margin, respectively. Laboratory studies show:

Hematocrit
42%

Leukocyte count
15,000/mm^3

Segmented neutrophils
46%

Eosinophils
1%

Lymphocytes
50%

Monocytes
3%

Platelet count
120,000/mm^3

Blood smear shows mature lymphocytes that rupture easily and appear as artifacts on a blood smear. Flow cytometry shows lymphocytes expressing CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
content_preview: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of an unintentional 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. During this period, the patient has had recurrent episodes of high-grade fever, night sweats, and feelings of fatigue. Two months ago, he had herpes zoster that was treated with acyclovir. He appears pale. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows generalized painless lymphadenopathy. The liver and the spleen are palpated 2–3 cm below the right and the left costal margin, respectively. Laboratory studies show: Hematocrit 42% Leukocyte count 15,000/mm3 Segmented neutrophils 46% Eosinophils 1% Lymphocytes 50% Monocytes 3% Platelet count 120,000/mm3 Blood smear shows mature lymphocytes that rupture easily and appear as artifacts on a blood smear. Flow cytometry shows lymphocytes expressing CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
hint: This patient's history (weight loss, fatigue), examination (generalized painless lymphadenopathy) and laboratory findings (lymphocytosis) suggest chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate treatment for chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

answers.explanation_why: Chlorambucil is commonly used to treat CLL in individuals > 65–70 years of age with poor overall fitness and comorbidities, which is not the case in this patient. To improve the chances of remission in an individual with CD20-positive lymphocytes, as is the case here, treatment should include a particular monoclonal antibody that targets B cells.

Allogeneic stem cell transplantation can be considered in refractory CLL or early recurrence in otherwise healthy, young patients. This patient is already > 60 years old, presents with various symptoms, and the first-line medical treatment has not yet been tried.

The combination of vincristine, glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone), and doxorubicin is commonly used as induction therapy for patients with ALL. Clinical findings often include fatigue, pallor, hepatomegaly, and/or splenomegaly, as well as painless lymphadenopathy and B symptoms, which can be seen in this patient. However, patients with ALL are typically very young (peak incidence is 2–5 years) and laboratory studies would show a high number of lymphoblasts. Additionally, smudge cells on peripheral smear would not be expected.

Vitamin A derivatives such as all-trans retinoic acid are used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), the M3 variant of acute myelogenous leukemia (AML). Clinical findings of individuals with acute leukemia commonly include B symptoms, fatigue, pallor, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly, which may resemble this patient's presentation. APL would be confirmed by a peripheral blood smear showing immature blasts, often containing characteristic Auer rods, in contrast to the mature lymphocytes and smudge cells detected on this patient's blood smear.

CLL can manifest with recurrent viral infections, B symptoms, immunosuppression, painless lymphadenopathy, and hepato-/splenomegaly, along with lymphocytic leukocytosis and suppression of other blood cell lines (e.g., granulocytopenia, thrombocytopenia). Additionally, CLL is associated with smudge cells (ruptured lymphocytes) on peripheral blood smear and the detection of B-cell antigens CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23 on flow cytometry. Chemotherapy with fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, and rituximab is appropriate for patients experiencing severe symptoms (e.g., extreme fatigue or painful lymph nodes) or those with signs of advanced disease (e.g., hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia) and who are < 65–70 years. It would be the preferred treatment for a 63-year-old man presenting with symptoms due to CLL.

A low thrombocyte count (< 100,000/mm^3) indicates a worse prognosis.

CLL is characterized by a slow rate of cell division and gradual disease progression. Treatment is often unnecessary or is unlikely to improve survival time, which is why observation and monitoring of disease progression usually suffice in cases of asymptomatic CLL. However, this patient has already presented with a number of clinical findings that are caused by CLL and could benefit from medical treatment as palliative therapy.

The combination of adriamycin (doxorubicin), bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine (ABVD) is the first-line treatment for patients with Hodgkin lymphoma. Individuals usually present with painless lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and/or splenomegaly and B symptoms, which may resemble the symptoms seen in this patient. However, this patient's peripheral smear has smudge cells, which are not consistent with Hodgkin lymphoma.

The tyrosine kinase inhibitor imatinib is appropriate as first-line targeted therapy for patients with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) caused by a t(9,22) chromosome, also known as the Philadelphia chromosome. While CML is often asymptomatic and diagnosed incidentally in adults on routine CBC with the discovery of leukocytosis, the differential in the case of CML would show a left shift toward neutrophils and other granulocytes, in contrast to the lymphocytosis found in this patient's CBC differential.

question_text: A previously healthy 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of chronic, progressive fatigue over the last 18 months. About four months ago, he started experiencing left-sided abdominal discomfort and occasionally has left shoulder pain. He also has had a 7-kg (15.4-lb) weight loss during this period. He has not seen a physician since he retired from his job on a production line at a shoe factory 5 years ago. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nontender, bilateral axillary, and right-sided inguinal lymphadenopathy. The spleen is palpated 7 cm below the left costal margin and the liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.5 g/dL, leukocyte count of 40,000/mm^3 with marked lymphocytosis, and a thrombocyte count of 97,000/mm^3. Peripheral blood smear shows numerous mature lymphocytes and smudge cells. Flow cytometry shows B cells that express CD20. Which of the following is the strongest indicator of a poor prognosis for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A previously healthy 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of chronic, progressive fatigue over the last 18 months. About four months ago, he started experiencing left-sided abdominal discomfort and occasionally has left shoulder pain. He also has had a 7-kg (15.4-lb) weight loss during this period. He has not seen a physician since he retired from his job on a production line at a shoe factory 5 years ago. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nontender, bilateral axillary, and right-sided inguinal lymphadenopathy. The spleen is palpated 7 cm below the left costal margin and the liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.5 g/dL, leukocyte count of 40,000/mm3 with marked lymphocytosis, and a thrombocyte count of 97,000/mm3. Peripheral blood smear shows numerous mature lymphocytes and smudge cells. Flow cytometry shows B cells that express CD20. Which of the following is the strongest indicator of a poor prognosis for this patient's condition?
hint: This patient presents with chronic, progressive fatigue, painless, generalized lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. In addition, he has left shoulder pain (likely referred pain), lymphocytosis, smudge cells, and B cells with CD20 expression. Exposure to organic solvents (e.g., from working in a shoe production factory) increases the risk of developing hematological conditions, making chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) the most likely diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), and recall the prognostic indicators of CLL.

answers.explanation_why: In patients with CLL, peripheral lymphadenopathy indicates disease progression, as it shows the involvement of lymph nodes following lymphocytosis in the bone marrow and blood. Individuals who present with peripheral lymphadenopathy in addition to lymphocytosis (Rai stage I) are defined as having an intermediate-risk disease with a median survival time of 101 months.

In patients with CLL, splenomegaly is a characteristic finding and another indication of disease progression. Individuals who present with hepatosplenomegaly in addition to lymphocytosis and peripheral lymphadenopathy (Rai stage II) are defined as having an intermediate-risk disease with a median survival time of 71 months.
In patients with CLL, B cells commonly express the CD20 antigen as well as CD5, CD19, and/or CD23. However, the expression of one or a combination of antigens does not indicate a poor prognosis.

Thrombocytopenia typically manifests in later stages of CLL and indicates severely impaired bone marrow function. Patients with a platelet count < 100,000/mm^3, in addition to other findings (i.e., lymphocytosis, lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly and/or splenomegaly, anemia), have the worst prognosis among individuals with CLL.

For patients with signs of advanced disease, treatment usually consists of chemotherapy with fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, and rituximab.

In patients with CLL, lymphocytosis is a characteristic finding that is already present in early stages of the disease. Isolated lymphocytosis in individuals with CLL does not indicate a poor prognosis (median survival time of > 150 months).

Smudge cells on peripheral blood smear is a characteristic finding in patients with CLL. Although a percentage of > 10% is generally seen as pathognomonic for CLL, it does not indicate a poor prognosis.

question_text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and lower back pain for the past 4 months. The back pain worsened significantly after he had a minor fall while doing yard work the previous day. The patient's brother died of prostate cancer at the age of 75 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilateral paravertebral muscle spasm, severe tenderness over the second lumbar vertebra, and mild tenderness over the lower thoracic vertebrae. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.5 g/dL, serum alkaline phosphatase concentration is 90 U/L, and serum calcium concentration is 11.1 mg/dL. An x-ray of the skull is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and lower back pain for the past 4 months. The back pain worsened significantly after he had a minor fall while doing yard work the previous day. The patient's brother died of prostate cancer at the age of 75 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilateral paravertebral muscle spasm, severe tenderness over the second lumbar vertebra, and mild tenderness over the lower thoracic vertebrae. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.5 g/dL, serum alkaline phosphatase concentration is 90 U/L, and serum calcium concentration is 11.1 mg/dL. An x-ray of the skull is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with fatigue, bone pain, and a possible pathological vertebral fracture. In combination with anemia, hypercalcemia, and multiple lytic lesions ("punched-out" holes) in the skull on x-ray, these features suggest multiple myeloma (MM).
learning_objective: Recognize features suggestive of multiple myeloma, and choose the most appropriate initial screening test.

answers.explanation_why:
Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) is an initial screening test in patients with suspected MM. SPEP can detect monoclonal production of a protein by a malignant plasma cell, showing a characteristic abnormal peak (M spike) in the γ-globulin region. Subsequent serum immunofixation enables determination of the type of monoclonal protein, with most cases being due to abnormal production of IgG (50%) or IgA (25%). In patients with MM, anemia (and possibly thrombocytopenia and leukopenia) results from bone marrow infiltration by malignant plasma cells with suppression of normal hematopoiesis. Hypercalcemia is caused by increased production of osteoclast-activating factors that result in osteolysis.

If SPEP confirms abnormal plasma cell protein production, a 24-hour urinary collection for protein electrophoresis and immunofixation is indicated to detect the possible presence of light chains in the urine (Bence Jones protein), which can cause renal failure due to cast nephropathy.

images.title: Multiple myeloma - serum protein electrophoresis with M protein
images.description: Pathological protein electrophoresis in multiple myeloma: the monoclonal antibodies cause a peak in the gamma-globulin zone of the electrophoresis, which is termed M protein (also M component, myeloma protein, spike protein, and paraprotein).

answers.explanation_why: Prostate biopsy is used to diagnose prostate cancer (PCa), which, in a metastatic stage, can manifest with fatigue, back pain, pathologic fractures, and bone lesions on x-ray. This patient's family history of prostate cancer puts him at increased risk for this condition. However, PCa metastases are typically osteoblastic (rather than osteolytic), manifesting with sclerotic lesions and increased alkaline phosphatase. Moreover, because of the lack of osteolytic activity in patients with PCa, hypercalcemia is not a common laboratory finding. Furthermore, a digital rectal examination and measurement of prostate-specific antigen would be indicated prior to pathologic confirmation of prostate cancer.

images.title: Sclerotic bone metastases
images.description: X-ray pelvis (AP view) of a patient with prostate cancer:Numerous sclerotic metastases are seen throughout the pelvis, lumbar spine, and proximal femurs (examples indicated by green overlay). Also seen is avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of the right hip, with marked fragmentation of the femoral head (indicated by red overlay) and superior subluxation of the femur (asymmetry indicated by dashed lines).

answers.explanation_why: Bone marrow biopsy showing ≥ 10% clonal plasma cells is the confirmatory test of choice in patients with suspected MM. While this patient's symptoms are highly suggestive of MM, bone marrow biopsy is an invasive test that is only performed after monoclonal protein production has been confirmed with the appropriate screening test.

An MRI of the spine can help to determine the neurologic involvement in patients with vertebral fractures. While this patient's history of recent trauma and the severe tenderness over the second lumbar vertebra are suggestive of a vertebral fracture, the absence of neurologic symptoms (e.g., weakness, numbness, urinary incontinence) and the normal neurologic exam make spinal compression less likely. An anterior-posterior and lateral x-ray of the spine should be obtained first to assess the integrity of the vertebral column.

A bone scan can be used in the diagnosis of Paget disease of bone, which typically affects older men. Paget disease of bone may also manifest with bone pain, pathologic fractures, and osteolytic skull lesions. However, affected patients usually have elevated alkaline phosphatase and normal serum calcium. Moreover, radiographs of patients with Paget disease of bone usually show a mixed picture of both sclerotic and osteolytic lesions, as well as a thickened calvaria. Also, this patient lacks other features of the disease, such as skull enlargement, cranial nerve deficits, or hearing loss.

images.title: Paget disease of the skull
images.description: X-ray skull (lateral view)The calvarium is markedly thickened (left right arrow), with widening of the diploic space. Numerous ill-defined lytic (examples indicated by green overlay) and sclerotic (examples indicated by red overlay) lesions are present.The presence of multiple poorly marginated sclerotic lesions in Paget disease has been termed “cotton wool appearance.”

answers.explanation_why: In adults, a deficiency of vitamin D causes osteomalacia, which can also manifest with bone pain and pathologic fractures. However, low levels of vitamin D impair intestinal resorption of calcium, resulting in hypocalcemia. Alkaline phosphatase is typically elevated in osteomalacia due to increased bone turnover. Furthermore, patients with osteomalacia would present with generalized low bone mineral density and thin cortices on x-ray rather than the localized osteolytic lesions seen here. Also, anemia is not a feature of osteomalacia; instead, patients typically complain of muscle weakness and difficulty walking.

Hemoglobin electrophoresis is used in the diagnosis of hemoglobinopathies, including thalassemias. While the homozygote form of beta-thalassemia (thalassemia major) can cause anemia, skeletal abnormalities, and pathologic fractures, the diagnosis is typically established at age 6–12 months, when affected children present with pallor, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly (due to extramedullary hematopoiesis). Untreated children with beta-thalassemia major will die of their disease, ruling out this diagnosis in this 70-year-old. Also, rather than the punched-out lytic lesions seen on the skull x-ray in this patient, patients with beta-thalassemia major have characteristic skeletal deformities with a high forehead and prominent zygomatic bones and maxilla (chipmunk facies) due to expansion of the bone marrow.

images.title: Lytic calvarial lesions in multiple myeloma
images.description: X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myelomaNumerous very small, well-circumscribed (punched-out) lytic lesions without sclerotic margins are seen (examples indicated by arrowheads).
