question_text: A 75-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of fatigue. During this period, she has also had fever, pain in both shoulders and hips, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. She also reports feeling stiff for about an hour after waking up. She has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. There is no family history of serious illness. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. Her medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. She appears pale. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Range of motion of the shoulders and hips is reduced due to pain. Examination shows full muscle strength. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 50 mm/h and a C-reactive protein concentration of 8.2 mg/L (N = 0.08–3.1). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 75-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of fatigue. During this period, she has also had fever, pain in both shoulders and hips, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. She also reports feeling stiff for about an hour after waking up. She has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. There is no family history of serious illness. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. Her medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. She appears pale. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Range of motion of the shoulders and hips is reduced due to pain. Examination shows full muscle strength. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 50 mm/h and a C-reactive protein concentration of 8.2 mg/L (N = 0.08–3.1). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This older patient presents with systemic (fatigue, fever, weight loss) and musculoskeletal symptoms (symmetrical pain in the shoulders and hips, morning stiffness) as well as elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) concentration. These features are consistent with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR).
learning_objective: Recognize polymyalgia rheumatica, and choose the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Low to medium-dose oral glucocorticoids such as prednisone are the treatment of choice for PMR, a condition most commonly seen in women aged over 70 years. The diagnosis of PMR is established based on typical clinical symptoms and laboratory findings (elevated acute phase reactants, normal creatine kinase, negative rheumatoid factor, and no autoantibodies). Symptomatic relief is typically achieved quickly after therapy is initiated, and the glucocorticoid dose can be slowly tapered until the patient is in full remission. If symptoms do not begin to improve within 2 weeks, the glucocorticoid dose should be increased.

images.title: Polymyalgia rheumatica and giant cell arteritis fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: A biopsy of the temporal artery is indicated to confirm the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis (GCA). GCA may also manifest with fatigue, weight loss, and elevated ESR and CRP levels. While GCA is often associated with PMR, in the absence of the characteristic temporal headache, hardened, tender temporal artery, and impaired vision (e.g., vision loss, diplopia), a biopsy is not required.

High doses of intravenous methylprednisolone are administered to prevent further joint or organ damage in patients with severe inflammatory conditions, such as giant cell arteritis (GCA) or rheumatoid arthritis (RA). While GCA is often associated with PMR, this patient has no characteristic features of GCA (e.g., temporal headache, hardened temporal artery) and no features of RA (e.g., involvement of metacarpophalangeal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints). Treatment with high-dose IV methylprednisolone is therefore not indicated.

A muscle biopsy is indicated if polymyositis or dermatomyositis is suspected. While both conditions affect the pelvic and shoulder girdle muscles and can be associated with myalgia, the predominant symptom is muscle weakness. Because this patient shows full strength on physical examination, a muscle biopsy is not indicated.

Electromyography is indicated in patients with suspected inflammatory myopathy, such as polymyositis or dermatomyositis. While both conditions affect the pelvic and shoulder girdle muscles and can be associated with myalgia, the predominant symptom is muscle weakness. Since this patient has full muscle strength on examination, electromyography is not indicated.

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which typically manifests with constitutional symptoms, morning stiffness, and joint pain. However, patients with SLE typically present with distal, symmetrical polyarthritis that most commonly affects the joints of the fingers, wrists, and knees. Skin findings, e.g., malar rash, are also common. Moreover, SLE typically affects women between 15 and 45 years of age. Finally, antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) should be obtained first; if positive, antigen-specific ANAs such as anti-dsDNA antibodies should be requested.

A chest x-ray should be considered in this patient to rule out lung cancer. With a smoking history of 50 pack years and constitutional symptoms of weight loss, fever, and fatigue, a malignancy is possible. However, since this patient has no further symptoms indicating lung cancer (e.g., cough, hemoptysis), and instead presents with symptoms of PMR, a chest x-ray is not the most appropriate next step in management.

question_text: A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well but is unhappy about being overweight. She reports that she feels out of breath when walking for more than one block and while climbing stairs. She has tried to lose weight for several years without success. She goes for a walk 3 times a week but she has difficulty following a low-calorie diet. During the past 12 months, she has had two urinary tract infections that were treated with fosfomycin. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis. Her only current medication is metformin. She has never smoked. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 39 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows cracking in both knees on passive movement. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show an HbA1c of 9.5%, and a fasting serum glucose concentration of 158 mg/dL. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well but is unhappy about being overweight. She reports that she feels out of breath when walking for more than one block and while climbing stairs. She has tried to lose weight for several years without success. She goes for a walk 3 times a week but she has difficulty following a low-calorie diet. During the past 12 months, she has had two urinary tract infections that were treated with fosfomycin. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis. Her only current medication is metformin. She has never smoked. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 39 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows cracking in both knees on passive movement. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show an HbA1c of 9.5%, and a fasting serum glucose concentration of 158 mg/dL. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: This patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with recurrent urinary tract infections, and a hemoglobin A1c of 9.5%, both of which suggest insufficient glycemic control with her current medication regimen. The patient's desire to lose weight should also be considered when adjusting her treatment.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for a diabetic patient with obesity and recurrent urinary tract infections.

answers.explanation_why: GLP-1 agonists, such as exenatide, can cause weight loss and control hyperglycemia. Incretin-based therapeutic agents such as GLP-1 agonists also have the additional benefit of a low risk of medication-induced hypoglycemia. Besides metformin and GLP-1 agonists, other drugs that can be used for weight loss in diabetic patients include SGLT-2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin), orlistat, and pramlintide. However, SGLT-2 inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with recurrent urinary tract infections, as is the case here. Also, orlistat does not cause glycemic control, which is desired in this patient, and pramlintide is only used in combination with insulin therapy.

images.title: Mechanism of action: oral diabetes medications
images.description:
- Biguanides (e.g., metformin): inhibit mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD) → reduction in hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipogenesis
- SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin): inhibit SGLT2 transport molecules in the kidney → reduced reabsorption of glucose from the renal filtrate
- α-Glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose): inhibit glycoside hydrolase enzymes, which are required to break down carbohydrate molecules in the gastrointestinal tract
- Thiazolidinediones (TZDs; e.g., pioglitazone): stimulate the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG) → transcription of genes responsible for glucose and lipid metabolism
- Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) and sulfonylurea analogs (e.g., repaglinide): inhibit ATP-dependent potassium channels → cell depolarization and the influx of calcium ions. The increased intracellular calcium stimulates insulin secretion from the pancreas.
- Incretin mimetics/GLP-1 receptor agonists (exenatide): bind to GLP-1 receptors and are resistant to degradation by DPP-4 enzyme → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying
- DPP-4 inhibitors/gliptins (e.g., sitagliptin): indirectly increase the endogenous incretin effect by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme that breaks down GLP-1 → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, delayed gastric emptying

answers.explanation_why: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione known to cause weight gain, both directly and due to fluid retention and edema, making this treatment inappropriate.

Glyburide is a sulfonylurea, which is known to cause weight gain. The need for weight loss in this patient makes this drug undesirable. Moreover, in patients older than 65 years, the use of sulfonylureas with biguanides such as metformin is associated with an increased risk of hypoglycemia.
Acarbose, an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, is not associated with weight loss and is therefore not indicated in the management of this patient.

While dapagliflozin can be used for weight loss in diabetic patients, it is contraindicated in patients with recurrent urinary tract infections (as is the case here) because the glycosuric effect of SGLT-2 inhibitors creates a favorable environment for bacterial colonization of the urinary tract.

Phentermine is an appetite suppressant and can therefore cause weight loss. However, phentermine monotherapy is not used for the management of diabetes mellitus because it does not control hyperglycemia.

Saxagliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor, can be used as an adjunct to metformin in patients with poor glycemic control. However, it does not cause weight loss. Moreover, the glucose-lowering capacity of DPP-4 inhibitors is not as good as some of the other classes of antidiabetic medications. Since this patient has a very high HbA1c of 9.5%, a drug that offers greater glycemic control is needed.

question_text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up visit for elevated blood pressure. Three weeks ago, her blood pressure was 154/78 mm Hg at a routine visit. Subsequent home blood pressure measurements at days 5, 10, and 14 have been: 156/76 mm Hg, 158/80 mm Hg, and 160/80 mm Hg. She has trouble falling asleep but otherwise feels well. She had a cold that resolved with over-the-counter medication 2 weeks ago. She has a history of primary hypothyroidism and a cyst in the right kidney, which was found incidentally 20 years ago. She takes levothyroxine. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 67 kg (148 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m^2. Her pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 162/79 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including thyroid function studies, serum electrolytes, and serum creatinine, are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's blood pressure findings?
content_preview: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up visit for elevated blood pressure. Three weeks ago, her blood pressure was 154/78 mm Hg at a routine visit. Subsequent home blood pressure measurements at days 5, 10, and 14 have been: 156/76 mm Hg, 158/80 mm Hg, and 160/80 mm Hg. She has trouble falling asleep but otherwise feels well. She had a cold that resolved with over-the-counter medication 2 weeks ago. She has a history of primary hypothyroidism and a cyst in the right kidney, which was found incidentally 20 years ago. She takes levothyroxine. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 67 kg (148 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Her pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 162/79 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including thyroid function studies, serum electrolytes, and serum creatinine, are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's blood pressure findings?
hint: This older patient has a wide pulse pressure with elevated systolic blood pressure and normal diastolic pressure.
learning_objective: Recognize decreased arterial compliance as a cause of isolated systolic hypertension.

answers.explanation_why: Increased kidney size is seen in patients with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) and is associated with both decrease in GFR and the development of hypertension. Virtually all patients with ADPKD will develop hypertension. However, it is typically not associated with isolated systolic hypertension. This patient has an isolated cyst that is most likely benign and clinically inconsequential.

Isolated systolic hypertension is caused by decreased arterial elasticity and compliance associated with aging. This condition most commonly occurs in adults aged over 60 years and typically manifests with wide pulse pressure. Patients with isolated systolic hypertension have a high risk of renal dysfunction and cardiovascular events, e.g., myocardial infarction, stroke.

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a common cause of secondary hypertension. Nocturnal periods of hypoxemia and hypercapnia activate the sympathetic nervous system and trigger surges in both systolic and diastolic blood pressure. This patient has no risk factors for OSA (e.g., obesity, smoking, alcohol consumption before sleep), nor does she present with symptoms of this diagnosis (apnea, breathlessness or choking in her sleep, chronic fatigue). The isolated elevation in systolic blood pressure also makes this etiology unlikely.

Most over-the-counter nasal decongestants contain sympathomimetics (e.g., phenylephrine, pseudoephedrine), which induce both local and systemic vasoconstriction. While the use of these medications can cause hypertension, the time course of this patient's presentation and her isolated systolic pressures make this etiology unlikely.

Increase in end-diastolic volume, as seen in aortic regurgitation (AR), causes increased stroke volume and increases the pulse pressure. While this patient does have evidence of a widened pulse pressure, AR alone would not cause hypertension, and a high-pitched, early diastolic murmur would be expected.

An increase in cardiac output secondary to hyperthyroidism (including from excessive levothyroxine) could present with hypertension. However, her recent thyroid studies were normal and she has no other evidence of active thyroid disease.

answers.content: Decrease in renal artery blood flow
answers.explanation_why: Reduced renal artery blood flow would cause activation of the renin-angiotensin system and result in renovascular hypertension. Important causes of reduced renal artery blood flow include renal artery stenosis, external compression of the renal arteries (cyst, tumor, etc), atherosclerosis of the renal arteries, and fibromuscular dysplasia. While atherosclerosis of the renal arteries should be considered given her age, the normal diastolic pressures in this patient make another underlying cause more likely.

A decrease in baroreceptor sensitivity describes the underlying mechanism that results in orthostatic hypotension. Unlike this patient's asymptomatic hypertension, it is characterized by autonomic dysfunction and insufficient counterregulation after postural changes that leads to dizziness and syncope after standing up.

Primary hyperaldosteronism is the most common cause of secondary hypertension and typically presents with hypertension and hypokalemia. The blood pressure seen in primary hyperaldosteronism is frequently markedly elevated, and causes increases in both systolic and diastolic pressures. This woman's isolated systolic hypertension and normal lab values make an alternative etiology more likely.

question_text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Over the past year, he has had problems initiating urination and the sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. He does not drink alcohol. His medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and daily aspirin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a pulsatile abdominal mass at the level of the umbilicus and a bruit on auscultation. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, nontender prostate with rubbery texture. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Over the past year, he has had problems initiating urination and the sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. He does not drink alcohol. His medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and daily aspirin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a pulsatile abdominal mass at the level of the umbilicus and a bruit on auscultation. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, nontender prostate with rubbery texture. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has a history of smoking, hypercholesterolemia, and arterial hypertension and presents with a pulsatile abdominal mass and a bruit on auscultation. These features are suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He does not have abdominal, back, or flank pain, flank ecchymoses, or signs of hemodynamic instability that would suggest rupture.
learning_objective: Recognize abdominal aortic aneurysm, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.content: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
answers.explanation_why: CT angiography of the abdomen and pelvis is appropriate for hemodynamically stable patients with confirmed or suspected symptomatic AAA. This test provides a detailed assessment of the location, size, and extent of the aneurysm, as well as the involvement of branch vessels, presence of a thrombus, and/or rupture. Signs of symptomatic AAA include abdominal, back, or flank pain, flank ecchymoses, and signs of aortic fistula (e.g., heart failure, upper gastrointestinal bleeding), which this patient does not have. A different step in management is more appropriate for asymptomatic AAA.

images.title: Infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm
images.description: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen (transverse section at L3; arterial phase)Infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (5 x 5.5 cm) with peripheral, hypodense thrombotic material (red overlay) and central, hyperdense contrast-enhanced blood (green overlay). A light calcification of the aortic wall is visible (red outline).

answers.explanation_why: Intraoperative catheter arteriography of the aorta can be used to assess the intraluminal space and the presence of a leak after repair of an AAA. However, it has limited use during diagnostic workup, as it only assesses the aortic lumen and cannot distinguish between the vessel wall and a blood clot in an aneurysm (and thus cannot estimate aneurysm size).

A prostate biopsy would be appropriate for a patient with a high suspicion for prostate cancer (e.g., presence of constitutional symptoms, terminal hematuria). However, this patient's urinary symptoms (hesitancy and incomplete voiding), in combination with a digital rectal examination showing a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, nontender prostate with rubbery texture, are consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia. This does not merit urgent management at this time, particularly in this patient with findings suspicious for an AAA.

Elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels are a nonspecific finding in several conditions that affect the prostate, including prostate cancer and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). This patient's urinary symptoms (hesitancy and incomplete voiding), in combination with a digital rectal examination showing a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, nontender prostate with rubbery texture, are consistent with BPH. This does not merit urgent management at this time, particularly in this patient with findings suspicious for an AAA.

Patients with a suspected asymptomatic AAA should undergo abdominal ultrasonography to confirm the diagnosis (dilatation of the aorta ≥ 3 cm) and evaluate the extent of disease, including location and size of the aneurysm, presence of a blood clot, and presence of comorbid iliac artery aneurysms. The sensitivity and specificity of abdominal ultrasonography for AAA are nearly 100%. After the diagnosis is established, management strategies depend on the risk factors for rupture (e.g., aneurysm diameter and rate of expansion).

Renal arteriography is the gold standard for diagnosing renal artery stenosis (RAS), which can also present with an abdominal bruit. However, additional clinical features include treatment-resistant hypertension and hypokalemia (from elevated aldosterone levels) and elevated serum creatinine concentration, which this patient does not have. Other diagnostic methods for workup of RAS include renal ultrasonography, CT angiography, and MR angiography.

question_text: A 65-year-old African American woman comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain. She has had dull lower back pain for several months, which suddenly became sharp in nature after lifting a heavy bucket of water 2 days ago. The pain is midline and does not radiate. She has had frequent vaginal dryness and hot flashes since menopause at the age of 55 years, for which she is on hormone replacement therapy. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and hypothyroidism. Her other medications include hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, and levothyroxine. She attends a 30-minute power walking class twice a week. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. She does not drink alcohol. She does not appear in distress. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); her BMI is 28 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows midline lumbar tenderness. Muscle strength is full and deep tendon reflexes are 2+. Straight leg raising is negative but painful. MRI of the spine shows an acute compression fracture of the L3 vertebral body and an old compression fracture of the L4 vertebra. Which of the following factors in this patient's history is the strongest predisposing factor for her condition?
content_preview: A 65-year-old African American woman comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain. She has had dull lower back pain for several months, which suddenly became sharp in nature after lifting a heavy bucket of water 2 days ago. The pain is midline and does not radiate. She has had frequent vaginal dryness and hot flashes since menopause at the age of 55 years, for which she is on hormone replacement therapy. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and hypothyroidism. Her other medications include hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, and levothyroxine. She attends a 30-minute power walking class twice a week. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. She does not drink alcohol. She does not appear in distress. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); her BMI is 28 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows midline lumbar tenderness. Muscle strength is full and deep tendon reflexes are 2+. Straight leg raising is negative but painful. MRI of the spine shows an acute compression fracture of the L3 vertebral body and an old compression fracture of the L4 vertebra. Which of the following factors in this patient's history is the strongest predisposing factor for her condition?
hint: This patient is presenting with a spontaneous fracture following mild physical exertion (e.g., lifting objects, bending over, or sneezing/coughing). There is also evidence on imaging of an additional, older compression fracture. In a postmenopausal woman, these pathological fractures are often a result of underlying osteoporosis.
learning_objective: Recognize smoking as a risk factor for osteoporosis.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's age at menopause (55 years) is at the upper end of the typical age bracket. Undergoing menopause late in life is a protective factor against osteoporosis because it means that levels of estrogen, which is bone-protective, also drop later.

Weight-bearing exercise is a protective measure against osteoporosis, as it helps to maintain and increase bone mass. This patient regularly goes power-walking (a moderate impact weight-bearing activity), which can also provide functional benefits. Exercise also improves balance, which reduces the risk of falling and fractures.

Smoking is a risk factor for osteoporosis in both premenopausal and postmenopausal women. The strongest risk factor for osteoporosis in this patient is her 40-pack-year history of smoking.

Screening recommendations for osteoporosis vary. The USPSTF recommends routine screening with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry for all women ≥ 65 years of age and for postmenopausal patients < 65 years of age who have one or more risk factors, such as prolonged glucocorticoid use, low BMI (< 21 kg/m^2) or weight < 127 lb, alcohol use, or smoking. Other individuals with risk factors for osteoporosis should be assessed using osteoporosis risk assessment tools to determine the need for screening.
The lower the BMI, the higher the risk of lower bone density (e.g., as a result of malnutrition). This patient's BMI is in the overweight range.

Hormone replacement therapy is the second-line treatment for osteoporosis, with bisphosphonate therapy being the first-line treatment. Hormone replacement therapy exerts a beneficial effect on the bone by inhibiting apoptosis of osteoblasts and decreasing osteoclast function.

Hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism, is a risk factor for osteoporosis because it causes an accelerated metabolic rate and, subsequently, accelerated bone metabolism. While an excess of thyroid hormones due to medication error cannot be ruled out, this patient does not show any symptoms of clinically manifest hyperthyroidism.

The use of certain diuretics (e.g., loop diuretics) is associated with a decline in bone mineral density. However, this patient takes hydrochlorothiazide, which increases serum calcium levels through decreased urinary calcium secretion and has been shown to attenuate bone mineral loss. This patient's diuretic use would not contribute to declining bone mineral density.

In the African American population, the incidence of osteoporosis is statistically lower than in individuals of Asian, Hispanic, and northern European ancestry. It is therefore considered a protective factor against osteoporosis.

question_text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of persistent pain in her right shoulder. The pain is localized to the top of the shoulder and is worse with movement. She has stiffness in the right shoulder that is worse in the morning and usually lasts 20 minutes. The patient reports that she is unable to brush her hair and has stopped going to her regular tennis lessons because of the pain. She does not recall any fall or trauma. When her right arm is passively abducted in an arc, there is pain between 60 and 120 degrees of abduction. When asked to lower the right arm slowly from 90 degrees of abduction, she is unable to hold her arm up and it drops to her side. Passive range of motion is normal. Injection of 5 mL of 1% lidocaine into the right subacromial space does not relieve the pain or improve active range of motion of the right arm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of persistent pain in her right shoulder. The pain is localized to the top of the shoulder and is worse with movement. She has stiffness in the right shoulder that is worse in the morning and usually lasts 20 minutes. The patient reports that she is unable to brush her hair and has stopped going to her regular tennis lessons because of the pain. She does not recall any fall or trauma. When her right arm is passively abducted in an arc, there is pain between 60 and 120 degrees of abduction. When asked to lower the right arm slowly from 90 degrees of abduction, she is unable to hold her arm up and it drops to her side. Passive range of motion is normal. Injection of 5 mL of 1% lidocaine into the right subacromial space does not relieve the pain or improve active range of motion of the right arm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The patient's inability to hold up her arm at 90 degrees of abduction indicates a positive drop arm test.
learning_objective: Recognize a rotator cuff tear.

answers.explanation_why: Cervical radiculopathy is most often caused by spondylosis or a herniated disc in the cervical spine and may cause neck, shoulder, and/or arm pain. However, cervical radiculopathy is typically characterized by radiating pain and paresthesias and pain with passive abduction of the shoulder would not be expected.

Subacromial impingement syndrome, rotator cuff tendinopathy, and rotator cuff tear can all manifest with pain exacerbated by overhead activity. This patient's pain with passive abduction between 60 and 120 degrees suggests impingement and/or rotator cuff disease, and the weakness seen on the drop arm test further narrows the diagnosis to a tear in the supraspinatus muscle of the rotator cuff. It is important to note that the sensitivity and specificity of these physical examination maneuvers are limited, especially with regard to rotator cuff tears; musculoskeletal ultrasound and/or MRI should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

images.title: Rotator cuff tear
images.description: The top image shows a cross-section of the shoulder joint.The bottom images show the progression of a degenerative rotator cuff tear. Repetitive overhead movement and/or anatomical variants of the acromion can result in inflammation of the subacromial bursa and rotator cuff tendons (left). This may progress to degeneration of the bursa and tendons (middle). As a result, the tendon fibers are less elastic and prone to tear, resulting in a rotator cuff tear (right). The supraspinatus tendon is most commonly affected.

answers.explanation_why: Calcific tendinitis of the rotator cuff can also manifest with shoulder pain exacerbated by overhead activity, as seen in this patient. However, this patient's pain with passive movement of the arm, positive drop arm test, and negative lidocaine injection test are not consistent with calcific tendinitis.

Subacromial bursitis is usually due to repetitive overhead movement. It may result in subacromial impingement syndrome and can progress to adhesive capsulitis if movement is limited by pain for a prolonged period of time. Although subacromial bursitis is also characterized by pain with abduction, as seen in this patient, it would not cause weakness.

Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is most common in women > 50 years old and can manifest with shoulder pain and morning stiffness. However, pain from PMR is usually bilateral, diffuse, and accompanied by neck pain and/or pelvic girdle pain. Although this patient complains of morning stiffness, PMR is characterized by prolonged morning stiffness (> 45 minutes). Additionally, this patient's weakness on examination is not consistent with PMR.

Biceps tendinitis is usually due to repetitive lifting or pulling activities. It typically manifests with anterior shoulder pain that radiates down the anterior upper arm. The pain with passive abduction and weakness seen in this patient is not consistent with biceps tendinitis.

Rotator cuff tendinitis is common in individuals who engage in repetitive overhead activities and may also manifest with shoulder pain and weakness exacerbated by activity. The pain associated with rotator cuff tendinitis should resolve with subacromial lidocaine injection. This patient's continued pain and limited range of motion suggest another diagnosis.

Adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder) typically manifests with shoulder pain and limited active range of motion which typically does not improve significantly with a lidocaine injection test. However, passive range of motion is typically restricted in patients with frozen shoulders, making this diagnosis unlikely.

question_text:
An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening confusion. His caretaker at the skilled nursing care facility where he resides says that, since he had a “mini-stroke” 2 weeks ago, he has been a “poor eater”. He has dementia, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Current medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, inhaled budesonide, and pravastatin. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, and cracked lips. Capillary refill time is greater than 3 seconds. Serum studies show:

Glucose
95 mg/dL

Creatinine
1.5 mg/dL

Na^+
155 mEq/L

K^+

3.7 mEq/L

Cl^-

110 mEq/L

HCO_3^-

22 mEq/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening confusion. His caretaker at the skilled nursing care facility where he resides says that, since he had a “mini-stroke” 2 weeks ago, he has been a “poor eater”. He has dementia, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Current medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, inhaled budesonide, and pravastatin. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, and cracked lips. Capillary refill time is greater than 3 seconds. Serum studies show: Glucose 95 mg/dL Creatinine 1.5 mg/dL Na+ 155 mEq/L K+ 3.7 mEq/L Cl- 110 mEq/L HCO3- 22 mEq/L Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: This patient's hypotension, tachycardia, dry mucous membranes, and delayed capillary refill, along with hypernatremia (likely chronic—i.e., developing over the past 2 weeks) and elevated creatinine concentration, should raise concern for hypernatremia with severe hypovolemia. Management involves volume repletion followed by correction of excess sodium with free water.
learning_objective: Choose the initial management for severe hypovolemia with hypernatremia.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous administration of free water, a hypotonic fluid with an osmolality of zero, would lead to rapid lowering of the serum sodium concentration but would not increase the patient's extracellular fluid volume sufficiently to treat his hypovolemia. Rapid correction of hypernatremia carries a risk of causing cerebral edema. Additionally, intravenous infusion of free water can cause hemolysis (due to the large difference in tonicity between free water and red blood cells).

answers.content: Intravenous administration of 5% dextrose in 0.45% saline
answers.explanation_why: Intravenous administration of 5% dextrose in 0.45% saline, a hypertonic fluid, can simultaneously correct a free water deficit (to lower the serum sodium concentration) and increase extracellular fluid volume. However, after the dextrose is rapidly metabolized, the resulting 0.45% saline is hypotonic. Thus, this fluid would not be sufficiently effective for volume repletion in this patient, who presents with signs and symptoms of severe hypovolemia.

Intravenous administration of 0.9% saline, an isotonic fluid, is the best initial step in the management of this patient with severe hypovolemia and hypernatremia. Although normal saline only increases extracellular fluid volume and has a minimal effect on lowering the serum sodium concentration, it should be administered first in a patient with hypovolemic shock to prevent severe complications of volume depletion, such as myocardial and/or cerebral ischemia. After adequate expansion of the extracellular fluid volume, the next step in management is to correct the hypernatremia with a gradual infusion of 5% dextrose in 0.45% saline. Hypotonic saline is preferred in patients with subacute or chronic mild hypovolemic hypernatremia because it corrects the free water deficit without rapidly decreasing the serum osmolality, which can cause cerebral edema.

answers.content: Intravenous administration of 5% dextrose in water
answers.explanation_why: Gradual intravenous administration of 5% dextrose in water is a common initial fluid regimen to lower the serum sodium concentration of patients with euvolemic or hypervolemic hypernatremia. However, following the rapid metabolism of dextrose, the resulting free water is very hypotonic. Thus, it would not increase this patient's extracellular fluid volume sufficiently to treat his hypovolemia.

Intravenous administration of 0.45% saline, a hypotonic fluid, can simultaneously correct a free water deficit (to lower the serum sodium concentration) and increase the patient's extracellular fluid volume. However, hypotonic fluids would not be sufficiently effective for volume repletion in this patient, who presents with signs and symptoms of severe hypovolemia.

question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of multiple red spots on his trunk. He first noticed these several months ago, and some appear to have increased in size. One day ago, he scratched one of these spots, and it bled for several minutes. A photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of multiple red spots on his trunk. He first noticed these several months ago, and some appear to have increased in size. One day ago, he scratched one of these spots, and it bled for several minutes. A photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This middle-aged man presents with bright red papules that bleed with traumatic rupture, which suggests that the lesions are highly vascular.
learning_objective: Recognize cherry angioma.

answers.explanation_why: Bartonella henselae infections cause bacillary angiomatosis, which manifests with vascular proliferations that bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient. Although the lesions of bacillary angiomatosis can manifest with a papular appearance, they also commonly manifest as nodular, pedunculated, or verrucous lesions. In addition, this condition usually develops in patients infected with HIV, of which there is no indication here.

Cherry angiomas are benign, vascular proliferations that commonly develop in adult patients. The diagnosis is typically made based on the clinical appearance of multiple, bright red, dome-shaped papules on the trunk and upper extremities that bleed with trauma and usually blanch with pressure. These lesions manifest more frequently with age and do not regress. Histologically, they are characterized by dilated interconnecting capillaries within the papillary dermis. No treatment is necessary unless lesions become bothersome (e.g., if they catch on clothing, bleed frequently, or are cosmetically unappealing). Options for removal include electrodessication, laser ablation, and surgical excision.

Strawberry angiomas are benign, vascular proliferations that may bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient. However, strawberry angiomas usually develop in the first weeks of life on the head or neck and then involute by 5–8 years of age.

images.title: Infantile hemangioma
images.description: Dome-shaped, crusted, red nodule on the lower left eyelid of a child. Two smaller nodules can be seen above the left eye and on the forehead.These lesions are also referred to as strawberry hemangiomas and are usually located on the head and neck region.

answers.explanation_why: Amelanotic melanoma is a rare variant of melanoma that manifests as a skin-colored or red papule or nodule. Like this patient's papules, amelanotic melanoma may also bleed with trauma. However, this condition typically manifests as a solitary lesion, unlike the multiple lesions seen here.

images.title: Amelanotic melanoma
images.description: A solitary, red nodule on an erythematous base with slight hyperpigmentation on the bottom-right is visible.Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of amelanotic melanoma.

answers.explanation_why: Spider angiomas are benign, vascular lesions. However, they are usually flat and have a characteristic appearance of a central arteriole from which multiple, small vessels radiate outwards, resembling the shape of a spider. Furthermore, they typically develop in patients with hyperestrogenic conditions (e.g., chronic liver failure, pregnancy), of which there is no indication here.

images.title: Spider angioma
images.description: A telangiectasia characterized by a vascular arcade branching out from a central arteriolar point. Spider angiomas can arise during childhood or pregnancy as well as in patients with liver disease or thyrotoxicosis.

answers.explanation_why: Seborrheic keratoses are common, benign skin proliferations with a characteristic greasy, stuck-on appearance. Like this patient's papules, seborrheic keratoses typically develop as multiple lesions on the trunk of adult patients. However, they also commonly develop on the head and extremities. Additionally, these lesions are more commonly brown, tan, or skin-colored and do not bleed with trauma as readily as the lesions seen in this patient.

images.title: Seborrheic keratosis
images.description: Photograph of the upper body of an older adult (dorsal view)Multiple sharply demarcated, darkly pigmented hyperkeratotic papules are visible. The papules have a characteristic stuck on appearance.Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin tumor that arises from keratinocytes and is common in older adults.

answers.explanation_why: Pyogenic granulomas are benign, vascular proliferations that bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient. However, this condition typically manifests as a solitary papule at sites of trauma (particularly on the face, hands, or mucous membranes), unlike the multiple lesions seen here. Moreover, pyogenic granulomas are more prevalent among children, young adults, and pregnant women.

images.title: Pyogenic granuloma
images.description: An ovoid, distinctly erythematous, pedunculated papule that is surrounded by a zone of hyperplastic and hyperkeratotic epidermis (acanthosis) is visible in the center of the photo.

images.title: Capillary hemangioma of the skin (cherry angioma)
images.description: Multiple well-demarcated cherry-red papules are distributed on the skin.This appearance is characteristic of cherry angiomas.

question_text: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of lesions on her left arm. She first noticed them 3 months ago and they have grown larger since that time. She has not had any pain or pruritus in the area. She has a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, which was treated with mastectomy and radiation therapy 27 years ago. Since that time, she has had lymphedema of the left arm. Physical examination shows extensive edema of the left arm. There are four coalescing, firm, purple-blue nodules on the left lateral axillary region and swelling of the surrounding skin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of lesions on her left arm. She first noticed them 3 months ago and they have grown larger since that time. She has not had any pain or pruritus in the area. She has a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, which was treated with mastectomy and radiation therapy 27 years ago. Since that time, she has had lymphedema of the left arm. Physical examination shows extensive edema of the left arm. There are four coalescing, firm, purple-blue nodules on the left lateral axillary region and swelling of the surrounding skin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: A biopsy would likely show collections of slit-like anastomosing vascular channels that are lined by endothelial cells.
learning_objective: Recognize angiosarcoma associated with chronic lymphedema.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic lymphedema is an important risk factor for development of cellulitis and other soft tissue infections, and this patient is certainly at ongoing risk of infection because of her long-standing edema. However, she lacks typical features of cellulitis (e.g., fever, pain, erythema, warmth, or tenderness), which makes an infection very unlikely. Additionally, untreated cellulitis would have progressed more quickly and the timeline of her symptoms is not consistent with this diagnosis.

images.title: Cellulitis in superinfected scabies
images.description: Diffuse, poorly demarcated erythema and edema associated with small, crusted red patches are visible over the left leg.These findings are consistent with cellulitis due to scabies infection.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with thrombophlebitis of a superficial vein typically present with erythema and tenderness along the vein, and the condition can cause congestion of venous vasculature distal to the thrombus. In the upper extremities, it is usually associated with intravenous catheter use. While the nodular appearance and the distribution of this patient's lesions is potentially consistent with a thrombophlebitis, pain and erythema would also be expected. Her history of chronic lymphedema suggests a different diagnosis.

Cutaneous lichen planus typically manifests as purple, polygonal, pruritic papules or plaques on the lower back, wrist, and/or ankles. Patients also present with a lattice-like network of white stripes called Wickham striae. This patient is missing common features of lichen planus, e.g., pruritus and polygonal shape. Moreover, the distribution of her lesions and the fact that they appear in conjunction with chronic lymphedema suggest a different diagnosis.

images.title: Lichen planus
images.description:
Ventral wrist of an adult presenting with a bilateral pruritic rash

Multiple purple-red, well-demarcated, partially confluent polygonal papules can be seen. White reticular lines (Wickham striae) are also visible on the surface of the papules.

The location and appearance of this rash are typical of lichen planus.

answers.explanation_why:
Cutaneous angiosarcoma is a rare malignancy that can occur secondary to chronic lymphedema. The condition classically manifests in women who have undergone radiation therapy with subsequent lymph node sclerosis and/or mastectomy with extensive axillary lymphadenectomy, in which case it is also referred to as Stewart-Treves syndrome. Angiosarcomas typically manifest as multiple violaceous macules, papules, and/or subcutaneous nodules that develop in the area of the breast, chest wall, or upper extremity.

Due to their locally aggressive nature and tendency to metastasize early, angiosarcomas have a poor prognosis.

images.title: Radiation-induced angiosarcoma of the breast
images.description: Right breast of a 56-year-old female patient after receiving radiotherapy for ductal carcinoma in situA purple macule measuring approximately 7 × 5 cm and resembling a hematoma is visible on the previously irradiated lower right quadrant of the right breast. Parts of the macule appear darker and indurated.This type of cutaneous lesion combined with the patient's medical history suggest an angiosarcoma of the breast, which can occur secondary to radiation therapy. Since this is a rare condition, the clinical features seen here are easily mistaken for benign angiomas, small hematomas, or atypical telangiectasia. Histopathological investigation is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

answers.explanation_why: Melanoma should always be considered in the differential for a growing, asymmetric, hyperpigmented skin lesion. The amelanotic subtype can present as pink or even skin-colored nodules. While this patient is at increased risk (age, previous skin cancer) for development of melanoma, the presence of chronic lymphedema suggests a different diagnosis.

images.title: Amelanotic melanoma
images.description: A solitary, red nodule on an erythematous base with slight hyperpigmentation on the bottom-right is visible.Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of amelanotic melanoma.

answers.explanation_why: Human herpesvirus 8 can cause Kaposi sarcoma, which manifests as purple-colored or brownish skin plaques of the extremities that can progress to deeper, more nodular, and, occasionally, ulcerative, lesions. However, the lesions occur in patients who are significantly immunocompromised (e.g., AIDS, transplant recipients). The absence of severe immunocompromise in this woman makes this diagnosis highly unlikely.

images.title: Kaposi sarcoma
images.description: Violaceous nodules and papules are visible beside several black-crusted plaques on the lower leg of this patient with Kaposi sarcoma.

question_text: Six days after undergoing surgical repair of a hip fracture, a previously healthy 79-year-old woman is agitated and confused. She is unarousable during the day, but then is awake and impulsive during the night, requiring frequent reorientation. Her husband says that she usually drinks one to two glasses of wine weekly. Her only current medication is oxycodone for pain. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is distressed and oriented to person but not to place or time. Neurologic examination shows inattentiveness but no focal deficits. Urine dipstick is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her current condition?
content_preview: Six days after undergoing surgical repair of a hip fracture, a previously healthy 79-year-old woman is agitated and confused. She is unarousable during the day, but then is awake and impulsive during the night, requiring frequent reorientation. Her husband says that she usually drinks one to two glasses of wine weekly. Her only current medication is oxycodone for pain. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is distressed and oriented to person but not to place or time. Neurologic examination shows inattentiveness but no focal deficits. Urine dipstick is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her current condition?
hint: This condition is characterized by waxing and waning attentiveness.
learning_objective: Recognize delirium in postoperative elderly patients.

answers.explanation_why: Dementia is a common cause of chronic, sustained altered mental status in elderly patients. However, the sudden onset and waning pattern of this patient's symptoms are not consistent with dementia.

Alcohol withdrawal is an important diagnosis to consider in a hospitalized patient with altered mental status, and can manifest with anxiety, psychomotor agitation, insomnia, alcoholic hallucinosis, and/or delirium tremens. This patient has been in the hospital for at least six days, which is beyond the typical timeframe of alcohol withdrawal symptom onset. Furthermore, her normal vital signs, lack of a tremor, and minimal alcohol use make this diagnosis unlikely.

Opioid intoxication is an important cause to consider in a patient with altered mental status who is taking oxycodone. Classic signs of opioid intoxication include somnolence and respiratory depression, whereas this patient has a normal respiratory rate and episodically altered sensorium with periods of hyperactivity.

Delirium occurs postoperatively in approx. 10–50% of elderly patients who undergo surgical hip fracture repair and is characterized by the acute onset of waxing and waning altered mental status. This patient has multiple risk factors for delirium, including advanced age, current hospitalization, recent surgery, and administration of opioids. Inadequate analgesia has also been implicated in the development of delirium in postoperative patients.

Schizophrenia is typically characterized by hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thought processes, and/or negative symptoms of psychosis. The acute onset and episodic, waning nature of this patient's symptoms are not consistent with schizophrenia. Furthermore, a new diagnosis of schizophrenia in this age group would be highly unusual.

Urinary tract infections (UTI) can present with altered mental status, especially in elderly patients. This patient's extended hospitalization increases her risk for UTI. However, the unremarkable urinary dipstick and lack of symptoms, such as dysuria, urgency, or frequency makes this diagnosis unlikely.

question_text: An 82-year-old man with Alzheimer disease is brought to the physician by his daughter because of extensive bruising on his arms. He lives in an assisted living facility. Physical examination shows large ecchymoses across both forearms and upper arms in varying stages of healing. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.7 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 78 μm^3, and platelet count is 180,000/mm^3. Coagulation studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's bruises?
content_preview: An 82-year-old man with Alzheimer disease is brought to the physician by his daughter because of extensive bruising on his arms. He lives in an assisted living facility. Physical examination shows large ecchymoses across both forearms and upper arms in varying stages of healing. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.7 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 78 μm3, and platelet count is 180,000/mm3. Coagulation studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's bruises?
hint: This patient's history of dementia and residing in an assisted living facility are risk factors for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize nonaccidental trauma as a cause of bruising in elderly patients.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient's bruises on the upper extremity are most likely caused by nonaccidental trauma due to older adult abuse. Older adults, especially those with dementia, are at increased risk for abuse. Older adult abuse is most commonly perpetrated by caregivers (e.g., spouse, nursing home staff) and can be physical, psychological, or financial, or take the form of neglect. Physicians are legally and ethically obligated to report suspected abuse. When a physician suspects abuse, they should privately speak with the affected patient, ask for further information, and offer assistance.

Finally, this patient's decreased MCV and hemoglobin are consistent with microcytic anemia (e.g., due to insufficient iron intake) but do not indicate an increased bleeding risk.

Bruising due to platelet aggregation inhibition can be seen in patients on antiplatelet agents, and most commonly occurs in women > 60 years old who have recently started antiplatelet therapy (duration < 1 month). This patient with Alzheimer disease has a normal platelet count and coagulation studies, bruises in different stages of healing (localized to the upper extremity), and no history of antiplatelet use, all of which should raise concern for a different etiology.

Intravascular coagulation with fibrinolysis is consistent with a consumptive coagulopathy, such as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). This patient with bruises localized to the upper extremities, normal platelet count and coagulation studies, and no evidence of systemic disease (e.g., due to sepsis or malignancy) is unlikely to have DIC.

Increased activity of epidermal melanocytes is seen in solar lentigo. Solar lentigines are commonly found on sun-exposed areas including the back of the hands, forehead, and scalp, but not the upper arms. The affected skin shows solitary or multiple dark, sharply demarcated, pigmented macules due to melanin, rather than purple/reddish poorly demarcated lesions due to hemoglobin breakdown.

Vitamin K deficiency causes large ecchymoses, which are seen here, and deep tissue bleeding (e.g., hemarthrosis, hematomas). However, vitamin K deficiency is unlikely in this patient with normal coagulation studies.

question_text: One week after admission to the hospital for an extensive left middle cerebral artery stroke, a 91-year-old woman is unable to communicate, walk, or safely swallow food. She has been without nutrition for the duration of her hospitalization. She has advanced vascular dementia. The patient's sister requests placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube for nutrition. The patient's husband declines the intervention. There is no living will. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action by the physician?
content_preview: One week after admission to the hospital for an extensive left middle cerebral artery stroke, a 91-year-old woman is unable to communicate, walk, or safely swallow food. She has been without nutrition for the duration of her hospitalization. She has advanced vascular dementia. The patient's sister requests placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube for nutrition. The patient's husband declines the intervention. There is no living will. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action by the physician?
hint: If a patient lacks decision-making capacity, it is paramount that decisions be made based on what the patient would have wanted.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate action when addressing surrogate decision-making without a living will.

answers.explanation_why: Consulting the hospital ethics committee is appropriate if there is a complicated, unresolved ethical dilemma in which the stakeholders would benefit from the involvement of professionals (physicians, nurses, social workers, bioethicists) with advanced training in facilitating difficult decision-making. However, an ethics consult is more appropriate if there is a conflict between the four core bioethics principles of autonomy, beneficence, nonmaleficence, and justice. Disagreements between family members are routine in medical care, and the team should first attempt another course of action.
Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is not indicated in this patient because she can still receive enteral nutrition (e.g., PEG).

A family meeting with the patient's husband, sister, and members of the healthcare team could provide clarification as to what the patient would have desired had she been able to make the decision herself. Although the patient's sister and husband currently disagree, a discussion about the patient's own goals and values could encourage family agreement and facilitate better surrogate decision-making. If a resolution of the disagreement is not possible, the husband will most likely have the final say as his wife's next of kin.

The role of PEG placement in patients with dementia is controversial; studies have found no survival benefit or increase in quality of life in patients with advanced dementia who received PEG feeding compared with no tube feeding.

A request for a court-appointed guardian for a patient who lacks the capacity to make medical decisions is typically made when there is no medical power of attorney or next-of-kin available to serve as surrogate decision maker. In this scenario, the patient has multiple family members involved. Another approach would better facilitate reaching a decision in the best interests of the patient.

answers.content: Transfer to a physician specialized in hospice care
answers.explanation_why: Hospice care is not indicated here, as there is no suggestion that the patient is terminally ill and expected to live less than six months.

question_text: An 81-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter after he was found wandering on the street. For the past several months, he often has a blank stare for several minutes at a time. On several occasions, he has claimed to have seen strangers in the house who were not present. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. He was diagnosed with a condition 3 months ago for which he was prescribed carbidopa-levodopa. His symptoms have not improved. His blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. He has short-term memory deficits and appears confused and disheveled. Examination shows bilateral muscle rigidity and resting tremor in his upper extremities. He has a slow gait with short steps. Microscopic examination of the cortex of a patient with the same condition is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: An 81-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter after he was found wandering on the street. For the past several months, he often has a blank stare for several minutes at a time. On several occasions, he has claimed to have seen strangers in the house who were not present. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. He was diagnosed with a condition 3 months ago for which he was prescribed carbidopa-levodopa. His symptoms have not improved. His blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. He has short-term memory deficits and appears confused and disheveled. Examination shows bilateral muscle rigidity and resting tremor in his upper extremities. He has a slow gait with short steps. Microscopic examination of the cortex of a patient with the same condition is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Histopathological findings show intracellular eosinophilic inclusions composed of α-synuclein. This finding with visual hallucinations is a common combination in this patient's condition.
learning_objective: Recognize dementia with Lewy bodies.

answers.explanation_why: Histopathological findings of intracellular Lewy bodies in the cortex are found in patients with dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) and Parkinson disease. Dementia, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism with a poor response to levodopa are typical of DLB. Unlike Parkinson disease, dementia onset in DLB occurs before or alongside motor dysfunction. DLB is a Parkinson-plus syndrome and the second most common form of neurodegenerative dementia.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a prion disease that causes dementia and visual hallucinations, as seen in this patient. However, the disease progresses extremely rapidly and other findings, such as myoclonus and seizures, would be expected as well. In addition, the biopsy shown in this case does not show prions.

Patients with vascular dementia may present with dementia and loss of cognitive function (e.g., disorientation), but the onset is typically abrupt with stepwise deterioration. Moreover, vascular dementia does not cause visual hallucinations, and focal neurologic deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, dysarthria) would be expected. Vascular dementia also does not explain the biopsy findings.

images.title: Multi-infarct dementia
images.description: Frontal section of the brain at the level of the optical chiasma (dashed blue overlay) showing hemorrhage and infarction (examples indicated by green circles) in the region of the basal ganglia. As a result, there is reduced demarcation of the internal capsule (dashed white outline) between the caudate (yellow overlay) and lentiform nuclei (blue overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Histopathological findings of intracellular Lewy bodies in the cortex are found in patients with Parkinson disease. Although parkinsonism and dementia are typical features of Parkinson disease, this patient's neurocognitive and motor symptoms began within months of each other. In Parkinson disease, dementia occurs in advanced disease, usually several years after the onset of motor symptoms. In addition, this patient's motor symptoms have not responded to levodopa.

Frontotemporal dementia also causes dementia and parkinsonism. However, unlike in this patient, these findings typically manifest in the late stages of disease. Instead, early changes in behavior and personality (e.g., irritability, failure to observe social etiquette) and primary progressive aphasia, which are cardinal signs of frontotemporal dementia, would be expected. Biopsy findings of frontotemporal dementia would also show inclusions of hyperphosphorylated tau proteins (called Pick bodies) or ubiquitinated TDP-43. In addition, frontotemporal dementia typically manifests between the ages of 40–60.

images.title: Pick bodies
images.description: Photomicrograph of an anterior cingulate cortex tissue specimen (immunohistochemistry for tau-protein; 100x magnification, insert 600x magnification)There is a decrease in neuron density as an expression of neurodegeneration. Multiple positively stained (brown) paranuclear inclusion bodies are seen (example in insert).These pick bodies (intracytoplasmic inclusions of tau fibrils) are seen in a subtype of frontotemporal lobar degeneration.

images.title: Lewy body and Lewy neurite
images.description: Photomicrographs of a substantia nigra tissue sample (A: H&E stain, 500x magnification; B: immunochemical α-synuclein stain, 400x magnification)Image A: An eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion (Lewy body; blue overlay) is visible inside a neuron. There is a large accumulation of neuromelanin (brown granules; green overlay).Image B: A neurite staining positive for α-synuclein is visible in the center of the image (Lewy neurite; yellow overlay).Lewy bodies and neurites are seen in various neurodegenerative disorders, e.g., Parkinson's disease and dementia with Lewy bodies.

question_text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because he frequently misplaces his personal belongings and becomes easily confused. His daughter mentions that his symptoms have progressively worsened for the past one year. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. He vividly recalls memories from his childhood but can only recall one of three objects presented to him after 5 minutes. His affect is normal. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by damage to which of the following?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because he frequently misplaces his personal belongings and becomes easily confused. His daughter mentions that his symptoms have progressively worsened for the past one year. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. He vividly recalls memories from his childhood but can only recall one of three objects presented to him after 5 minutes. His affect is normal. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by damage to which of the following?
hint: Short-term memory loss is often the earliest sign of Alzheimer disease, the most common cause of progressive dementia in the United States.
learning_objective: Recognize Alzheimer disease, and recall the brain structures involved in memory formation.

answers.explanation_why: The substantia nigra is part of the basal ganglia and plays a role in initiation of voluntary movements. Damage to this region occurs in Parkinson disease, which presents with bradykinesia, tremor, and/or rigidity. This patient has memory deficits, which are unlikely to be caused by damage to the substantia nigra.

The amygdala is a structure of the limbic system that plays a role in the processing of emotions. Involvement of the amygdala in Alzheimer disease causes emotional lability, depression, and/or anhedonia. Damage to a different structure would more likely explain the short-term memory loss in this patient with a normal affect.
answers.explanation_but: Bilateral damage to the amygdala results in Klüver-Bucy syndrome, which is characterized by emotional lability, anxiety, hypersexuality, hyperorality, and hyperphagia.

answers.explanation_why: The ventral posterolateral nucleus is a structure of the thalamus involved in relaying sensory input from the spinothalamic tract and dorsal column to the primary somatosensory cortex. This nucleus does not play a role in memory formation and is not affected in early Alzheimer disease. The medial dorsal nucleus of the thalamus and the anterior thalamic nucleus are involved in memory formation.

The nucleus accumbens is a basal forebrain structure that has a role in the reward pathway. This structure does not play a major role in semantic (factual) recall. Degeneration of other basal forebrain structures such as the nucleus basalis of Meynert can cause memory loss and cognitive decline in Alzheimer disease.
answers.explanation_but: Decreased GABA secretion by the nucleus accumbens is seen in Huntington disease and anxiety disorders.

answers.explanation_why: The earliest sites of neurodegeneration in Alzheimer disease are structures in the medial temporal lobe such as the hippocampus and parahippocampal cortex, which are critical for memory formation.

The superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere contains the primary auditory cortex and the Wernicke area. Damage to this structure would result in sensory aphasia. Early Alzheimer disease can cause atrophy of the medial temporal lobe structures but typically has little impact on the superior temporal gyrus.

question_text: A 66-year-old woman with hypertension comes to the physician because of crampy, dull abdominal pain and weight loss for 1 month. The pain is located in the epigastric region and typically occurs within the first hour after eating. She has had a 7-kg (15.4-lb) weight loss in the past month. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Physical examination shows a scaphoid abdomen and diffuse tenderness to palpation. Laboratory studies including carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9), carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and lipase concentrations are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 66-year-old woman with hypertension comes to the physician because of crampy, dull abdominal pain and weight loss for 1 month. The pain is located in the epigastric region and typically occurs within the first hour after eating. She has had a 7-kg (15.4-lb) weight loss in the past month. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Physical examination shows a scaphoid abdomen and diffuse tenderness to palpation. Laboratory studies including carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9), carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and lipase concentrations are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: A 66-year-old woman with multiple atherosclerotic risk factors (hypertension, smoking) who presents with chronic postprandial pain, food avoidance, and unintentional weight loss, should raise concern for chronic mesenteric ischemia.
learning_objective: Recognize chronic mesenteric ischemia due to celiac artery narrowing.

answers.explanation_why: Slow progressive narrowing of the celiac artery secondary to atherosclerosis can lead to chronic mesenteric ischemia, which manifests with the signs and symptoms seen in this patient. She likely also has atherosclerotic narrowing of the SMA or IMA. If only one main artery is affected, collateral connections will typically compensate for the reduced flow and the patient will often be asymptomatic.

images.title: Arterial supply of the gastrointestinal tract
images.description:
The gastrointestinal tract is supplied by the three anterior branches of the abdominal aorta.
- Celiac artery: artery of the foregut (lower esophagus, stomach, proximal duodenum, liver, gall bladder, pancreas)
- Superior mesenteric artery: artery of the midgut (distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, cecum, ascending colon, proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon)
- Inferior mesenteric artery: artery of the hindgut (distal third of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, rectum, anal canal proximal to the pectinate line)

answers.content: Malignant mass at the head of the pancreas
answers.explanation_why: Pancreatic cancer causes abdominal pain and weight loss, as in this patient, and smoking is also a known risk factor. However, this patient lacks other common signs of pancreatic cancer, including nausea and vomiting. Pancreatic cancer involving the head typically also causes obstructive jaundice, which is not present. Lastly, laboratory values typically elevated in patients with pancreatic cancer, including CA 19-9, CEA, and lipase, are all normal. This combination of findings makes pancreatic cancer an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms.

images.title: Pancreatic head cancer
images.description: Tumors of the pancreatic head may obstruct the extrahepatic bile ducts and pancreatic duct. Bile duct obstruction results in Courvoisier sign (painless jaundice plus an enlarged, nontender gallbladder on palpation), pale stools, dark urine, and pruritus. Pancreatic duct obstruction results in exocrine pancreatic insufficiency and steatorrhea. The obstruction-related dilation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct demonstrates as the double-duct sign on radiology.

answers.explanation_why: Gastric outlet obstruction results from narrowing of the gastric pylorus and presents with postprandial pain and weight loss, as seen in this patient. However, she lacks the vomiting that is seen in nearly all patients with gastric outlet obstruction, making this diagnosis unlikely.

answers.content: Embolus in the superior mesenteric artery
answers.explanation_why: Arterial thromboembolism to the superior mesenteric artery causes acute mesenteric ischemia. This presents with sudden, severe, periumbilical pain, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The pain is classically disproportionate to abdominal examination findings. Instead, this patient presents with chronic mesenteric ischemia and has a gradual onset of symptoms associated with post-prandial pain and weight loss.

answers.content: Focal wall thickening in the colon
answers.explanation_why: Focal wall thickening in the colon can represent a colonic mass or infectious colitis. Although both could potentially cause weight loss, these diagnoses do not explain the postprandial pain seen in this patient. Furthermore, she lacks other typical symptoms for colonic mass or infectious colitis, such as hematochezia.

answers.content: Decreased motility of gastric smooth muscle
answers.explanation_why: Decreased motility of gastric smooth muscle causes gastroparesis, a condition that presents with postprandial pain and in severe cases, weight loss. However, this patient lacks other typical symptoms of gastroparesis, including nausea and vomiting. She also lacks risk factors such as diabetes or a history of upper GI surgery, making this diagnosis unlikely.
