question_text: A 74-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively blurry vision. About 3 years ago, she stopped using her reading glasses for several months because her eyesight improved temporarily. She is a landscape painter. For the past year, she has mostly been working inside her studio instead of outside her house. She comments that “the bright sunlight makes me see halos around lights and then I cannot distinguish between the nuances of colors anymore.” The patient recently stopped driving at night because she no longer trusts her eyes. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, asthma, and atrial fibrillation. She has smoked 1.5 packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years and occasionally drinks 1–2 glasses of wine. Her medications include metformin, albuterol, budesonide-formoterol, digoxin, and rivaroxaban. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min and irregular, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/80 in both eyes. On fundoscopic examination, the retina is hard to visualize and the red reflex appears darkened. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 74-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively blurry vision. About 3 years ago, she stopped using her reading glasses for several months because her eyesight improved temporarily. She is a landscape painter. For the past year, she has mostly been working inside her studio instead of outside her house. She comments that “the bright sunlight makes me see halos around lights and then I cannot distinguish between the nuances of colors anymore.” The patient recently stopped driving at night because she no longer trusts her eyes. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, asthma, and atrial fibrillation. She has smoked 1.5 packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years and occasionally drinks 1–2 glasses of wine. Her medications include metformin, albuterol, budesonide-formoterol, digoxin, and rivaroxaban. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min and irregular, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/80 in both eyes. On fundoscopic examination, the retina is hard to visualize and the red reflex appears darkened. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's bilateral progressive, painless loss of vision, halos around lights, reduced night vision, and temporary near vision improvement, along with darkening of the red reflex and obscuration of the ocular fundus indicate bilateral cataracts. Risk factors for cataract formation include advanced age, diabetes mellitus, and smoking, all of which are seen here.
learning_objective: Recognize bilateral cataracts, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Intravitreous injection of bevacizumab is the first-line treatment for patients with exudative age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD), which can cause progressive and painless loss of vision. However, wet AMD affects one eye first rather than both eyes, and progresses over weeks to months rather than years. Additionally, this condition does not cause a temporary improvement in near vision, darkening of the red reflex, and obscuration of the ocular fundus. Finally, the visual impairment is usually central or pericentral and patients generally present with metamorphopsia and scotomas, none of which are seen here.

Surgical replacement of the lens is the treatment of choice for patients with cataracts with significant cataract-related visual impairment, as seen in this patient. The standard surgical technique is extracapsular cataract extraction. There is no pharmacological therapy available except in galactosemia, in which the cataract is reversible when following a galactose-free diet. Untreated cataracts eventually lead to complete blindness.

images.title: Mature cataract
images.description: Slit-lamp examination of the left eyeThere is cloudy white opacification of the entire lens (green overlay). As a result, the red reflex is absent.An additional finding is a posterior synechia (arrow), as the superior part of the pupil is not completely round.

answers.explanation_why: Laser photocoagulation of the retina is used in the treatment of both proliferative (PDR) and nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR). Diabetic retinopathy is the most common cause of visual impairment in patients aged 25–74 years in the US and can also cause bilateral, progressive, painless vision loss. However, diabetic retinopathy is not associated with the visualization of halos around lights, a temporary improvement in near vision, or the darkening of the red reflex. Characteristic fundoscopic findings of PDR include preretinal neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage, retinal detachment, and fibrovascular proliferation, while characteristic fundoscopic findings of NPDR include hard exudates and macular ischemia.

Topical latanoprost is the preferred first-line treatment for patients with open-angle glaucoma, which also causes bilateral, progressive vision loss that can be associated with halos around lights. Advanced age, diabetes mellitus, and steroid use, all of which are seen in this patient, are known risk factors for open-angle glaucoma. However, a temporary improvement in near vision and a fundoscopy showing darkening of the red reflex and obscuration of ocular fundus are not expected. Additionally, in patients with open-angle glaucoma, the visual field loss progresses from peripheral to central over time, which is not seen here.

answers.content: Administration of topical pilocarpine and timolol
answers.explanation_why: Topical pilocarpine and timolol are the first-line treatment for acute angle-closure glaucoma, which can cause blurred vision associated with halos around lights and manifest with a hard to visualize retina (due to corneal opacification). However, acute angle-closure glaucoma is usually unilateral rather than bilateral, and patients typically present with a red, painful eye with a fixed pupil, which is not seen here. Additionally, the visual impairment has a sudden onset rather than a progressive course. Furthermore, beta blockers should be avoided in this patient with asthma because of the risk of bronchoconstriction.

Blurred vision is a common side effect of digoxin therapy, affecting 1–10% of patients taking this cardiac glycoside. However, digoxin therapy is not associated with halos around lights, temporary improvement in near vision, darkening of the red reflex, or obscuration of the ocular fundus. Other visual side effects of digoxin therapy include central scotomas, photopsia, diplopia, and dyschromatopsia. Finally, further side effects (gastrointestinal, neurological) would be expected in the case of digoxin toxicity.

question_text: An 81-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She lives in a senior living facility in the Midwestern United States. There have been several cases of heavy metal poisoning through drinking water in her state, and she is concerned about potential exposure to toxic substances. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 153 cm (5 ft) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. Pulse is 76/min and regular, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Which of the following neurologic examination findings in this patient would necessitate immediate investigation?
content_preview: An 81-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She lives in a senior living facility in the Midwestern United States. There have been several cases of heavy metal poisoning through drinking water in her state, and she is concerned about potential exposure to toxic substances. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 153 cm (5 ft) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Pulse is 76/min and regular, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Which of the following neurologic examination findings in this patient would necessitate immediate investigation?
hint: This finding can be observed on examination of the cranial nerves.
learning_objective: Recognize abnormal neurologic examination findings, and recall conditions that necessitate immediate investigation.

answers.explanation_why: High-frequency, progressive, bilateral hearing loss in an older patient suggests presbycusis, which affects more than 50% of individuals at the age of 75 years, with increasing prevalence in older age groups. This condition is caused by age-related damage to hair cells at the base of the cochlea. Although otoscopy and audiometry would eventually be indicated to establish the diagnosis, high-frequency hearing loss is an expected finding in older patients and does not require immediate investigation.

Vertical or rotatory nystagmus on neurologic examination is considered abnormal in all age groups and warrants immediate investigation. Causes for vertical nystagmus include vestibular conditions (e.g., anterior and posterior semicircular canal BPPV), severe alcohol intoxication, drug side effects (e.g., phencyclidine, lithium, carbamazepine, phenytoin), Wernicke encephalopathy, and CNS lesions (e.g., bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia in multiple sclerosis, cerebellar lesions). In contrast, although horizontal nystagmus is most frequently pathological, it can occur physiologically (e.g., end-gaze nystagmus) in all age groups. Other neurophthalmological findings considered normal in older patients (especially those aged over 80 years) are sluggish convergence, sluggish pupillary reflex, decreased upward gaze (while lateral and downward movements usually remain intact), and impaired accommodation (presbyopia).

images.title: Characterization of nystagmus by direction
images.description: In jerk nystagmus, there is a slow drift phase followed by a fast corrective phase. The name of the nystagmus is determined by the direction of movement in the fast phase (left horizontal, right horizontal, downbeat, upbeat, clockwise, or counterclockwise).

answers.content: Decreased vibration sensation in the great toe
answers.explanation_why: A decreased sensation of vibration in the distal lower extremities is common in older patients. It can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of distal sensory axons and does not require immediate investigation if it is an isolated finding. Further diagnostic workup is indicated if the decreased sensation of vibration occurs alongside additional signs and symptoms (e.g., signs of ischemia, ulcers, loss of reflexes, concomitant involvement of upper extremities, changes to other types of sensation).

Decreased sense of smell (hyposmia) is a common finding in older patients, affecting more than 60% of individuals aged ≥ 80 years. This finding can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of olfactory neurons. The isolated finding of hyposmia/anosmia in an older patient does not require immediate investigation. Hyposmia in patients < 60 years of age should raise concern for an underlying disease (e.g., Parkinson disease) and further diagnostic workup might be indicated.

Diminished or absent ankle jerk reflexes are a common finding in older patients. This finding can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of distal sensory axons, which results in diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes. The isolated finding of absent ankle jerk reflexes in an older patient does not require immediate investigation. Further diagnostic workup is indicated if this finding occurs with additional signs and symptoms, e.g., muscle weakness, sensory changes, constitutional symptoms, asymmetry, back pain.

question_text: A 79-year-old man is brought to the physician because of abdominal pain for the past 5 days. He had a bowel movement 6 hours ago that was watery but not bloody. He has not had any unexpected weight changes. He lives in a nursing care facility and has been bedridden for the past 4 years. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and vascular dementia. His medications are amlodipine, lisinopril, insulin, and aspirin. He has had no recent changes in his diet. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is mildly distended, and there is mild tenderness to palpation diffusely. There are palpable masses in the lower abdomen. Bowel sounds are decreased. Digital rectal examination shows hard stool. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 79-year-old man is brought to the physician because of abdominal pain for the past 5 days. He had a bowel movement 6 hours ago that was watery but not bloody. He has not had any unexpected weight changes. He lives in a nursing care facility and has been bedridden for the past 4 years. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and vascular dementia. His medications are amlodipine, lisinopril, insulin, and aspirin. He has had no recent changes in his diet. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is mildly distended, and there is mild tenderness to palpation diffusely. There are palpable masses in the lower abdomen. Bowel sounds are decreased. Digital rectal examination shows hard stool. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Diffuse abdominal pain and distention, palpable masses in the lower abdomen, and hard stool on digital rectal examination are consistent with fecal impaction. Patients with fecal impaction can develop paradoxical diarrhea with leakage of watery stool past the impacted segment of the rectum.
learning_objective: Recognize fecal impaction, and choose the most appropriate initial intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Exploratory laparotomy is rarely required in patients with fecal impaction. It can be considered if there are signs of impending bowel perforation or ischemia (e.g., severe abdominal tenderness), which is not the case here. A more conservative treatment modality should be tried first.
A regular physical therapy regimen is an effective strategy for preventing the recurrence of fecal impaction but will not resolve an acute case of fecal impaction.

answers.content: Place a nasogastric tube and administer polyethylene glycol
answers.explanation_why: Administration of polyethylene glycol through a nasogastric tube is unlikely to clear a distal fecal impaction. However, after disimpaction via another method, it may be considered for softening the stool and facilitating evacuation of the colon.

Colonoscopy with a snare can be used to clear a fecal impaction in the distal colon via fragmentation. However, this method is only used in cases in which more conservative methods of treatment have failed to disimpact the bowel. A different treatment modality should be tried before considering colonoscopy in this patient.

Fecal impaction is most commonly seen in older adults with reduced mobility, such as this patient. The initial management of fecal impaction involves manual fragmentation of the compacted feces. This procedure can be followed with warm water or mineral oil enemas to soften the stool and facilitate further evacuation of the colon. Once the fecal impaction is treated, lifestyle modifications such as a high-fiber diet and physical therapy should be initiated, together with a maintenance bowel regimen (e.g., osmotic laxative therapy) to prevent recurrence. Untreated fecal impaction can lead to complications such as intestinal obstruction, intestinal perforation, stercoral ulcers, stercoral colitis, and fistulas.

Digital rectal examination may not detect a fecal impaction if the location is in the proximal rectum or sigmoid colon. In these cases, an x-ray of the abdomen may show large, speckled, low-density opacities within distended loops of the large bowel and rectum.

question_text: A 55-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well besides a vague sensation of vaginal fullness for the last 5 months. Upon questioning, she also reports occasional mild lower back pain that worsens with prolonged standing or lifting. She does not have urinary or fecal incontinence. Ten years ago, she underwent a mastectomy for intraductal carcinoma of the right breast and has been cancer-free since then. All of her children were delivered vaginally without complications. Her last menstrual period was 3 years ago. She is sexually active with her husband only. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (188 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination during Valsalva maneuver shows visible protrusion of the cervix proximal to the level of the hymen into the vagina. There is no urinary leakage upon straining. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 55-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well besides a vague sensation of vaginal fullness for the last 5 months. Upon questioning, she also reports occasional mild lower back pain that worsens with prolonged standing or lifting. She does not have urinary or fecal incontinence. Ten years ago, she underwent a mastectomy for intraductal carcinoma of the right breast and has been cancer-free since then. All of her children were delivered vaginally without complications. Her last menstrual period was 3 years ago. She is sexually active with her husband only. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (188 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination during Valsalva maneuver shows visible protrusion of the cervix proximal to the level of the hymen into the vagina. There is no urinary leakage upon straining. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Vaginal fullness, lower back pain associated with prolonged standing, and protrusion of the cervix during Valsalva maneuver suggest uterine prolapse, a type of pelvic organ prolapse (POP). Multiple vaginal deliveries and obesity are risk factors for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize uterine prolapse, and choose the most appropriate initial management step.

answers.explanation_why: Hysterectomy, typically performed with concomitant transvaginal apical suspension, is a treatment option for POP with severe symptoms (e.g., urinary or defecatory dysfunction) and/or after unsuccessful first-line treatment of mild POP. This patient is only mildly symptomatic and has not yet received any treatment for her uterine prolapse. Therefore, a different intervention is more appropriate at this time.

Topical estrogen is the first-line treatment option for moderate to severe atrophic vaginitis, which commonly occurs in menopause and may be concomitant to POP. Atrophic vaginitis typically manifests with vaginal soreness, dyspareunia, and vaginal discharge, none of which are seen in this patient. Topical estrogen is not indicated in patients with POP who do not have concomitant atrophic vaginitis.

Reassurance and observation without treatment are indicated for patients with asymptomatic pelvic organ prolapse. This patient has a sensation of vaginal fullness and mild lower back pain due to uterine prolapse, which can be improved through treatment.

Colporrhaphy is a highly effective treatment option for some types of POP, such as cystocele and rectocele, both of which can manifest with vaginal fullness and back pain. However, cystocele and rectocele are typically characterized by urinary and defecatory dysfunction, respectively, neither of which are seen here. This patient's clinical and physical examination findings are consistent with uterine prolapse, for which colporrhaphy is not indicated.

Conservative treatment is the best initial step for managing patients with mildly symptomatic POP in the absence of urinary or defecatory dysfunction. The most commonly used conservative methods include vaginal pessaries and pelvic floor muscle training (e.g., Kegel exercises). Patients should also be advised on lifestyle modifications that help prevent the progression of POP through the reduction of intraabdominal pressure, such as weight loss, smoking cessation (to prevent chronic cough), and constipation treatment (to prevent straining). If the symptoms of POP persist or worsen despite conservative management, surgical treatment is indicated. Asymptomatic POP requires no treatment.

question_text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with lower abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. He describes the pain as an 8/10 in intensity with no radiation. He denies fever or chills. He has not passed urine since the early morning. He took oral diphenhydramine last night because he had difficulty falling asleep. He has a history of hypertension. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily but quit 1 year ago. Current medications include amlodipine. He appears restless. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 134/90 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a tender palpable suprapubic mass. Digital rectal examination shows a mildly enlarged, nontender prostate without any palpable masses. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A bedside ultrasound scan shows a large anechoic mass in the lower abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with lower abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. He describes the pain as an 8/10 in intensity with no radiation. He denies fever or chills. He has not passed urine since the early morning. He took oral diphenhydramine last night because he had difficulty falling asleep. He has a history of hypertension. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily but quit 1 year ago. Current medications include amlodipine. He appears restless. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 134/90 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a tender palpable suprapubic mass. Digital rectal examination shows a mildly enlarged, nontender prostate without any palpable masses. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A bedside ultrasound scan shows a large anechoic mass in the lower abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: This patient's anuria and palpable suprapubic mass along with a distended bladder (anechoic mass) on ultrasound suggest acute urinary retention (AUR). First-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) increase the risk of developing this condition, especially in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (as suggested by an enlarged, smooth, and nontender prostate on digital rectal examination).
learning_objective: Recognize acute urinary retention, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Although finasteride reduces the incidence of AUR in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia, which this patient most likely has, it is not used to treat acute episodes of urinary retention because it usually takes several months before it has a noticeable effect.
A suprapubic catheter can be placed in patients with AUR. However, a suprapubic catheter should only be placed if first-line therapy fails or is contraindicated.

answers.content: Obtain CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
answers.explanation_why: A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is useful for diagnosing urolithiasis, which can cause AUR if a calculus obstructs the urethral orifice. However, in a patient with urolithiasis, the pain is usually colicky and, since most calculi contain calcium, a hyperechoic calculus with an acoustic shadow is typically seen on ultrasound. In a patient with AUR, a different step is more appropriate at this point.

Bethanechol can be used to treat acute postoperative urinary retention, postpartum urinary retention, or urinary retention in patients with a neurogenic bladder. Furthermore, even in the presence of such indications, bethanechol is not the first-line treatment, as it does not provide immediate relief.

Relief of the overfilled bladder via transurethral catheterization is the treatment of choice for patients with AUR. Drug-induced AUR can result from decreased detrusor muscle contractility or increased urethral sphincter tone. Decreased detrusor muscle contractility is usually due to the anticholinergic effects of drugs such as anticholinergics, first-generation antihistamines, and tricyclic antidepressants. Increased urethral sphincter tone is typically due to the sympathomimetic effects of drugs such as beta and alpha-adrenergic agonists. Precipitating drugs, (e.g., drugs with sympathomimetic or anticholinergic effects) should be discontinued or substituted.

A normal saline bolus can be administered in patients with anuria secondary to prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI) as an attempt for fluid repletion. However, this patient's distended bladder indicates urinary tract obstruction (postrenal) rather than prerenal AKI. IV fluid administration is not indicated in this patient, as it would increase urine production, thereby exacerbating the AUR and bladder distention.

question_text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of multiple brown patches on the back of her hands that have increased in size during the past 6 months. She does not have any pain or itching. She is retired and spends most of her time in her garden, but she usually forgets to wear gloves or use sunscreen. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus well-controlled with an oral hypoglycemic agent. She smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 10 years ago when her granddaughter was born. Vital signs are within normal limits. Skin examination of both hands shows several flat, brown macules and patches; a photograph of the left hand is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to counseling on sun protection, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of multiple brown patches on the back of her hands that have increased in size during the past 6 months. She does not have any pain or itching. She is retired and spends most of her time in her garden, but she usually forgets to wear gloves or use sunscreen. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus well-controlled with an oral hypoglycemic agent. She smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 10 years ago when her granddaughter was born. Vital signs are within normal limits. Skin examination of both hands shows several flat, brown macules and patches; a photograph of the left hand is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to counseling on sun protection, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's history of extensive sun exposure and hyperpigmented macules and patches are most consistent with solar lentigo.
learning_objective: Recognize solar lentigo, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Topical imiquimod can be used in patients with actinic keratosis, a precancerous skin lesion that typically manifests on sun-exposed skin (e.g., the scalp, face, dorsal aspects of the hands or arms) and predominantly affects light-skinned individuals over 50 years of age. However, the lesion is initially small with a rough, sandpaper-like surface, which grows slowly in size and becomes erythematous and scaly. Solar lentigo should be managed differently.

images.title: Actinic keratosis
images.description: Right hand of an older patientMultiple scaly lesions on erythematous skin are visible.These lesions and their location (sun-exposed area) are typical of actinic keratosis.

answers.explanation_why: Solar lentigo is a benign skin condition commonly seen in older individuals with light skin. Flat, brown macules or patches occur as a result of the overproduction of melanin by existing keratinocytes or from the proliferation of melanocytes caused by prolonged sun exposure. No further interventions are necessary unless patients desire the removal of solar lentigines for cosmetic reasons. Limiting exposure to the sun as well as applying sunscreen can prevent the development of new lesions and decrease the darkening of existing lesions.

Surgical excision with a safety margin is performed in malignant skin conditions such as melanoma or basal cell carcinoma. However, this patient has solar lentigo, a benign condition caused by chronic solar damage. Surgical excision should be performed when malignancy is suspected, e.g., based on the ABCDE criteria. Chemical peels, cryotherapy, and laser modalities can be used to remove solar lentigo for cosmetic reasons.

images.title: Superficial spreading melanoma
images.description: A roughly symmetrical lesion with an irregular border and heterogeneous pigmentation can be seen. The lesion is approx. 12 mm in diameter and slightly raised.These findings suggest superficial spreading melanoma.

answers.explanation_why: Topical corticosteroids are used to treat various skin conditions, e.g., psoriasis, eczema, atopic dermatitis, and lichen planus. However, this patient has solar lentigo, a condition characterized by an increase in melanization. A triple combination cream containing steroids, hydroquinone, and tretinoin can be used as an adjuvant to cryotherapy in patients seeking to lighten hyperpigmented areas. Steroid use alone is not indicated in patients with solar lentigo.

Topical hydroquinone is a depigmenting agent that can be used in patients with severe melasma (chloasma). Melasma is a benign condition that is characterized by irregular, patchy hyperpigmentation of the skin and can be triggered and/or exacerbated by exposure to sunlight. However, melasma is most commonly seen in female individuals of reproductive age and those experiencing hormonal changes (e.g., pregnancy, oral contraceptive use).

images.title: Melasma
images.description: Multiple hyperpigmented, irregularly shaped maculae are visible across this patient's forehead. Smaller spots of hyperpigmentation are visible above the right eyebrow.These findings are indicative of melasma.

images.title: Solar lentigo
images.description: Multiple hyperpigmented brown macules are visible on this older patient's hand.This is the characteristic appearance and location of solar lentigo, which results from exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

question_text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter for a follow-up examination. He was diagnosed with Alzheimer disease 6 years ago. Three years ago, when he was no longer able to perform daily tasks and take care of himself, the patient moved in with his daughter, who is his surrogate decision-maker. Over the past year, he has been treated twice for food poisoning. He takes no medications. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 56 kg (115 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m^2. He appears tired and is oriented only to person. His temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 105/63 mm Hg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and dry skin and mucous membranes; capillary refill time is 2 seconds. There is a tender, nonblanching, erythematous area over the patient's sacrum with superficial skin loss. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation and increased bowel sounds. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. Neurologic examination shows ankle clonus and an ataxic gait. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 9/30. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.0 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 116 μm^3, and leukocyte count is 13,800/mm^3 (14% eosinophils). Microscopic evaluation of the stool shows multiple eggs of Diphyllobothrium latum. The patient is admitted to the hospital for treatment and further evaluation. The daughter asks if the patient could be treated at home. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter for a follow-up examination. He was diagnosed with Alzheimer disease 6 years ago. Three years ago, when he was no longer able to perform daily tasks and take care of himself, the patient moved in with his daughter, who is his surrogate decision-maker. Over the past year, he has been treated twice for food poisoning. He takes no medications. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 56 kg (115 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. He appears tired and is oriented only to person. His temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 105/63 mm Hg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and dry skin and mucous membranes; capillary refill time is 2 seconds. There is a tender, nonblanching, erythematous area over the patient's sacrum with superficial skin loss. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation and increased bowel sounds. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. Neurologic examination shows ankle clonus and an ataxic gait. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 9/30. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.0 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 116 μm3, and leukocyte count is 13,800/mm3 (14% eosinophils). Microscopic evaluation of the stool shows multiple eggs of Diphyllobothrium latum. The patient is admitted to the hospital for treatment and further evaluation. The daughter asks if the patient could be treated at home. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: This patient, who has severe cognitive impairment, has a fish tapeworm infection, which most likely has led to his megaloblastic anemia. He is also dehydrated, malnourished, and has a pressure ulcer, which cannot be explained by his medical history.
learning_objective: Recognize signs of elder neglect, and choose the appropriate agency to contact.

answers.content: Evaluate the patient's eligibility for home hospice care
answers.explanation_why: This patient is malnourished, has advanced Alzheimer dementia, and is almost completely dependent in all activities of daily living. The onset and progression of feeding difficulties is a hallmark of advanced dementia, which has a prognosis similar to other end-of-life conditions such as metastatic cancer and stage IV heart failure (i.e., life expectancy < 6 months); therefore, this patient may be eligible for home hospice care. However, his history of food poisoning, dehydration, and unexplained pressure ulcer make another step in management more appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Provide a prescription for necessary medications and discharge the patient
answers.explanation_why: Physicians should consider requests made by surrogate decision-makers if the patient lacks decision-making capacity, which is the case here. However, this patient's unexplained malnutrition and dehydration require further investigation before he is discharged.

Older adult abuse, including older adult neglect, is frequently perpetrated by someone with power over and responsibility for the patient (e.g., a caregiver or relative, as seen here). In this case, the patient presents with signs of malnourishment, dehydration, and an unexplained pressure ulcer, all of which should raise suspicion for older adult neglect. In the US, physicians are legally and ethically obligated to report suspected older adult abuse to Adult Protective Services if the patient lives at home or with a relative or to the Long-Term Care Ombudsman programs if the abuse occurred in an institution (e.g., assisted living facility). Apart from investigating complaints, these agencies protect older adults by providing them with social, medical, and legal aid.

answers.content: Obtain the patient's approval for discharge
answers.explanation_why: This patient's Mini-Mental State Examination score suggests he has advanced dementia (i.e., any score below 13/30), which means he most likely lacks decision-making capacity. Therefore, he cannot consent to his own discharge.

answers.content: Reach out to a health care assistance program
answers.explanation_why: Health care assistance programs, which include Medicare and county-specific programs, are financial aid programs designed to improve health care access among low-income individuals. The current state of this patient, who lacks decision-making capacity and is dependent on his daughter for health care, is not the result of a lack of financial resources but neglect; a different step is required in the case of older adult neglect.

question_text: A 78-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department an hour after falling on the road while taking her dog for a walk. She says that she has not lost consciousness but “simply tripped over a rock.” A similar event happened 2 weeks ago when she fell while grocery shopping. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her family history is significant for Parkinson disease. She does not smoke cigarettes and drinks one to two glasses of wine each week. Current medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, aspirin, metformin, and empagliflozin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. Examination shows an abrasion on her right knee and a deep cut on her right hand. Neurologic examination shows normal sensation to pinprick and vibration. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the left lower limb and 2+ in the right lower limb. She was able to get up out of her chair and walk to the wall and back to the chair without any problems. Which of the following is the most important risk factor for future falls in this patient?
content_preview: A 78-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department an hour after falling on the road while taking her dog for a walk. She says that she has not lost consciousness but “simply tripped over a rock.” A similar event happened 2 weeks ago when she fell while grocery shopping. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her family history is significant for Parkinson disease. She does not smoke cigarettes and drinks one to two glasses of wine each week. Current medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, aspirin, metformin, and empagliflozin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. Examination shows an abrasion on her right knee and a deep cut on her right hand. Neurologic examination shows normal sensation to pinprick and vibration. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the left lower limb and 2+ in the right lower limb. She was able to get up out of her chair and walk to the wall and back to the chair without any problems. Which of the following is the most important risk factor for future falls in this patient?
hint: The “Timed Up and Go” test is used to assess musculoskeletal function and postural stability in patients who have fallen. The patient is asked to get up from a chair, walk a certain distance, turn around, walk back, and sit down again.
learning_objective: Recall the main risk factor for future falls in older individuals.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's history of previous falls is the main risk factor for future falls. Falls in older individuals are usually due to a combination of age-related factors (e.g., lower-extremity weakness, cognitive and/or visual impairment), underlying medical conditions (e.g., Parkinson disease, osteoarthritis of the knee, orthostatic hypotension), and environmental hazards (e.g., slippery surfaces). Certain medications, such as benzodiazepines, increase the risk of falling. Patients who have fallen should undergo a risk assessment that involves testing of visual acuity, cognitive, neurological, musculoskeletal, and hearing function, postural vital signs, and past medical history including information about the circumstances of the current as well as previous falls. Strategies to prevent further falls include minimizing medications, physical therapy, and modifying the older individual's home environment.

While medication use is an important risk factor for falls, this patient's current medications are not known to pose a risk. Drugs commonly associated with an increased risk of falling include central nervous system active drugs (e.g., antipsychotics, benzodiazepines, antidepressants) and vasodilators.

Patients with peripheral neuropathy are at increased risk for falls due to progressive loss of sensation and weakness in the distal lower extremities. Though this patient has diabetes and is therefore at risk for developing peripheral neuropathy, her neurological exam showed no abnormal findings.

Orthostatic hypotension is common in older persons and is often associated with falls. While orthostatic hypotension is a known side effect of antihypertensive agents, ACE inhibitors such as enalapril are not implicated. Moreover, orthostatic hypotension typically manifests with symptoms such as dizziness, lightheadedness, and possibly loss of consciousness upon standing, none of which are reported by this patient.

Underlying chronic diseases such as Parkinson disease (PD) are an important risk factor for falls. While this patient's family history of PD raises her risk of developing this condition, she shows no signs or symptoms of PD.
Though heavy alcohol use is a known risk factor for falls, light use, such as the one to two glasses of wine this patient drinks each week, is not associated with an increased risk of falling.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because his wife is worried about a lesion on his face. She first noticed it 4 months ago and thinks it has grown but she is unsure. The patient says he feels well and that the lesion does not bother him. He has a 10-year history of hypertension. His family history is unremarkable. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and enalapril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a soft, painless, 5-mm papule on the right cheek; a photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because his wife is worried about a lesion on his face. She first noticed it 4 months ago and thinks it has grown but she is unsure. The patient says he feels well and that the lesion does not bother him. He has a 10-year history of hypertension. His family history is unremarkable. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and enalapril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a soft, painless, 5-mm papule on the right cheek; a photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The photograph shows a sharply demarcated and darkly pigmented papule that has a “stuck-on” appearance. This type of lesion in an older individual is characteristic of seborrheic keratosis.
learning_objective: Recognize seborrheic keratosis, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why:
Seborrheic keratosis is a benign, slow-growing lesion that is commonly seen in older individuals. For asymptomatic lesions, such as the one seen here, treatment is generally not necessary and reassurance with follow-up is sufficient. If atypical features are present (e.g., asymmetry, rapid change or growth, ulceration) or if the diagnosis is unclear, a biopsy may be indicated. Treatment with cryotherapy, laser therapy, or surgical excision is appropriate for cosmetic removal or if the lesion becomes symptomatic (e.g., pruritic, painful, or bleeds easily).

In patients with the sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses, known as the Leser-Trélat sign, further investigation is necessary because of this feature's association with malignancies such as lung cancer and gastrointestinal cancer.

Topical salicylic acid is the first-line treatment for warts, which can manifest as soft papules on the face (i.e., flat warts or verruca plana). However, flat warts are more common in younger individuals and they are usually flesh-colored, smooth, and flat, whereas this elderly patient's lesion is darkly pigmented and has a “stuck-on” appearance. Salicylic acid treatment is not recommended for seborrheic keratosis.

images.title: Common warts
images.description: Partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are seen on the dorsal surface of the hand at the level of the metacarpophalangeal joint

answers.explanation_why: A shave biopsy might be indicated to rule out malignancy in patients with pigmented skin lesions with atypical features (e.g., size > 6 mm; a recent change in shape, size, or color; irregular borders; asymmetry). This patient, however, has a small (5 mm), asymptomatic lesion that has not changed much over the past 4 months and has a waxy, “stuck-on” appearance, all of which are characteristic of seborrheic keratosis.

An excisional biopsy is indicated for pigmented lesions if there is suspicion for melanoma. According to the ABCDE rule for melanoma, a biopsy should be considered if the lesion is > 6 mm in diameter, asymmetric, has color variegation, irregular borders, or recent change in size, shape, or color. This patient's lesion has a waxy, “stuck-on” appearance characteristic of seborrheic keratosis, for which biopsy is not routinely indicated.

images.title: Superficial spreading melanoma
images.description: Upper backAn asymmetrical lesion approx. 16 mm in diameter is visible.This lesion fulfills the A (asymmetry), B (border irregularity), C (color variegation), and D (diameter > 6 mm) criteria for melanoma. The diagnosis should be confirmed by performing a full-thickness excisional biopsy.

answers.explanation_why: Cryotherapy is the most common treatment for seborrheic keratosis. However, cryotherapy is indicated in symptomatic lesions or if the patient requests treatment for cosmetic reasons, which is not the case here.

images.title: Seborrheic keratosis
images.description: A sharply demarcated darkly pigmented papule with a greasy, stuck-on appearance is visible.This is the typical appearance of seborrheic keratosis.

question_text: A 73-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He feels well. Following the recent death of his wife, he moved in with his daughter. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He is physically active and exercises three to four times weekly. His medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (177 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows ecchymoses on the dorsal aspect of the patient's forearms bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 205,000/mm^3, a prothrombin time of 12 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time of 30 seconds, and a bleeding time of 3 minutes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's physical examination findings?
content_preview: A 73-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He feels well. Following the recent death of his wife, he moved in with his daughter. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He is physically active and exercises three to four times weekly. His medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (177 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows ecchymoses on the dorsal aspect of the patient's forearms bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 205,000/mm3, a prothrombin time of 12 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time of 30 seconds, and a bleeding time of 3 minutes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's physical examination findings?
hint: Other findings associated with this patient's presentation include presbyopia, occasional word-finding difficulty, and bilateral hearing loss.
learning_objective: Recognize senile purpura as a normal aging process.

answers.explanation_why: Aspirin use increases the risk of bleeding, bleeding time, and bruising, which typically manifest as ecchymoses after minor trauma (most commonly on the lower extremities). While this patient has bilateral ecchymoses on the dorsal forearms, it was not preceded by any trauma. The absence of prior trauma and this patient's normal bleeding time make aspirin use an unlikely explanation for his symptoms.

Senile purpura is a benign skin condition that typically affects individuals aged > 50 years and manifests with recurrent, irregularly-shaped, dark purple macules. It is caused by progressive loss of dermal connective tissue, subcutaneous fat, and blood vessel elasticity with age, all of which results in increased susceptibility to bruising in elderly individuals. Senile purpura is more common in light-skinned persons (due to increased sensitivity to sunlight) and typically develops on sun-exposed areas (e.g., forearms, face, neck). The diagnosis is clinical and does not require further evaluation.

images.title: Senile purpura and skin atrophy
images.description: Forearm of an elderly patientThere are multiple irregular dark purple macules with well-defined margins. The surrounding skin appears thin and inelastic.

answers.explanation_why: Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) can develop in a patient aged > 55 years and manifest with ecchymoses. However, ITP is characterized by a low platelet count (< 100,000/mm^3). This patient's normal platelet count is inconsistent with ITP.

Nutrient deficiency (e.g., protein malnutrition, vitamin K or vitamin C deficiency) can increase an individual's risk of bleeding and bruising and manifest with ecchymoses. However, nutrient deficiency typically develops in individuals who are chronically ill, have limited access to food, or have malabsorption diseases (e.g., pancreatic insufficiency, celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease), none of which apply to this man.

Physical abuse is a potential cause of bruising in an elderly individual with a normal coagulation profile. However, most elderly individuals who experience physical abuse present with asymmetric skin lesions in unusual locations, unexplained fractures, signs of malnutrition, depressed mood, and, in rare cases, suicidality. This patient's isolated bruising and the symmetric bilateral ecchymoses on the dorsal forearms make another etiology more likely.

content_preview: Patient Information Age: 68 years Gender: M, self-identified Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have been falling down a lot lately.” History of Present Illness: several falls in the past 2 months; no major injuries feels unsteady when walking no loss of consciousness or vertigo Past Medical History: 5-year history of Parkinson disease 3-year history of major depressive disorder with psychotic features; currently no depressive or psychotic symptoms presbyopia, corrected with glasses; last visit to ophthalmologist 4 months ago Medications: carbidopa-levodopa mirtazapine Vaccinations: up-to-date Allergies: no known drug, food, or contact allergies Family History: mother and father deceased Psychosocial History: retired elementary school teacher lives alone since his wife died 2 years ago has two children who visit him frequently and a supportive network of friends Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 36.7°C(98.1°F) 78/min 14/min 130/80 mm Hg 97% on RA 172 cm(5 ft 8 in) 75 kg(165 lb) 25 kg/m2 Appearance: alert and well HEENT: PERRLA Pulmonary: clear to auscultation Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs Abdominal: bowel sounds normoactive; soft, nontender Extremities: several bruises of varying size, age, and color on forearms, knees, and shins bilaterally Neurologic: reduced arm swing; mild resting tremor of the right hand; postural instability on pull test; findings stable compared to last visit 6 months ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Falls are a common problem, even in well-controlled Parkinson disease, mainly because of postural instability and unsteady gait.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for an elderly individual who experiences frequent falls.

answers.explanation_why: Physical therapy is indicated in all older adults with evidence of poor gait, strength, or balance (e.g., patients with Parkinson disease). In addition to physical therapy, this patient would benefit from a fall risk assessment to identify more personalized preventive measures (e.g., occupational therapy, home hazard assessment and modification). Falls are the leading cause of injury-related death in adults aged ≥ 65 years. All older adults should be counseled on fall prevention strategies and screened for fall risk annually, beginning with the question: “Have you fallen in the past year?” A fall risk assessment should be performed for individuals who screen positive for fall risk and those who present after an acute fall.

Although SSRIs like citalopram are generally safe and effective for treating depression in individuals with Parkinson disease, this patient has no indications for switching to another class of antidepressants (e.g., inadequate symptom control, adverse effects). While mirtazapine can cause drowsiness, SSRIs like citalopram have a higher risk of orthostatic hypotension and have been associated with an increased risk of falling in the elderly.

Initiating another medication for Parkinson disease, such as rotigotine, is indicated in patients with refractory symptoms or intolerable adverse effects that require dose reduction of the current regimen. This patient's symptoms are well controlled with carbidopa-levodopa, and another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

While visual acuity testing is an important part of fall prevention, this patient's presbyopia is corrected with glasses, and his last ophthalmology visit was four months ago. Therefore, another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

Previously, vitamin D was administered routinely to patients with an increased risk of falls but currently, the USPSTF advises against routine vitamin D supplementation for community-dwelling older patients at increased risk for falls unless evidence of osteoporosis or vitamin D deficiency is present. It would be appropriate to screen for vitamin D deficiency and osteoporosis in this patient, but another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

question_text: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated in the rehabilitation facility of a hospital 2 weeks after admission for an ischemic stroke that resulted in right hemiparesis. She has been recovering well. She can walk with the aid of a walker, has no speech impairment, and tolerates a regular diet. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications are metformin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and daily aspirin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Cranial nerves are intact. Muscle strength in the extremities is 5/5 on the left and 3/5 on the right. Sensation is intact bilaterally. Standardized assessment of cognitive function shows mild impairment. The patient says that she is tired of being in the hospital. She lives alone in a small apartment on the ground floor with no stairs. The patient's daughter agrees to take care of her mother but mentions that she cannot afford to take any more time off work. The daughter works part-time as a kindergarten teacher. Which of the following is the most appropriate action to ensure the patient's well-being?
content_preview: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated in the rehabilitation facility of a hospital 2 weeks after admission for an ischemic stroke that resulted in right hemiparesis. She has been recovering well. She can walk with the aid of a walker, has no speech impairment, and tolerates a regular diet. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications are metformin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and daily aspirin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Cranial nerves are intact. Muscle strength in the extremities is 5/5 on the left and 3/5 on the right. Sensation is intact bilaterally. Standardized assessment of cognitive function shows mild impairment. The patient says that she is tired of being in the hospital. She lives alone in a small apartment on the ground floor with no stairs. The patient's daughter agrees to take care of her mother but mentions that she cannot afford to take any more time off work. The daughter works part-time as a kindergarten teacher. Which of the following is the most appropriate action to ensure the patient's well-being?
hint: Discharge planning is the process of developing an individualized plan to ensure the safe transition of a patient from the hospital to another care setting (e.g., home health care, skilled nursing facility).
learning_objective: Recognize the role of a social worker in multidisciplinary discharge planning.

answers.explanation_why: Prolonged hospitalization can raise certain risks (e.g., hospital-acquired infections) in older patients and disrupt others' access to care. In addition, physicians should be mindful of the impact on health care resources (e.g., staffing, health care costs). This patient is medically stable and should not be kept at the hospital any longer than necessary.

answers.content: Transfer responsibility for discharge planning to the patient's daughter
answers.explanation_why: The physician should involve the patient's family and future caregivers in discharge planning and identify who will be primarily responsible for understanding the discharge instructions. However, physicians, together with other health care personnel, are obligated to ensure safe discharge planning, and this responsibility cannot be transferred to a family member.

answers.content: Discharge the patient to an assisted living facility
answers.explanation_why: An inpatient program (e.g., assisted living facilities) may be appropriate for patients who require skilled care services. However, assuming that a safe discharge can be ensured, the patient's needs and preferences should also be considered during discharge planning. Therefore, discharge to an assisted living facility without prior discussion with the patient and their family is inappropriate.

answers.content: Discuss a plan for regular outpatient visits with the patient
answers.explanation_why: Physicians should involve patients in decision-making processes (e.g., discharge planning) and respect their individual preferences. This patient with a history of stroke, hemiparesis, and mild cognitive impairment requires skilled medical services (e.g., physical therapy, skilled nursing care) and is unlikely to be able to travel to outpatient therapy. Therefore, a plan that only consists of regular outpatient visits is not feasible.

answers.content: Involve a social worker in discharge planning
answers.explanation_why:
The physician is responsible for assessing whether to involve a multidisciplinary team of discharge planners (usually social workers and/or nurses). Discharge planners can be especially helpful for patients who are at high risk for adverse events after discharge and require ongoing skilled care. Discharge planning should be initiated as early as possible and includes a psychosocial assessment, discharge counseling, medication reconciliation, planning of follow-up visits, and coordination of services. The patient, their family, and future caregivers should be involved to establish a plan that meets the patient's medical needs and personal preferences. Effective discharge planning can increase patient satisfaction, reduce the duration of hospitalization, and decrease readmission rates.

Home health care should be considered for patients who live at home and require complex ongoing care but are unable to travel. This form of rehabilitation reduces costs while avoiding the risks associated with prolonged hospitalization (e.g., nosocomial infections).

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 73 years
Sex: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I still feel unsteady while washing and dressing.”
History of Present Illness:

evaluated 3 months ago because of a 6-month history of multiple falls often preceded by dizziness; no abnormalities on resting ECG
at the last visit, compression stocking therapy was initiated and she was counseled on physical counterpressure measures and the need for an increase in fluid and sodium intake

reports worsening symptoms; two falls in the last two weeks, one of which occurred when getting up quickly from bed to go to the bathroom

Past Medical History:

Parkinson disease diagnosed 5 years ago
Medications:
levodopa-carbidopa
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP 
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

36.8°C
(98.2°F)

89/min and regular
14/min

134/82 mm Hg (lying down)
110/70 mm Hg (after standing for 5 min)

-

170 cm
(5 ft 7 in)
60 kg
(132 lb)
20 kg/m^2

Appearance: comfortable; not in acute distress
Cardiac: S1 and S2; no murmur or gallop
Neurologic: mild resting tremor; no other abnormalities

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: Patient Information Age: 73 years Sex: F, self-identified Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I still feel unsteady while washing and dressing.” History of Present Illness: evaluated 3 months ago because of a 6-month history of multiple falls often preceded by dizziness; no abnormalities on resting ECG at the last visit, compression stocking therapy was initiated and she was counseled on physical counterpressure measures and the need for an increase in fluid and sodium intake reports worsening symptoms; two falls in the last two weeks, one of which occurred when getting up quickly from bed to go to the bathroom Past Medical History: Parkinson disease diagnosed 5 years ago Medications: levodopa-carbidopa Allergies: no known drug allergies Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 36.8°C(98.2°F) 89/min and regular 14/min 134/82 mm Hg (lying down)110/70 mm Hg (after standing for 5 min) - 170 cm(5 ft 7 in) 60 kg(132 lb) 20 kg/m2 Appearance: comfortable; not in acute distress Cardiac: S1 and S2; no murmur or gallop Neurologic: mild resting tremor; no other abnormalities Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: A sustained decrease in systolic BP by ≥ 20 mm Hg and/or diastolic BP by ≥ 10 mm Hg from the supine to standing position is consistent with orthostatic hypotension. This patient's orthostatic hypotension and syncope are most likely the result of autonomic dysfunction due to Parkinson disease (neurogenic orthostatic hypotension).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for orthostatic hypotension due to autonomic dysfunction in Parkinson disease.

answers.explanation_why: Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, can be used for refractory postprandial hypotension and for refractory neurogenic orthostatic hypotension but is not the first-line treatment.

Selegiline, a monoamine oxidase type B (MAO-B) inhibitor, is used as an adjunct in patients with Parkinson disease for treating an akinetic crisis and for the short-term treatment of mild parkinsonism with bradykinesia and postural instability as the predominant symptoms. MAO-B inhibitors have no role in the treatment of orthostatic hypotension.

Propranolol, a nonselective beta blocker, is used to treat postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS) and cardiac syncope due to certain arrhythmias. Cardiac syncope often manifests without any prodrome, i.e., a sudden fall without a preceding sensation of dizziness, and POTS manifests with an abnormal increase in the heart rate by ≥ 30 beats per minute when moving from a supine to an upright position without significant orthostatic hypotension. Propranolol is not used to treat orthostatic hypotension because it may exacerbate the condition.

The initial treatment of orthostatic syncope is nonpharmacological and consists of an increase in fluid and sodium intake, discontinuing or decreasing the dosage of offending or contributing drugs (e.g., diuretics, antihypertensives), compression stocking therapy, and education on physical countermeasures (e.g., muscle tensing, leg crossing). If nonpharmacological treatment fails, treatment with an alpha-1 adrenergic agonist (e.g., midodrine) is indicated. Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor agonists, which are also used to treat recurrent vasovagal syncope and postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome, increase vascular tone and thereby increase blood pressure. Contraindications for alpha-1 adrenergic receptor agonists include urinary retention and hypertension. Alternative first-line medications for neurogenic orthostatic syncope include fludrocortisone and droxidopa but droxidopa may interact with antiparkinson drugs.
Pyridostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, can be used for refractory neurogenic orthostatic hypotension but is not the first-line treatment.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 29 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: Asian
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “It takes me ages to fall asleep.”
History of Present Illness:

sleep onset typically around 3:00 a.m.

lies awake for several hours if he tries to sleep earlier
prefers to sleep until noon, including on weekends and holidays

excessive drowsiness on days when he is required to wake up early for work meetings
has been a “night owl” since his teenage years
drinks approx. 5 coffees every day
gradual worsening of symptoms over the past 6 months that has started to affect his work

Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
noncontributory
Psychosocial history:

works from home as a freelancer in software development
lives alone
does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use substances or non-prescribed drugs

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

37°C
(98.6°F)

72/min
16/min
130/85 mm Hg
98% on RA

178 cm
(5 ft 10 in)
72.6 kg
(160 lb)
23 kg/m^2

Appearance: well-nourished, well-groomed; no acute distress
Skin: warm, dry; no rashes or lesions
HEENT: PERRLA
Neck: supple; no lymphadenopathy; no thyroid enlargement or nodules
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation bilaterally; no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi
Cardiac: regular rate and rhythm; no murmurs, rubs, or gallop
Abdominal: normal bowel sounds; soft, non-tender, non-distended; no hepatosplenomegaly
Extremities: no cyanosis, clubbing, or edema; full range of motion; no deformities
Neurologic: alert and fully oriented to person, place, and time; cranial nerves II-XII grossly intact; normal muscle strength and tone; sensation intact; normal gait and coordination

In addition to sleep hygiene counseling, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: Patient Information Age: 29 years Gender: M, self-identified Race/Ethnicity: Asian Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “It takes me ages to fall asleep.” History of Present Illness: sleep onset typically around 3:00 a.m. lies awake for several hours if he tries to sleep earlier prefers to sleep until noon, including on weekends and holidays excessive drowsiness on days when he is required to wake up early for work meetings has been a “night owl” since his teenage years drinks approx. 5 coffees every day gradual worsening of symptoms over the past 6 months that has started to affect his work Past Medical History: unremarkable Medications: none Vaccinations: up-to-date Allergies: no known drug allergies Family History: noncontributory Psychosocial history: works from home as a freelancer in software development lives alone does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use substances or non-prescribed drugs Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 37°C(98.6°F) 72/min 16/min 130/85 mm Hg 98% on RA 178 cm(5 ft 10 in) 72.6 kg(160 lb) 23 kg/m2 Appearance: well-nourished, well-groomed; no acute distress Skin: warm, dry; no rashes or lesions HEENT: PERRLA Neck: supple; no lymphadenopathy; no thyroid enlargement or nodules Pulmonary: clear to auscultation bilaterally; no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi Cardiac: regular rate and rhythm; no murmurs, rubs, or gallop Abdominal: normal bowel sounds; soft, non-tender, non-distended; no hepatosplenomegaly Extremities: no cyanosis, clubbing, or edema; full range of motion; no deformities Neurologic: alert and fully oriented to person, place, and time; cranial nerves II-XII grossly intact; normal muscle strength and tone; sensation intact; normal gait and coordination In addition to sleep hygiene counseling, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: This patient presents with a recurrent delay in sleep onset and waking times compared to social norms. He has a normal duration of sleep when allowed to set his own schedule but experiences excessive drowsiness on days when he must wake up early. This pattern is consistent with delayed sleep phase disorder (DSPD).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for delayed sleep phase disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Mirtazapine is used to treat major depressive disorder in individuals with insomnia. Although this patient has difficulty falling asleep, he reports no symptoms of depression. This patient presents with features of DSPD, for which mirtazapine is not used.

Melatonin receptor agonists (e.g., ramelteon) help to realign the circadian rhythm and can be used to treat insomnia and some circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorders, including DSPD. Ramelteon should be administered at night, at least 90 minutes before bed. Management of DSPD additionally includes phototherapy in the morning and several behavioral modifications, such as avoiding certain substances (e.g., caffeine, nicotine, and alcohol) and refraining from daytime naps or stimulating activity before bedtime. Furthermore, sleep schedule adjustments (e.g., chronotherapy) may be considered.

Reassurance is sufficient for sleep disorders that resolve spontaneously (e.g., jet lag disorder) and for sleep disorders that do not affect the patient's daily life. This patient has DSPD, which is not likely to resolve spontaneously and does affect his work.

Modafinil can be used in individuals with severe shift-work disorder, which causes sleep deprivation, and in those with hypersomnolence disorder, which is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness. This patient presents with features of DSPD, for which modafinil is not used.

Scototherapy, which involves the avoidance or reduction of light exposure in the evening, is used to treat non-24-hour sleep-wake disorder (N24SWD) in sighted individuals. Individuals with N24SWD present with an irregular circadian rhythm that does not adjust to the light-dark cycle, whereas this patient presents with features of DSPD. Although scototherapy may be useful as adjunctive therapy for DSPD, another treatment is more appropriate.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a 3-month history of chest pain, dyspnea on mild exertion, and episodic loss of consciousness. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and obstructive sleep apnea, for which he uses nocturnal PAP. The patient is widowed, lives alone, and has two adult children. Medications are amlodipine and ramipril. He does not drink alcoholic beverages or smoke cigarettes. He is not in acute distress. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (181 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2^. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Cardiac examination reveals an S4 heart sound most prominent at the apex and a grade 4 late systolic ejection murmur best heard in the second right intercostal space. The murmur radiates bilaterally to the carotids and decreases in intensity with handgrip. Which of the following factors in this patient most strongly predicts a poor prognosis?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a 3-month history of chest pain, dyspnea on mild exertion, and episodic loss of consciousness. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and obstructive sleep apnea, for which he uses nocturnal PAP. The patient is widowed, lives alone, and has two adult children. Medications are amlodipine and ramipril. He does not drink alcoholic beverages or smoke cigarettes. He is not in acute distress. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (181 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Cardiac examination reveals an S4 heart sound most prominent at the apex and a grade 4 late systolic ejection murmur best heard in the second right intercostal space. The murmur radiates bilaterally to the carotids and decreases in intensity with handgrip. Which of the following factors in this patient most strongly predicts a poor prognosis?
hint: A grade 4 late systolic ejection murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space and radiating bilaterally to the carotids indicates aortic valve stenosis (AS).
learning_objective: Recognize aortic stenosis, and recall its prognostic factors.

answers.explanation_why: Angina pectoris due to myocardial ischemia and syncope caused by poor cerebral perfusion are symptoms of severe AS and are associated with a poor prognosis. Approximately half of patients with AS die within 5 years after the onset of angina, and half die within 3 years after the onset of syncope. However, another factor in this patient more strongly predicts a poor prognosis.

Murmur radiation to the carotids is a typical clinical feature of AS. However, in severe AS, the radiated murmur may become barely audible due to left ventricular failure and decreased cardiac output. Therefore, this clinical sign is not the most significant prognostic factor for AS.

Dyspnea is an early sign of heart failure, which occurs in severe AS as a result of left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. While patients with AS can be asymptomatic for years, the onset of symptoms usually indicates a progression to severe AS. Mortality rates increase from less than 1% per year in asymptomatic patients to over 50% within the first two years after the onset of symptoms if left untreated. Dyspnea is the strongest predictor of a poor prognosis, followed by syncope and angina pectoris. Approximately half of AS patients with dyspnea die within 2 years of symptom onset. Aortic valve replacement can slow the rapid decline in life expectancy after the onset of symptoms.
answers.explanation_but: Dihydropyridines (e.g., amlodipine) are contraindicated in patients with severe stenotic heart valve defects. This patient should be switched to another antihypertensive.

answers.explanation_why: An S4 heart sound indicates ventricular hypertrophy and results from late diastolic atrial contraction against high ventricular pressure. In young patients, S4 heart sound signifies severe AS. In older individuals, an S4 heart sound may occur in the absence of overt heart disease and is therefore not the strongest predictor of poor prognosis in this patient.

The timing and duration of the systolic murmur correlate with the severity of AS. Mild to moderate AS typically manifests with an early peaking murmur, while severe AS is characterized by a longer late systolic murmur. While most murmurs with an intensity of grade 3 or higher are pathological, their intensity does not always correlate with the clinical severity of the underlying lesion. The murmur in severe AS decreases in intensity and may even disappear once the patient develops left heart failure.
